dayInfo.description: Arrive into Colombo Airport and head to Villa Hundira which takes approximately 30 minutes. Villa Hundira is a modern, private villa nestled amidst two acres of lush tropical gardens and edged by the tranquil Negombo Lagoon. Interiors are a stylish blend of contemporary architecture and furniture, art, and sculptures from Sri Lanka and the orient. High roofs, large glass doors and windows allow for spectacular views of the lagoon where local fisherman go about their day’s work. A small tributary of the lagoon even runs through the gardens making it possible for guests to hop on a boat right from the living room terrace. Spend the rest of the day at leisure.

Today you will be transferred to The Ibis in Wilpattu to experience the Wildlife, this transfer takes approximately 4.5 hours. Nestled on the banks of a local lake amidst a green wilderness minutes away from the largest national park in the island, Ibis is a charming rustic bungalow setting. Offering accommodation in two bedrooms located either side of an open living area with all modern facilities, Ibis is ideal for wildlife enthusiasts and guests who enjoy rustic living. You could walk around the property to experience the wildlife. Walk with a naturalist and spot wild creatures in the late evening.

Today you will be going on a morning and evening jeep safari to the Wilpattu National park. Wilpattu offers travelers the chance to get up-close-and-personal with Sri Lanka’s wildlife: go on an enthralling game drive through the park, looking out for leopards, elephants, sloth bear and deer as well as a wide variety of migrant and endemic birds, and enjoy the spectacular scenery of lakes, jungle, grasslands and the stunning coastal border.

After breakfast you will be heading to the Northern Province which takes approximately 5hours. Surrounded by the rich culture and history in the Northern peninsula that dates back to the 13th century, Jetwing Jaffna is the latest project by the Jetwing group. Featuring 55 stylishly-designed bedrooms, the accommodation offers luxury whilst giving the guests the opportunity to explore a part of Sri Lanka that has been shrouded in mystery for the past few decades. Relax after the long drive.

Visit The Nallur Kandaswamy Kovil, one of Jaffna’s most significant Hindu temples and the fourth re-built structure, since the original temple was built in 948. The temple is a socially important institution for the Sri Lankan Tamils Hindu identity of north Sri Lanka and for the Sri Lankan Tamil diaspora. Located in the ancient capital town of Nallur in Jaffna, it is recorded that the center of the city was once a bustling market place, surrounded by a square fortification that sheltered courtly buildings for kings, Brahmin priests and soldiers. The old Nallur Kandaswamy temple functioned within this ancient defensive fort, among a city that was laid out like the traditional temple town according to Hindu traditions. Then visit the The library, which was built in 1933 and burnt in 1981. During the early 1980s, it was one of the biggest libraries in Asia, containing over 97,000 books and manuscripts. In 2001, rehabilitation of the library was completed, with new structure being built and new books received, although its old books and manuscripts were not replaced. It is Sri Lanka‘s second main public Library only rivaled by the Library in Colombo.

Today visit Sri Lanka’s forgotten island, the Delft Island. The day is one of discovery! Your chauffeur driver will drive you along the causeway to board a boat which will take you to Delft Island, off the Jaffna peninsula. Your host for the day is a Pastor, who originally hails from Sri Lanka’s tea country. Having made his home at Delft, your host will show you around this remote island, allowing you to take in the sights of the old Delft Fort, an ancient Baobab tree and how Palmyra toddy and crafts are made with local farmers. Ask to see the wild ponies grazing. End the day with a simple lunch with the Pastor and his wife at their humble home. Before leaving Delft, a swim after lunch at the beach, not far from your host’s house offers for one of the most relaxed and non-touristic encounters you will have on this journey. The beach is not developed, and has a calm and gentle sea.

Today transfer to Anuradhapura, which takes around 4hours. Forest Rock Garden Resort is designed around a 50-acre wilderness with rock boulders, ponds and waterways, age old trees and lotus filled ponds. Even the rooms and suites at this much-praised resort are raised above ground to the level of the tree canopy to avoid any disturbance to the untouched wilderness below. A sturdy network of concrete pillars and meandering walkways connects the rooms to the restaurant, swimming pool and other facilities, allowing the animals that inhabit this land, including deer and wild elephants to pass through along their natural jungle corridors. Forest Rock Garden Resort offers luxurious Deluxe Rooms and Suites; traditional Sri Lankan and Western vegetarian cuisine; mind and body wellness through Ayurveda and meditation; and a serene setting that will leave you totally rejuvenated.

After breakfast, transfer to Sigiriya which takes approximately around 1hour. You could climb the Sigiriya Rock fortress in the evening to experience the sunset at the top of the rock. Sigiriya, also known as Lion Rock, built on top of a huge boulder in the 5th century. A palace. A rock fortress. The hidden castle of King Kasyapa. A Buddhist monastery from the 14th century. Similar to the cosmic mountain of Meru? The eighth wonder of the world? No place in Sri Lanka has generated as many theories and legends as the 180m monolith, set amidst stunning scenery. Then drive to Polonnaruwa which takes around 1hour. Visit the ancient ruins of Polonnaruwa which is the second most ancient kingdom of Sri Lanka. Pollonaruwa is divided into 4 areas. The visit starts with the Kings Palace and Baths. We then visit 3 different tooth relic temples and then proceed to the stupas. The visit ends on the far western side of the complex where you will see one of the most astonishing Buda rock carvings in Sri Lanka. One can walk, bike or drive between locations. It’s hot – no doubt. If it looks like it might rain don’t forget to take an umbrella from the vehicle. Drive back to Anuradhapura.

Visit the kingdom of Anuradhapura. Anuradhapura consists of more than a dozen archeological sites. Typically one moves around from site to site either by bike or inside the vehicle. The most important / significant sites are the 3 largest man-made stupas in Sri Lanka, which were – at the time of the pyramids of Egypt – the second largest man-made structures in the world. Then Sri Maha Bodhi, is a Sacred Fig said to be the southern branch from the tree under which lord Buddha was enlightened. Altogether the visit to Anuradhapura takes approximately 2 to 3 hours.

Transfer to Kegalle, this transfer takes around 3.5hours. Built in 1926, Rosyth Estate House is a seven-bedroom planter’s bungalow perched on a hillock about 1,100ft above sea level. Rosyth consists of the original Main House, located at a higher level, the swimming pool terrace (a level below) and a separate Duplex Unit. Rosyth is designed with verandas, courtyards and terraces that let you enjoy the tropical climate and lush gardens scattered with fruit trees. Rosyth Estate House offers well-appointed bedrooms, traditional Sri Lankan cuisine and a peaceful holiday setting. Visit the tea factory late in the afternoon. Just a few minutes’ walk from the house is the local tea factory & whilst not part of the estate, guests are welcome to visit the factory and understand the process of tea.

Guided tour around the Peradeniya Botanical gardens with a botanist at around 10am. Your guide will buy your entrance. Your chauffeur guide will wait for you in the vehicle outside. It’s a leisurely walk in a circular fashion. Our expert in Botany is a walking encyclopedia. Even if you have very little interest in Botany he makes the visit interesting and insightful with plenty of quirks and little side stories. For some it’s the best visit of them all in Sri Lanka. Visit the Temple of the Relic, Sri Dalada Maligawa or the Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic is a Buddhist temple in the city of Kandy, Sri Lanka. It is located in the royal palace complex which houses the relic of the tooth of Buddha. Since ancient times, the relic has played an important role in local politics because it is believed that whoever holds the relic holds the governance of the country. Kandy was the last capital of the Sri Lankan kings and is a UNESCO world heritage site partly due to the temple.

Transfer to Colombo leisurely, this transfer takes approximately 3.5hours. Galle Face Hotel is a heritage property that dates back to 1864. Once the mansion of a British Governor, this masterpiece of Victorian architecture was refurbished and reopened in 2006 and now offers a contemporary colonial feel. There is no sense of glitzy modernity: its stately wooden panelling and staunchly Victorian rooms are immediately resonant of a bygone age and make it a tempting alternative to Colombo’s modern five star hotels. Galle Face Hotel is a member of Select Hotels & Resorts International.
Transfer to the Airport for your departure flight. This transfer would take approximately 2.5 hours.

tourName: Northern Sri Lanka holiday
generalInfo:
Travel north to experience a very different Sri Lanka with its vast lagoons full of migrant waders, donkeys and baobabs, Tamil script and Hindi songstresses, bicycles and Brahman cows. Since the declaration of peace on the island in 2009, the north and east of the country have opened up and developed, but not too much – yet. So now is the time to visit on your very own tailor-made holiday. Our suggested itinerary takes in Mannar Island, Jaffna, the east coast around Trincomalee and the Cultural Triangle.

The flat lands of the north-western coastal plain are similar to the dry zone regions of the southeast until you reach the causeway. Here everything changes with the typical scrub jungle giving way to a vast lagoon, mud flats, wading birds and… donkeys!

Mannar Island is home to thousands of migrant birds from October to March. In the area, Thantirimale is an ancient village and temple complex. Other sites of interest include Mannar and Arippu Forts, Doric House, Talaimannar port and lighthouse, and Thiruketheeswaram temple.

Venturing further north to Jaffna you immediately appreciate that you have arrived in a different land with Tamil script adorning hoardings, Hindi songs resounding in the streets and bicycles dodging meandering sacred cows. Jaffna has recovered well from the ravages of war and, while it isn’t a city of many ‘must see’ sites, the real appeal of the area is the ethereal nature of its environs and the innocence of its people.

Nallur Kandaswamy Kovil is one of the island’s most holy Hindu temples and the focus of a spectacular annual festival. Also within the city are the reconstructed library, a World Heritage Site, and the renovated fort. Further afield are the islands of Nainativu, site of important Hindu and Buddhist temples, and windswept Delft, home to wild horses of Dutch origin.

Bearing east, you arrive at Trincomalee (or Trinco), which is blessed with one of the largest and deepest natural harbours on the planet and the envy of past conquerors. Just north along the coast is Nilaveli, a relatively quiet beach area.

Fort Frederick is a 17th century Portuguese-built city bastion, magnificent views and legends surround Swami Rock, and the imposing Koneswaram Kovil is one of the most holy Hindu temples on the island. China Bay has been a naval base since time immemorial and now a museum.

The island’s Cultural Triangle accounts for six of the country’s eight World Heritage Sites. Although these sites are principally of an historic interest, they are by no means cold, stony monuments since all of the dagobas and stupas are still places of worship and veneration for locals, which makes them profoundly atmospheric and full of life.

Anuradhapura was the first capital of ancient Lanka in the 3rd century BC. Mihintale is where Buddhism was introduced to Sri Lanka and the enigmatic setting makes a visit unforgettable. The unique rock fortress of Sigiriya is a national icon, despite its origins as a usurper’s pleasure palace!

dayInfo.description: Arrive Colombo airport and transfer to Negombo on the island’s west coast close by. Night stay in Negombo.

Head north to Anuradhapura, the first capital of ancient Lanka in the 3rd century BCE, for a guided tour of the historic city of Anuradhapura, with visits to the preserved and partially restored ruins of the three principal monasteries: Mahavihara, Abhayagiriya and Jetavanarama. Two nights stay in Anuradhapura.

All-day jeep safari in Wilpattu National Park, which is the island’s largest wildlife reserve as well as one of the oldest and most important protected areas in Sri Lanka. Principally a dry lowland zone, the main topographical feature in the park is the concentration of ‘villus’. Though looking like lakes, these ‘villus’ are in fact basin-like fault depressions in the earth that fill with rain water during the monsoon season. The ‘villus’ attract a variety of animals including leopards, elephants, sloth bears, crocodiles, water buffaloes and deer. The ‘villus’ also support a variety of resident and migratory waterfowl as well as forest or scrub dwellers.

Visit the hilltop temple of Mihintale, the cradle of Buddhism in Sri Lanka, and enjoy a guided walking tour of this significant site. Continue northwest to Mannar Island, a ‘dry zone’ region and one of the least visited areas on the island. Two nights on Mannar Island.

At leisure. Suggested sightseeing trips and activities include bird watching around Mannar Island and Giant’s Tank, a visit to the ancient village and temple of Thantirimale, and a tour of Mannar Fort.
Head further north, mostly following the north-western coastline and associated lagoons, to Jaffna at the northern tip of the island. Three nights stay in Jaffna.

Tour of Jaffna city, which may include the recently renovated Jaffna fort, market and library (a UNESCO World Heritage Site); Nallur Kandaswamy Kovil (one of the most sacred Hindu temples in Sri Lanka); Keerimalai natural springs; Nilavarai bottomless well; Elephant Pass (the gateway to Jaffna with army memorials commemorating one of the most infamous battle sites of the civil war); The Salterns; Casuarina Beach; Point Pedro (northernmost tip of the island with corals and sand dunes).

Local ferry trip out to Nainativu Island of the Jaffna archipelago, home to Nagadeepa Purana Rajamaha Viharaya, one of the sites the Buddha is believed to have visited and an important pilgrimage for Buddhists.

Board the train at Jaffna railway station - SUBJECT TO AVAILABILITY - for your journey back south to Anuradhapura before driving east to Nilaveli on the island’s quieter east coast just north of Trincomalee. Three nights on Nilaveli beach.

At leisure. Suggested sightseeing trips and activities (NOT INCLUDED IN PRICE) include a guided tour of Trincomalee (incl. Fort Frederick and Koneswaram Kovil), a visit to the naval base at China Bay, a boat trip to Pigeon Island for snorkelling, whale-watching boat safari, visits to Kanniyai Hot Springs and Velgam Vihara.

Head southeast to Minneriya for an afternoon jeep safari in Minneriya National Park, which forms an ‘elephant corridor’ for the vast herds roaming the eastern region of the country from Trincomalee through to Wasgamuwa, Maduru Oya and Gal Oya National Parks further south. The park is home to a variety of animals such as elephants, leopards, toque macaques, purple faced langurs, sloth bears, sambar and spotted deer, and about 160 bird species. Two nights stay near Dambulla.

Drive to Sigiriya for an early morning ascent of the rock fortress of Sigiriya to view the surrounding countryside at dawn – a very special experience indeed. Guided tour of Sigiriya's rock palace and ornamental gardens before returning to the hotel and at leisure for the rest of the day.
Transfer to the airport for your flight home.

tourName: Northern Sri Lanka tour, tailor made
generalInfo:
This journey takes you on a complete exploration of Sri Lanka, from the tranquil beaches of the west and east coasts to the rich cultural and historical heart of the north and the Cultural Triangle. You’ll begin in Colombo and Chilaw, easing into island life before heading north to Kalpitiya, where you can enjoy dolphin-spotting boat trips, snorkel or dive on Sri Lanka’s largest coral reef, try kite surfing, or simply relax by the pool.

From Kalpitiya, continue to Jaffna to discover Tamil culture, colonial forts, Hindu temples, and unique local markets, with excursions to the windswept islands of Delft - home to wild horses - and sacred Nagadeepa. Trincomalee on the northeast coast offers golden beaches, hot springs, and the dramatic cliffside Koneswaram Temple, with optional trips to Pigeon Island for relaxed snorkelling.

In the Cultural Triangle, you’ll explore lesser-known historical sites, including the giant Buddha statues at Reswehara and Avukana, set against serene forest and river landscapes. On your way back to the west coast, pause at the ancient forest monastery at Ritigala before arriving in Negombo to enjoy a final evening by the seaside.
Throughout the trip, you’ll experience Sri Lanka’s incredible wildlife, vibrant culture, rich history, and welcoming hospitality, all while enjoying a mix of relaxation and adventure tailored to your pace.

dayInfo.description: Welcome to Sri Lanka - We’ll be ready to welcome you on arrival in Colombo, where you’ll meet your chauffeur guide who will be with you throughout your journey in Sri Lanka. From the airport, it’s a gentle 45-minute drive along the coast to the laid-back town of Chilaw. Here, you can freshen up, unwind, and ease into the rhythm of island life with your first overnight stay.

Enjoy seaside life in Kalpitiya - This morning, continue your journey with a 1.5-hour drive north to Kalpitiya, a stunning peninsula framed by the Indian Ocean on one side and a vast lagoon on the other. After checking into your hotel, the day is yours to spend as you wish. You might head out by boat to spot dolphins (and, if you’re lucky, a passing whale), explore Sri Lanka’s largest coral reef by snorkel or scuba, try your hand at kite surfing, or simply unwind by the pool. You’ll be based here for the next two nights.

Wilpattu National Park - Set off early this morning with a packed breakfast from your hotel for a full-day adventure in Wilpattu National Park. Your journey begins with a boat ride across the lagoon, before switching to an open-top jeep for your game drive. Wilpattu is home to an extraordinary variety of wildlife, from deer and elephants to countless bird species, and it’s also one of the very best places in Sri Lanka to spot elusive leopards.

Drive to Jaffna - From Kalpitiya, it’s around a five-hour drive to Jaffna, the cultural heart of northern Sri Lanka. Once largely off-limits during the civil war, Jaffna has reopened as a fascinating place to explore, rich with Tamil heritage, colourful temples, colonial forts, and a very different pace of life to the south. Tourism is still in its early days here, so you may well find yourself exploring with few other visitors around. We recommend staying at the characterful Fox Resorts Jaffna, a wonderful base for your time in the city.

Delft Island & Nagadeepa - Today, set out on a daytrip to explore the islands off Jaffna’s coast. Begin with a ferry ride to Delft, a windswept island where wild horses still roam, descendants of those left behind by the Dutch, and where the ruins of an old fort stand as a reminder of its history. From here, continue by ferry to the sacred island of Nagadeepa before returning to your hotel for the evening.

Day out in Jaffna - Spend today discovering Jaffna itself, a city shaped by centuries of history and culture. Wander through the impressive Jaffna Fort, originally built by the Portuguese and later expanded by the Dutch, visit striking European-era churches, and explore vibrant Hindu temples that remain at the heart of local life.

Drive to Trincomalee - Today’s journey takes you from Jaffna to Trincomalee on Sri Lanka’s north-east coast, a drive of around four hours. After checking into your hotel, head out to explore the town, where you can visit the famous hot springs, admire the natural deep-water harbour, and climb up to Koneswaram Temple, perched dramatically on a cliff overlooking the ocean.

Trincomalee - Take today at a leisurely pace, with plenty of time to enjoy the beach and unwind by the sea. If you feel like a little adventure, you can also take a short boat trip to Pigeon Island for some gentle snorkelling in the clear waters.

Drive to Habanara - Drive about 1.5 hours to Habarana, located in the heart of Sri Lanka’s Cultural Triangle, and check into your hotel. If you’ve already explored the main sites in the north, this trip is a great opportunity to discover some of the lesser-known gems here. Equally fascinating but far less crowded, these hidden spots promise a more relaxed and authentic experience. We’ve suggested a few highlights for the next couple of days.

Day Trip to Reswehara & Avukana Budhas - Today, head out to explore some of Sri Lanka’s remarkable ancient artistry. Visit the giant Buddha statues at Reswehara and Avukana, with the latter renowned as the best-preserved ancient statue in the country. Set against lush greenery and tranquil rivers, these sites are as atmospheric as they are impressive, offering a peaceful glimpse into Sri Lanka’s rich spiritual and cultural history.

Drive to Negombo, via Ritigala - Today, you’ll drive to Negombo, a journey of just under five hours, but we suggest breaking it up with a visit to the ancient forest monastery at Ritigala. Plan to go early, as wild elephants make the area unsafe later in the day. Once in Negombo, check in to your hotel and enjoy your final evening by the seaside, soaking up the relaxed coastal atmosphere.

Fly Home - After your journey through Sri Lanka, we’ll transfer you to the airport for your return flight home. Over the past days, you’ve experienced the country’s diverse landscapes, and seen the cultural and historical richness of the north and the heart of the Cultural Triangle. You’ve seen wildlife up close, explored ancient temples and forts, and enjoyed the warmth of Sri Lanka’s people - memories to carry with you long after your trip ends.

tourName: Small group holiday to Sri Lanka
placesVisited: Dambulla, Sigiriya, Giritale Tank, Birdwatching, Polonnaruwa, Kandy, Kitulgala rainforest, Nuwara Eliya, Option to climb Adam’s Peak, Horton Plains, World’s End viewpoint, Bandarawela, Ella Gap, Wildlife drive Yala National Park or Udawalawe National Park depending on season, Ahangama, Galle, Option for whale watching
generalInfo:
This may be a small group holiday to Sri Lanka but its carefully crafted itinerary thinks big, with an eclectic mix of both cultural and natural highlights as well as some wonderful adventure activities packed into two weeks.

From the first day you are immersed in ancient heritage, one of the first stops on our tour of the island being Dambulla ancient cave complex. These are no ordinary caves either, five of them being packed with valuable religious icons. More cultural wonders located in spectacular places await, including the giant and beautifully imposing fortress at Sigiriya, and one of the country’s finest ancient kingdoms and UNESCO World Heritage Sites at Polonnaruwa.

From ancient sites to fine wildlife sights, we spend time out in the magnificent Yala National Park, where we take a game drive to search for some of its treasures, including elephants, sloth bears, wild buffalos and rare leopards. Birdlife isn’t rare, however, with over 200 species flying around the park’s forests and wetlands. There is much more birdlife to be seen on our day at Giritale Tank, ancient reservoirs that are now beacons for birdlife with everything from kingfishers to kites.

You'll also spend a few days in and around Kandy, in the heart of the country, a city that is famous for having been ruled by the Kings of Kandy since the 15th century. It has a wonderful combination of post colonial architecture here and in the surrounding hill country plantations, but also sacred sites such as the Temple of the Tooth which contains a sacred tooth belonging to the Buddha. Another important urban stop is Galle, on the south coast, where life revolves around the old fort founded in the 16th century by Portuguese colonists and now a maze of places to shop, eat, stay and enjoy the coastal ambience.

Getting out onto the hills and wilder areas of Sri Lanka is also an option on this holiday with trekking opportunities through the rainforest region of Kitulgala, and an option to go white water rafting here too when the waters are high enough. The Adam’s Peak trek here is certainly high and tough enough for those willing and able to take on this four hour ascent of this 2,243m sacred summit through the night in order to be there for sunrise. Another more accessible trek is at Horton Plains, a 2000m high plateau where we go trekking through misty forest where sambar and purple faced monkeys roam. Leading, finally to World’s End one of the country’s most stunning viewpoints.

Another added bonus for travellers on this holiday is the chance to go whale watching on their free day, if they are lucky enough to be visiting between November and April. This is peak season to see the high numbers of blue whales and other cetaceans that visit the waters off Dondra Head on the island’s southern tip.

dayInfo.description: Begin your adventure in Veyangoda, a 30 minute drive from Sri Lanka's energetic capital: Colombo. Around 6pm, say ayubowan to your tour leader and fellow travellers at our hotel, where we gather as a group for the first time to get to know each other and learn more about the adventures ahead. Your tour leader then ensures a big Sri Lankan welcome by arranging a group dinner together. Want to explore further? Secure pre-tour hotel nights through your sales representative. Accommodation: The Covanro (or similar)

We depart after breakfast for the drive (approximately 2hr 30min) among coconut palms, paddy fields and banana plantations through Kurunegala to Dambulla. Here, we visit the magnificent Cave Temple, among the most impressive sights in Sri Lanka. There are colourful, well-preserved paintings and Buddha statues inside the caves, which date to the first century BCE. After lunch, we continue to Sigiriya (Lion Rock). From our hotel, we can see the giant rock fortress rising from the plains (occasionally we may stay nearer to Dambulla due to hotel availability) Accommodation: Hotel Sigiriya (or similar)

Sigiriya is, perhaps, the standout attraction in Sri Lanka with the ruins of a fifth-century palace crowning an imposing granite peak, also known as Lion Rock. This morning, we drive to the base, where a moat surrounds impressive water gardens. We then take the route to the top, via a series of steep steps and gangways, ascending 655ft (200m) and passing an overhanging rock, under which portraits of native maidens holding flowers and temple offerings still adorn the rock wall. On the flat-topped summit are extensive remains of the King's Summer Palace. During the afternoon, there is a chance to enjoy an optional game drive in either Minneriya National Park, Kaudulla National Park or the Hurulu Eco Park to see elephants in their natural habitat (which location depends on the elephant herd movements). For those who would prefer not to join the game drive, you can relax by the hotel pool. Accommodation: Hotel Sigiriya (or similar)

This morning, we have a short drive to Girithale where our hotel overlooks the scenic Girithale Tank. The early inhabitants here solved the dual problem of heat and lack of water in this dry area by constructing large tanks to act as reservoirs and cool the warm breeze. Now they provide an important habitat for bird life, particularly from August to April. Today we hop on local bikes and enjoy a leisurely cycle through small villages and lakes. As an alternative to cycling, you can hire a tuk tuk locally for approximately 4,000 rupees and follow the group on their trail. Along the way, we should see plenty of bird life including egrets, brahmany kites, kingfishers and bulbuls. Breaking up the journey, we stop for a family-cooked lunch in a traditional village, enjoying authentic Sri Lankan dishes under a banyan tree, while also helping to support the family's small business. After, we return to our hotel in Girithale by late afternoon. Accommodation: Giritale Hotel (or similar)

After breakfast, we take a short drive to the 10th-century capital of Sri Lanka: Polonnaruwa, the ancient capital of the Sinhalese. There are many Buddhist relics and ruins here, dating from a 1,000 years ago when Sinhalese culture reached its zenith. We visit many of the temples, palaces, huge dagobas (Buddhist stupas) and remarkable Buddhist sculptures. After lunch, we head into the hills to the picturesque town of Kandy. Stopping along the way at a spice garden near Matale, where we learn about various spices and herbs growing, and there is a chance to stock up on fresh spices, massage oils and Ayurvedic medicines. This is a long but fascinating day, arriving to Kandy in the early evening. Accommodation: Earl's Regent Hotel/Hotel Suisse (selected departures)

Kandy is by a small lake and we spend two full days in and around the town. On the first day, we visit the Temple of the Tooth, which houses the most important Buddhist relic in Sri Lanka. The Tooth of Buddha was taken from the funeral pyre in 543 BCE and only found its way to Sri Lanka in the fourth century CE. Hundreds of worshippers visit the temple each day and in August the most spectacular ceremony takes place. Some of our August trips should coincide with the Kandy festival, but the exact dates, decided by priests, are not known until five months prior to the event. After our visit, we drive to a beautiful viewpoint over Kandy overlooked by a huge Buddha, and visit a gem museum where you can see the products of the traditional methods of gem extraction. Another highlight is the vast Peradeniya Botanical Garden with orchid species endemic to Sri Lanka. Your second full day in Kandy is free to explore this wonderful town or take it slow starting the day relaxing by the hotel pool. The surrounding hills are wonderful, offering fantastic views of the town below and there are many handicraft stores and antique shops in which to browse. On either evening, you have the option to attend a traditional performance of dancing and fire eating. Accommodation: Earl's Regent Hotel/Hotel Suisse (selected departures)

After a relaxed start to the day, we have a spectacular drive through the countryside on the way to Kitulgala. Here, we have the opportunity of going on a walk through the jungle or local villages followed by an optional white-water rafting excursion. The rafting is a supplement cost and requires minimum 4 people (see the Optional Excursions section of the trip notes), the activity lasts a maximum of 1.5 hours and there is a choice of gentle or wild water (grade III rapids) depending on your preference. If you do not wish to go rafting, freshen up and relax by the water until the rafters return for lunch. After, we drive to our hotel in Nuwara Eliya. Please note, it is possible to climb Adam's Peak (Sri Pada) from the full moon day of December to the full moon day of May. This is optional and you need to be confident in your fitness levels to attempt this. You would leave Nuwara Eliya around midnight on Day 8 and drive for approximately two hours to the base of the peak. From here, it is a strenuous four-hour climb to the top in time for sunrise. We then return to Nuwara Eliya to join the group for lunch on Day 9. Accommodation: Araliya Red (or similar)

This morning, we have free time to explore the beautiful town of Nuwara Eliya, a popular hill station during the British era, situated in the cool highland air. Known locally as Little England, it is dotted with British-style houses and parks and features a golf club and racecourse. Following lunch, we visit a nearby tea plantation and factory and learn about the process of tea production. Accommodation: Araliya Red (or similar)

We have an early start this morning and take a 19mi (30km) drive south to Horton Plains, a large plateau more than 6,560ft (2,000m) high, overlooked by the second and third highest peaks in Sri Lanka. The scenery is beautiful and the best way to explore is on foot. We take a three to four-hour guided walk (5.5mi/9km) through the picturesque rolling grasslands, spanning through various landscapes and elevations, where we hope to encounter monkeys along the way. We also visit World’s End, where the ground drops 3,445ft (1,050m) to the plains. For a more detailed terrain description of Horton Plains walk, please see our "Is this trip for you" section within the Trip Notes. Following this, we catch a train from the highest railway station in the country – within 90 minutes we drop from 6,198ft (1,889m) to 3,599ft (1,097m). The train travels through cloud forest into tea plantations, with breath-taking views of the lush valley below. We get off at Ella railway station and continue by road to Ella Gap where we have spectacular views of the coastal plain nearly 3,280ft (1,000m) below. Almost the entire southern part of the island is in view and (on a particularly clear day) the shimmering ocean is visible. We travel to Kataragama on the plains; this is our base for visiting the best-known national park in Sri Lanka, Yala. Accommodation: Mandara Rosen (or similar)

Today we proceed to Tissamaharama, we walk to Kalu farmhouse, where you’ll be offered tea in a coconut shell along with a local snack. We mix with real Sri Lankan life and take part in some traditional Sri Lankan games, returning to our bus in tractors used by the farmers. Later this afternoon, we take a game drive in Yala National Park, home to elephants, leopards, bears, crocodiles and wild boars. The park, which is primarily shrub jungle with several salt and freshwater lagoons, has one of the highest concentrations of leopards in the world. We explore the lesser-visited Block 5 area, which has denser vegetation than the open plains but the same chances of seeing the elusive leopards and sloth bears, all without having to compete with multiple other game vehicles. Please note, the sanctuary may be closed for four to six weeks from September to October, allowing park authorities to check the welfare of the animals. We therefore go to a nearby alternative, usually Udawalawe National Park. Accommodation: Mandara Rosen (or similar)

Today, we leave for the coast, with its beautiful palm-fringed bays. On the way you will visit the Elephant Transit Home in Udawalawe. This unique experience highlights and supports the conservation efforts in Sri Lanka for wild elephants. Located on the outskirts of Udawalawe National Park the Elephant Transit Home is rehabilitation centre for orphaned and sick elephants to receive nourishment and care until they become independent and healthy enough to be released back into the wild. From Udawalawe, we continuing on to Ahangama, arriving at our coastal hotel in the afternoon and you can relax for the rest of the day by the pool or on the beach. Accommodation: Insight Resort (or similar)

Today is free for you to relax on the beach or by the hotel pool. There are also optional activities including a boat ride through mangrove swamps to a cinnamon plantation or, from November to April, you can go whale watching off Dondra Head, one of the best places in the world for seeing blue and sperm whales. Dolphin pods often play alongside the boats. Accommodation: Insight Resort (or similar)

We drive along the coastal road to Galle, which dates to the 17th century, and is now a World Heritage site. On the way, we stop at a small folk museum inspired by the local writer Martin Wickramasinghe. The museum is a typical house from the Koggala region and is set among beautiful gardens. Later, we continue along the expressway to Colombo, reaching our hotel in the late afternoon. Departures from June 2026 onwards: We return to Insight Resort tonight and transfer (2hr 30min-3hr) straight to Colombo airport tomorrow. Accommodation: Ramada by Wyndham Colombo (or similar)

You've summited the mighty Sigiriya, been on safari in Yala National Park and cycled through rural Sri Lanka, but the adventure ends today and you begin your return journey home. Alternatively, if you're craving a little R&R, speak to your sales representative about a post-trip adventure in the Maldives or more time relaxing on the golden sands of Sri Lanka.

Guided Visits and Excursions:

dayInfo.description: NEGOMBO: Arrive into Colombo International Airport and head straight to The Wallawwa to recuperate amidst startlingly peaceful surroundings. Set in expansive tropical grounds with a big kitchen garden, this former manor house offers family-orientated room options, varied cuisine, discreet service and a decadent spa for post- and pre-flight pampering. Be on the beach in 30 minutes, play croquet in the garden or take a private guided tour by boat or kayak through the pretty bird-filled Muthurajawela Wetlands. Colombo’s restaurants, shops and sights are a mere 30- to 40-minutes’ drive away. Travel time Colombo Airport to The Wallawwa: 20 minutes. Stay 1 night at The Wallawwa.

KANDY: Travel into the hills to Taylors Hill, east of Kandy. This former planter’s abode dates back over a century and is home to just five bedrooms including one family suite. The house is well equipped for families, as it has a TV Room, a play area, a billiards room and plenty of board games. Outside, there’s a swimming pool, extensive gardens, a badminton/volleyball net, bicycles and a guide for taking you on walking, cycling and nature trails. Other local highlights include visiting Loolecondera, Sri Lanka’s oldest tea estate, and perhaps picnicking in Field No. 7, home to the oldest tea bushes. Around a 60-90-minute drive away is Kandy, a university town home to the Temple of the Tooth – Sri Lanka’s most sacred shrine – the Botanical Gardens and a tea museum. Travel time Negombo to (Deltota) Kandy: 4 hours. Stay 2 nights at Taylors Hill.

YALA NATIONAL PARK: Descend the hills into the low-lying southeastern plains and to the edge of Yala National Park to Noel Rodrigo’s Leopard Safaris, stopping off enroute at Buduruwagala – a series of seven well-preserved Buddhist figures carved into sheer rock. Yala National Park is home to a dense population of leopards, as well as elephants and sloth bears. Camping at the edge of the park is a magical once-in-a-lifetime experience that all the family will enjoy; Noel Rodrigo’s Leopard Safaris has family tents (including an air conditioned Luxury Lodge Family Tent due to open in the summer of 2018), and there are wildlife art classes and animal identification games for the kids. Travel time (Deltota) Kandy to Yala National Park: 5 hours. Stay 2 nights at Noel Rodrigo’s Leopard Safaris.

GALLE**: Travel west along the picturesque cove-sprinkled southern coastline to Galle, famed for pretty beaches, a 17th century Dutch fort and a cosmopolitan vibe. Here you’ll stay at Why House, an idyllic country-style boutique hotel with big garden and expansive swimming pool. The hotel has an excellent restaurant, and there are many others in the local area. Aside from sculpting sandcastles on one of the region’s pretty beaches, family activities include guided bicycle rides, boat trips, gentle river kayaking, seasonal whale and dolphin watching and surfing. Travel time Yala National Park to Galle: 4 hours. Stay 4 nights at Why House. **Alternative option: TANGALLE: Travel west to Tangalle, and continue a further seven-kilometres to reach The Last House, located on a gorgeous two kilometre bay to the west of Tangalle, a busy fishing town. With barely another soul to be seen on the beach here, this is a great alternative destination for relaxing in tranquility beside the sea. The hotel has body boards and surf boards that can be used, and also offers deep sea fishing trips. Activities in the local area include hikes up to the top of Mulkirigala Rock, an ancient Buddhist temple site. From Tangalle, it’s also possible to day trip to Udawalawe National Park (elephants), Bundala National Park and the Kalametiya Sanctuary, famed for migratory birds (including flamingoes). Travel time Yala National Park to Tangalle: 2 hours 15 minutes/Tangalle to the airport: 4 hours. Stay 4 nights at The Last House.
DEPART SRI LANKA: Travel time Galle to Colombo Airport: 2.5 hours

tourName: Sri Lanka 13 day tour
generalInfo:

Explore the majestic mountains of Ella, where scenic hikes await, and embrace the serene beauty of southern beaches. With knowledgeable local guides leading the way, you'll immerse yourself in Sri Lanka's vibrant culture through a variety of included activities.

Whether you're white-water rafting through thrilling rapids, embarking on a safari to encounter the country's wildlife, or riding the waves on a surfing adventure, there's never a dull moment on this journey. Indulge in delicious cuisine and experience the warm hospitality of one of the world's friendliest nations.

Against the backdrop of breathtaking natural beauty, your Sri Lanka adventure promises to create memories that will last a lifetime. Get ready for an unforgettable journey filled with exploration, excitement, and discovery.

dayInfo.description: Colombo: Your adventure in Sri Lanka begins with a warm welcome from your Adventure Leader at the Colombo hostel. After dropping off your luggage, gather for a pre-departure briefing to go over the itinerary and meet your fellow travelers. Once you're acquainted, embark on an evening walking tour around the old town of Colombo. Explore the vibrant streets and immerse yourself in the rich history and culture of the city. From colonial architecture to bustling markets, Colombo offers a fascinating glimpse into Sri Lanka's past and present. Get ready to start your journey with an exploration of this dynamic capital city.

Negombo & Dambulla: Start your day bright and early with a journey to Negombo to explore the renowned fish market, fondly called 'Lellama' by locals. Located along the picturesque Negombo beach, this bustling market offers an authentic glimpse into the local fishing industry. Immerse yourself in the vibrant atmosphere as you interact with fishermen and witness the lively fish auction, where fresh catches are bought and sold. Next, you'll head to the Sputnik Centre for a half-day of volunteer activities, gaining a firsthand look at Sri Lanka’s incredible efforts to support and empower its youth. For over 20 years, Sputnik has provided language courses, community programs, and even table tennis lessons—all driven by dedicated volunteers. It’s a truly uplifting experience that will leave you feeling inspired and connected. After experiencing the hustle and bustle of the fish market and the exciting visit to the Sputnik Center, continue your journey to Dambulla. Here, you'll visit the awe-inspiring Dambulla Cave Temple complex, a UNESCO World Heritage site. Explore the series of caves that were transformed into temples nearly 2,000 years ago, adorned with intricate statues and vibrant murals depicting Buddhist deities and legends. After your exploration, retreat to your hostel in Dambulla for a relaxing evening.

Sigiriya: After a hearty breakfast, embark on a journey northeast to visit another of Sri Lanka's iconic UNESCO World Heritage sites – the ancient city of Sigiriya. Here, you'll ascend the ancient rock fortress, famously known as Sigiriya Rock, which was once the site of a capital built by King Kashyapa I during his reign from 477 to 495. As you climb to the top, marvel at the ruins of the ancient city and enjoy breathtaking views of the surrounding lowlands. In the afternoon, you have the option to explore Sigiriya at your own pace or join an optional excursion to the old city of Polonnaruwa – yet another magnificent UNESCO World Heritage site. If you choose to visit Polonnaruwa, you'll have the opportunity to explore the ruins of this medieval capital city by bicycle, immersing yourself in its rich history and admiring its impressive monuments, statues, royal palaces, temples, and pagodas. After an adventurous day of exploration, return to your guesthouse in Dambulla for a relaxing evening. Unwind with a glass of arrack, a traditional Sri Lankan spirit distilled from the sap of coconut flowers, and reflect on the day's adventures.

Knuckles Mountain Range: After breakfast, we'll venture southward to the Knuckles Mountain Range, renowned for its distinctive recumbent folds and peaks resembling the knuckles of a clenched fist. Our hike along the picturesque Manigala Trail will offer breathtaking views of the surrounding cloud forest, allowing us to immerse ourselves in the rich diversity of flora and fauna found in this region. We'll enjoy a packed lunch amidst these stunning surroundings, providing the perfect opportunity to soak in the natural beauty of the area. In the late afternoon, we'll bid farewell to the mountains and make our way to Kandy, the picturesque hill capital and Sri Lanka's second-largest city. Here, you'll have the remainder of the day to explore the city's vibrant blend of ancient and modern architecture. From historic temples to bustling markets, Kandy offers a wealth of attractions to discover. As evening falls, we'll gather for a visit to a local pub, where you can unwind and reflect on the day's adventures while enjoying the lively atmosphere of this charming city.

Kandy: After breakfast, we'll commence the day with a visit to one of Sri Lanka's most iconic landmarks: the Temple of the Tooth. Once the royal palace of Sri Lankan kings, it now serves as a sacred temple housing the revered tooth relic of Lord Buddha. This spiritual site offers a glimpse into the country's rich religious heritage and provides a serene setting for reflection and contemplation. In the afternoon, you have the option to further explore Kandy at your leisure or join us for a visit to the Royal Botanical Gardens of Peradeniya. Located approximately 5.5 kilometers west of Kandy, these expansive gardens offer a tranquil retreat from the city's hustle and bustle. Be sure to admire the renowned collection of orchids and marvel at the diverse array of plant species on display. In the late afternoon, we’ll make our way to Kitulgala for an exhilarating white-water rafting adventure through the lush rainforest. After the adrenaline rush, unwind and soak in the serene jungle atmosphere for a peaceful night’s stay.

Ella: After an early breakfast, head to Nanu Oya railway station and board the iconic train to Ella. This breathtaking journey winds through rolling tea plantations, misty forests, and charming hilltop villages—widely hailed as one of the world's most scenic train rides! Upon arrival, take a short stroll to your hostel, drop off your bags, and soak up Ella’s relaxed atmosphere. Later, lace up your hiking shoes for a scenic trek to Little Adam’s Peak. This gentle climb through lush tea fields rewards you with stunning panoramic views of Ella’s picturesque hill country—the perfect way to wrap up the day!

Ella: Kick off your day with a packed breakfast before embarking on an unforgettable hike along the 15th and 16th stages of the Pekoe Trail. Your adventure begins at the serene Makulella Buddhist Temple, perched above the Ambagaswatte Valley. Stage 15 takes you through eucalyptus forests, lush tea fields, and jungle paths, leading up to the summit of Ella Rock. Here, soak in breathtaking views of Ella Gap and Little Adam’s Peak before the trail winds back into town. Stage 16 continues the journey, guiding you through the enchanting Ella Forest Reserve, past the iconic Nine Arches Bridge, and along scenic village roads. Along the way, you’ll pass stunning tea estates like Newburgh and Demodara, finishing at the renowned Demodara Railway Loop. As evening falls, unwind and explore Ella at your own pace—whether it’s browsing quirky shops, relaxing in cosy pubs, or indulging in delicious local cuisine, this charming town has plenty to offer.

Ella: Start your day with a hands-on Sri Lankan cooking class, where you’ll master the art of blending spices and creating iconic local dishes. Get ready to chop, stir, and season your way to a mouthwatering feast—your taste buds will thank you! The afternoon is yours to explore Ella at your own pace. Whether you opt for a relaxing yoga session, an adrenaline rush on the Flying Ravana Zipline, or a leisurely stroll through this charming hill town, the choice is yours.

Udawalawe: After breakfast, journey to Udawalawe, a region renowned for its breathtaking wildlife. Along the way, stop at the ancient Buduruwagala Temple, a hidden gem nestled in a tranquil forest. Admire the seven striking rock-carved statues, including a towering standing Buddha flanked by bodhisattvas and deities, dating back to the 10th century. The serene atmosphere makes this spiritual site even more enchanting. Later, arrive at your campsite on the edge of Udawalawe National Park. As you settle in, keep an eye out for wild elephants, crocodiles, spotted deer, and a dazzling array of birdlife in this incredible natural sanctuary.

Handunugoda & Unawatuna: After breakfast, we'll embark on a journey to explore Sri Lanka's renowned tea production. Our destination is the Handunugoda Tea Estate, located about 2 hours southwest of our current location. Here, you'll have the opportunity to learn about the fascinating tea-making process, from the cultivation of tea leaves in the fields to the art of tea production in the factory. Dive into the rich history of tea at the estate's museum and witness firsthand how tea leaves are transformed into the beverage enjoyed by millions worldwide. Cap off the experience with a refreshing cup of freshly brewed tea. Following our tea plantation visit, we'll continue our journey along the picturesque southern coastline, reaching the coastal town of Unawatuna in about 30 minutes. Unawatuna is renowned for its pristine beaches and vibrant surf culture, making it an ideal destination for relaxation and exploration. Spend the evening soaking up the laid-back atmosphere of this seaside town, perhaps indulging in some beach activities or sampling local cuisine, before retiring to our hostel for the night.

Unawatuna: Today is all about embracing the sun, sand, and sea as we enjoy a leisurely day at the beach. Spend the morning soaking up the sun's rays and lounging on the golden sands of Unawatuna Beach. It's the perfect opportunity to unwind, relax, and recharge amidst the serene coastal surroundings. In the afternoon, get ready for an exhilarating surfing lesson! Sri Lanka is renowned for its excellent surfing spots, and Unawatuna offers the ideal setting for beginners and experienced surfers alike. Our expert instructors will provide guidance and support as you learn to ride the waves, making it a memorable experience for everyone. (Please note that surfing conditions may vary, and if deemed unsuitable, alternative activities will be arranged or a refund provided.) After your surfing adventure, unleash your creativity with a mask painting session. Dive into the rich artistic tradition of Sri Lanka by crafting your own traditional mask. These intricately designed masks are believed to possess healing and protective powers, making them both meaningful and decorative pieces of art. Let your imagination run wild as you paint and decorate your mask, creating a unique souvenir to cherish. Whether you're catching waves or channeling your artistic side, today promises to be a fun-filled and memorable day by the beach in Unawatuna.

Galle: Today begins with an exciting tuk-tuk ride to Galle, one of Sri Lanka's bustling southern cities. Galle is renowned for its rich history and is home to the iconic Galle Fort City, a UNESCO World Heritage site. Built in the 16th century by the Portuguese, the fort is a testament to the blending of architectural styles and South Asian traditions. As you explore Galle Fort City on foot, you'll be mesmerized by its well-preserved ramparts, which feature a lighthouse, clock tower, churches, houses, and other historic buildings. Many of these structures have been repurposed into chic restaurants, boutique shops, and guesthouses, adding to the fort's charm while retaining its authenticity. After a fascinating exploration of Galle Fort City, you'll have the opportunity to witness the breathtaking sunset from the fort's ramparts. This serene moment offers a perfect opportunity to reflect on the day's adventures and soak in the beauty of the surroundings before returning to Unawatuna. Get ready for a day filled with history, culture, and unforgettable experiences as you delve into the captivating ambiance of Galle Fort City and witness the stunning sunset over the ramparts.

Colombo: Today marks the final day of your Sri Lanka group tour package! We will start our journey back to Sri Lanka’s capital city, Colombo, where you will bid farewell to your new friends and prepare to head home! On our way, we will stop by a temple where you will meet a Buddhist priest and take part in a pooja (blessing ritual) prior to the end of your journey.

tourName: Sri Lanka 14 day small group tour
generalInfo:
The 14-day small group holiday has been customized to include both touristy activities and off the beaten track locations.

During your holiday you will visit Negombo, Kandy, Sigiriya, Trincomalee, Anuradhapura and Colombo.

The holiday is designed by Rajiv who has been traveling with tourist for over 20 years. The holiday is designed to include a minimum of two nights at each location, and this gives you time to relax and enjoy your holiday.

One key element which must be considered when visiting Sri Lanka is the tropical weather. This holiday has been designed to give you as much sunshine as possible during your stay in Sri Lanka.

On your arrival in Sri Lanka, you will be met by your local team Gillian and Rajiv. Gillian and Rajiv are passionate about travel, and this makes them the best team to travel with during your holiday.

Gillian an ex-hotelier and banker married to Rajiv will work together to make sure you have an amazing holiday in Sri Lanka with memories for a lifetime.

We have designed this holiday for you from start to end with one key element in mind which is peace of mind.

From the time you confirm your holiday with us we get to work. On your arrival in our little island paradise, we meet you personally and till you leave Sri Lanka you will be pampered with the best of Sri Lankan hospitality.

You will enjoy local food and culture from the start. Gillian and Rajiv are foodies and enjoy entertaining. We have planned many local surprises during your holiday with us.

You will enjoy guided tours of the Sigiriya, Polonnaruwa and Dambulla Cave Temple which are ancient cultural sites.

Sri Lanka has an abundance of wildlife and during your holiday two separate wildlife safaris are planned. Full day safari at the biggest national park in Sri Lanka called Wilpattu National Park. and another safari which includes one of nature's greatest gathering called the "The Elephant Gathering" which takes place each year in Sri Lanka.

Sri Lanka is blessed with beautiful coastline. Your holiday includes a total of five nights at the beach. You will start your holiday at the beach in the fishing village of Negombo. Your second beach stay will be in Trincomalee on the east coast of Sri Lanka.

Kandy which was the last Kingdom in Sri Lanka before the British took full control of the Island. Here you will stay two nights and visit the Temple of the Tooth Relic and also enjoy a relaxed walk at the Royal Botanical Gardens.

All the hotels are locally owned and managed; they are centrally located which gives you the opportunity to explore on your own. Your stay at these hotels' benefits both the locals and Sri Lanka as a country.

All your meals are included in this holiday. Most of our dinners and breakfasts will be at the hotels. Lunch will be at local restaurants and cafes.

You will travel in luxury and comfort in a fully airconditioned vehicle. These vehicles are fully insured and driven by experienced drivers.

WELLCOME TO SRI LANKA MACHANG!

dayInfo.description: SIGIRIYA: Make your way straight up into Sri Lanka’s historic Cultural Triangle, so-called for the collection of World Heritage Sites and significant attractions located up here. You’ll stay at Water Garden – Sigiriya, one of the region’s newest boutique hotels, which is within eye-sight of one of the island’s most photographed attractions, Sigiriya. This former rock-top fortress dates back to the seventh century, and is home to superb examples of ancient hydro engineering as well as well-preserved frescoes. Hike up to the summit for incredible views. The hotel’s rooms are all freestanding villas, and offer plenty of space. Other notable local sights include Dambulla’s Cave Temples while further afield you could try your luck seeking out elephants in Minneriya National Park, or visit Polonnaruwa or Anuradhapura, two former ancient capitals, and both World Heritage Sites. Travel time Colombo Airport to Water Garden: 4 hours. Stay 3 nights at Water Garden - Sigiriya.

KANDY: Travel south to Kandy, a university town home to the Temple of the Tooth – Sri Lanka’s most sacred shrine – the Botanical Gardens, the British Garrison Cemetery and a tea museum. Around a 60- to 90-minute drive south west of Kandy is Taylors Hill, a spectacularly sited boutique hotel set in acres of landscaped gardens. With just five bedrooms, this century old former planter’s residence is redolent of the past and comes with a TV room, a snooker room, extensive gardens and plenty of outdoor activities such as tennis, badminton, croquet and swimming. There are bicycles for exploring the locality and a dedicated nature guide. Nearby is Sri Lanka’s very first tea plantation, the historic Loolecondera Estate, former home of Ceylon Tea legend James Taylor; the hotel’s naturalist will take you on a tour and pack you a picnic to enjoy in Field No. 7, home to Sri Lanka’s oldest tea bushes. Alternatively, couples might like to stay at The Kandy House, a striking manor house 20- to 30-minutes from Kandy (accepts the over 12’s only). Travel time Sigiriya to Kandy: 2 hours 45 minutes Stay. 2 nights at Taylors Hill or The Kandy House.

KANDAPOLA (NUWARA ELIYA) OR DEMODERA (ELLA): From Kandy, travel into the Hill Country. This region is a stunning natural tapestry of verdant mountains carpeted in neatly arranged tea estates, which date back to the British colonial era. Although there are many scenic drives, taking the Main Line train option offers a unique perspective to enjoy this destination. Here you have two options and both of these hotels, operated by Teardrop Hotels, are similar in that they are extensively refurbished former tea estate manager’s bungalows with four or five rooms apiece, butlers, superb food, contemporary comforts and gardens with swimming pools. The bungalows are surrounded by tea fields and attractions include tea factory visits, tea estate walks, waterfall visits and scenic picnics. Goatfell is located to the north west of Nuwara Eliya, a former British-era Hill Station, while Nine Skies is located in Demodera, near Ella, a little further south. Travel time Kandy to Kandapola/Demodera: 3 hours/4 hours. Stay 2 nights at either Nine Skies/Goatfell.

TANGALLE: Travel south to Tangalle, on the south coast, and continue a further seven-kilometres to The Last House, which is located on a gorgeous two kilometre curve of bay to the west of Tangalle, a busy fishing town. With barely another soul to be seen on the beach here, this is a great alternative destination for relaxing in tranquility beside the sea. The villa was built by legendary architect Geoffrey Bawa, and was his last private commission before he died, which makes the property extra special. The hotel has body boards and surf boards that can be used, and also offers deep sea fishing trips. You can also climb to the top of Mulkirigala Rock, an ancient Buddhist temple. From here, it’s also possible to day trip to Udawalawe National Park (elephants), Bundala National Park for migratory and resident birds, and the Kalametiya Sanctuary. Travel time Kandapola/Demodera to Tangalle: 5.5 hours/3.5 hours. Stay 3 nights at The Last House.

GALLE: Continue west to Galle, famed for pretty beaches, a 17th century Dutch fort and a cosmopolitan vibe. Stay right in the heart of Galle Fort, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, at Fort Bazaar, an 18-room boutique hotel with pool and fabulous wining and dining venues. From here you can wander the fort’s famed cobbled streets at will or discover hidden crevices with local guides. Beaches are just a 15-minute drive away, and activities in the local area include inland bicycle rides through rice fields, diving, surfing and fishing. Back at the hotel, enjoy spa treatments or a Sri Lankan cookery class. Travel time Tangalle to Galle: 1.5 hours. Stay 2 nights at The Fort Bazaar.

COLOMBO: Head to Sri Lanka’s up-and-coming capital for your last night, staying in Maniumpathy, a fabulous eight-bedroom heritage hotel. The city offers good souvenir shopping (Barefoot, Odel and Paradise Road are favourites), great restaurants (we love Monsoon), art galleries (Saskia Fernando Gallery is nearby) and historical sites such as the National Museum and Number 11, Geoffrey Bawa’s fascinating former home. You can also enjoy hosted walks around Colombo. Maniumpathy dates back to 1906 and was commissioned by a doctor from Jaffna whose descendants lived in the house until recently. Sister hotel to The Kandy House, this peaceful boutique hotel has been renovated for the modern age whilst preserving its sense of history. Travel time Galle to Colombo: 2 hours. Stay 2 nights at Maniumpathy.
DEPART SRI LANKA: Travel time Colombo to Colombo Airport: 45 minutes

placesVisited: Colombo, Railways journeys, Jaffna, Anuradhapura, Dambulla cave (Rock) temple, Polonnaruwa, Safari in Minneriya National Park, Sigiriya Rock Fortress, Trincomalee, Pasikudah, Kandy, Nuwara Eliya, Horton Plains National Park, Yala National Park, Galle
generalInfo:
Welcome to our unique 21-day holiday in amazing Sri Lanka.

This three-week Sri Lanka holiday is tailor-made for you by your local guides Rajiv who has been working with tourists for the past 20 years and has an immense knowledge of his 'teardrop' island he calls home together with his wife Gillian. Rajiv has included both touristy activities and off the beaten track locations.

On your arrival in Sri Lanka, you will be met by your local team Gillian and Rajiv. We are both passionate about travel and local food and this makes us the best local team to travel with during your holiday.

We have designed this holiday for you from start to end with one key element in mind which is peace of mind.

During your holiday you will visit Negombo, Trincomalee and Pasikudah Beaches, Anuradhapura, Polonnaruwa, Sigiriya, Jaffna, Kandy, Nuwara Eliya, Yala, Galle and Colombo.

One key element which must be considered when visiting Sri Lanka on holiday is the tropical weather. We have planned this holiday so that you will enjoy bright sunshine and blue skies especially when at the beach.

Sri Lanka a paradise that we proudly call the Pearl of the Indian Ocean is surrounded by golden sandy beaches, majestic rainforest-covered mountains, cascading waterfalls, UNESCO heritage sites, sacred rock temples, tea plantations, and ancient royal cities.

Sri Lanka offers something for everyone. Our 21-day standard itinerary gives you the opportunity to encounter herds of wild elephants, the elusive leopards, and endangered sloth bears of Sri Lanka including hundreds of bird species in the company of a local guide or ranger. cultural, natural, and historic attractions are unsurpassed in this authentic 21-day Amazing Sri Lanka Holiday including the amazing local food.

All hotels are locally owned and managed and you will be transported in the comfort of your own privet chauffeur-driven vehicle, where you sit back and enjoy a bespoke itinerary that is as unique and individual as you. All our vehicles are fully insured and driven by experienced chauffeurs.

Anyone can visit Sri Lanka, but not everyone gets the chance to chat over dinner or travel together with a local host, take a safari at dawn with a knowledgeable ranger, and get the best seats on one of the most scenic railway journeys in the world. You need a local specialist to provide you with insider information, make arrangements using local contacts, and advise on the best times of year to visit different areas.

Our family-operated company has been doing just that since 2004 and 50% of our business comes from personal referrals and repeat business. We strongly believe in responsible and sustainable tourism and are proud of the fact that 90% of your tour fee stays in Sri Lanka...

Sri Lanka is ready for you, so why not contact us today and allow us to design a unique, tailor-made Sri Lanka holiday to suit your specific interests and ideas? We look forward to hearing from you soon!

WELLCOME TO SRI LANKA MACHANG!

tourName: Sri Lanka adventure holiday
placesVisited: Negombo, Anuradhapura, Polonnaruwa, Dambulla, Kandy, Bandarawela, Udeweriya, Mirissa, Galle, Colombo
generalInfo:
This adventure holiday takes you to the Indian Ocean island of Sri Lanka, a country with a centuries’ old history and culture, which punches well above its weight when it comes to both natural and man-made beauty.

Over the space of two weeks you’ll take in the country’s top highlights. History buffs will be delighted by the beautifully-preserved Polonnaruwa ruins, the Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic, seaside Galle Fort and the dramatic Sigiriya Rock Fortress, as well as the old colonial mansions that dot the country’s tea plantations.

Nature lovers are well catered for too. As well as trekking through the highlands of Hill Country and staying in a local guesthouse, you’ll spend time at the beachside retreat of Mirissa, where there’s ample time for swimming in the clear waters and biking around the surrounding countryside.

dayInfo.title: Negombo.
dayInfo.description: Ayubowan! Welcome to Sri Lanka. Your adventure begins in the town of Negombo, close to the international airport, with a welcome meeting at 5.30 pm. If you arrive early, you can get into the spirit of seaside Sri Lanka by observing the local fishing craft and feasting on fresh seafood. The beautiful surrounding countryside is best explored on a bicycle, which you can rent with help from the hotel reception.

dayInfo.title: Anuradhapura.
dayInfo.description: Visit the Negombo Fish Markets this morning to see the hustle and bustle of daily trade, then hop in your private vehicle to ancient Anuradhapura – the centre of Theravada Buddhism for many centuries and a major Buddhist pilgrimage site, with ruins of ancient Buddhist temples, including Anuradhapura Maha Viharaya and the Jaya Sri Maha Bodhi, which is the oldest living planted tree in the world! Along the way, stop in the small town of Chilaw and maybe grab some local lunch. When you arrive, settle in and enjoy a free afternoon and evening. Those keen on history and archaeology might like to visit Mihintale – the sacred birthplace of Sri Lankan Buddhism.

dayInfo.title: Anuradhapura.
dayInfo.description: Take a guided bicycle tour of the city today. Among the ruins, you'll see the sacred old Bo Tree – a spiritual reminder of the beginnings of Buddhism in Sri Lanka, and the inspiration for Anuradhapura's great buildings. The ruins themselves are spread over quite an area, some in the woodlands and others with columns and ponds. After your cycle tour, you have a free afternoon. Maybe grab some delicious local cuisine – your leader will know the best spots.

dayInfo.title: Polonnaruwa.
dayInfo.description: Travel to one of the oldest kingdoms in Sri Lanka, Polonnaruwa by public bus and private vehicle today. A UNESCO World Heritage site, this was the capital of the Indian Chola Dynasty after Anuradhapura was conquered in the late 10th century. These ruins are close together and generally in much better repair than those you’ve seen so far. When the heat of the day has eased, you'll visit more palaces, temples and stupas, including the massive stone Buddhas. You'll also visit the museum, which has scale models of many of the buildings, to show how they would have existed in their time.

dayInfo.title: Dambulla.
dayInfo.description: Depart Polonnaruwa this morning and travel to Dambulla. When you arrive, you’ll head out to explore the amazing Dambulla Cave Temples, which sit on high on a stone cliff face with lots of steps. Some 150 Buddha images adorn the five caves, with fascinating frescoes and paintings on the walls and roofs. In the afternoon, you may like to relax by the hotel pool or take an optional wildlife 4WD safari to Minneriya, Kaudulla or Eco National Park where you might see some wild elephants!

dayInfo.title: Sigiriya – Kandy.
dayInfo.description: Early this morning, before the heat is too intense, you’ll head to Sigiriya. This ruined fortress is one of Sri Lanka's premier sights and a UNESCO World Heritage site. Those who make it to the top are rewarded with astounding views. Make sure you’re wearing sturdy footwear, as this is a very steep climb with some uneven slopes. Those unable to climb to the top can explore the gardens at the base of the rock and still get some fantastic shots of the fortress from below. Return to the hotel to freshen up before heading to Kandy. On the way, there's the option of stopping at one of the region's wonderful spice gardens for lunch and to learn about the medicinal properties of ingredients used in cooking and treatments. Carry on to Kandy, where you’ll visit the Dalada Maligawa (aka Temple of the Tooth) – Sri Lanka's most important Buddhist site. Time permitting, you'll also have the option of visiting the National Museum or the world-class Botanical Gardens.

dayInfo.title: Kandy.
dayInfo.description: Today, you’ll visit a nearby tea factory for a guided tour to learn about the production of Sri Lanka's best-known beverage. Of course, you’ll also sample some of the delicious varieties of locally produced tea while you're here. Later, head back to your hotel in Kandy, located far from the noise of the city. This spot is a great place to unwind, with lovely views over the town.

dayInfo.title: Bandarawela.
dayInfo.description: Start your day with a scenic train journey to Bandarawela, passing through tea plantations and winding along mountains into the highlands. When you arrive, you’ll visit a local home for a cooking demonstration to learn some secrets of traditional Sri Lankan cuisine. After, sit down to enjoy the delicious meal for dinner with your hosts and get to know each other. Tonight, you’re free to relax or explore at your own pace.

dayInfo.title: Haputale/ Bandarawela.
dayInfo.description: Today, you’ll drive to Haputale – at 1431 m above sea level, this area has a rich biodiversity, dense with various flora and fauna. Surrounded by hills and covered with cloud forests and tea plantations, it’s the perfect starting point for your Pekoe trail hike today. This section of the Pekoe trail hike takes you to see Hindu Kovils, through tea plantations and small Tamil villages. For lunch, head to a local Tamil tea worker’s house and enjoy a home-cooked meal with your host. Carry on and soak up the gorgeous scenery! Tonight, you’ll head back to Bandarawela.

dayInfo.title: Udawalawe Jungle Camp.
dayInfo.description: Embrace an early start this morning and take the train to Idalgashinna. When you arrive, head out on a hike to explore the beautiful surroundings of Sri Lanka's Hill Country. Enjoy this chance to meet the tea pickers along the way and stop for lunch in Haldummulla. After, make the drive to tonight’s jungle camp accommodation at Udawalawe, stopping at Diyaluma Falls along the way. Your accommodation this evening is a lake-facing camp that backs onto a forest reserve where many herbs used in ayurvedic medicine are grown. When you arrive, you can choose to go on a short tour of the local village or relax at your camp.

dayInfo.title: Mirissa.
dayInfo.description: This morning, you can take an optional excursion to Udawalawe National Park to look for elephants – just keep in mind this activity will require a wake-up call of around 4.30 am. Alternatively, you could sleep in, then maybe head to the ayurvedic medicine manufacturing centre. Later, set off to Mirissa by private bus – this is your paradise accommodation for two days of relaxation.

dayInfo.title: Mirissa.
dayInfo.description: Today is all about laying beachside in Mirissa. The beach itself is a long curve of sand with clear waters perfect for swimming – it’s also a great spot to watch the sunset! Consider taking a bike ride or tuk-tuk to nearby Weligama, where colourful fishing boats bring fresh fish to sell along the shore or maybe explore the UNESCO World Heritage coastal city of Galle by bike, stopping for lunch and taking in the surroundings.

dayInfo.title: Galle.
dayInfo.description: Head further down the coast to Galle – home to an impressive UNESCO World Heritage-listed Dutch fort with extensive walls and many old buildings. When you arrive, head to a local female artisan’s workshop for a demonstration on Beeralu lace weaving. Learn about this practise and how the local artisan hails from a family of traditional Beeralu lace makers. Beeralu is a form of pillow lace that’s hand woven in intricate patterns, often in delicate shades of white. Believed to have been introduced by the Portuguese in the 16th century, you’ll learn more about the history of this art. In the evening, take a stroll around the historic fort and watch the sunset from the ramparts.

dayInfo.title: Colombo.
dayInfo.description: Leaving Galle, you’ll travel on to Colombo – the nation's capital. Stop by some of the city's main sights on a bus tour including Independence Square, Parliament and the National Museum, finishing with a shopping opportunity for a good cause at the Barefoot Fairtrade Store. Here, you can find a collection of handicrafts from around the country and support small cottage industries. If you’re lucky enough to be in Colombo on a Saturday, you’ll visit Good Market – a local market full of stalls showcasing social enterprises and responsible businesses. Tonight, there's an optional group dinner to celebrate your journey together.

dayInfo.title: Colombo.
dayInfo.description: Your trip comes to an end today, with no activities planned. If you'd like to stay longer, just speak to your booking agent.

tourName: Sri Lanka bespoke tour, 14 days
generalInfo:
Sri Lanka is blessed with beautiful hills, beaches and national parks. Few places in the world can offer the traveler such a remarkable combination of stunning landscapes, pristine beaches, captivating cultural heritage and unique experiences within such a compact location. Be it Sinharaja, Udawalawe and Yala National Parks - known for its rich flora and fauna or Nuwara Eliya known for its hills, tea plantations and hiking - this tour covers it all.

Some of the Important Experiences Include:

1. Witness the traditional cultural dance show at Kandy Temple of the Tooth Relic.
2. Go on a Cycle Tour into nearby countryside at Kandy.
3. Go on a hike tour at Nuwara Eliya. Visit one of the highest waterfalls in Sri Lanka - Ramboda Falls.
4. Unwind at Ella – small laid-back town surrounded by the beautiful greens of tea.
5. Relax on the beaches of lovely Arugam Bay, a moon-shaped curl of soft sand.
6. Go on a Jeep Safari at Yala National Park and spot a leopard, safari at Udawalalwe National Park – get a view of Elephants and Safari at UNESCO World Heritage Site & biosphere reserve Sinharaja Forest.

dayInfo.description: Arrive at Colombo International Airport and receive a warm welcome from our representative. Get transferred to the hotel. Complete the check-in formalities and enjoy the rest of the day at leisure.

After breakfast check out from the hotel and travel to Kandy (122Km, 4 hours by car). On arrival complete the check-in formalities and rest for a while. • Later visit the temple of the tooth relic • Enjoy a brief tour of the beautiful Kandy town. • Thereafter witness the traditional cultural dance show starting at 1700hrs.

• After early breakfast, see another side of Kandy with a day cycling trip that takes you away from the busy lifestyle of Kandy city center and into the nearby countryside. • Later proceed to Peradeniya Botanical Gardens.

After breakfast, check out from the hotel and travel to Nuwara Eliya (80km, 3 hours by car). (If you wish you may also enjoy a scenic train ride from Kandy to Ella- Subject to Train ticket availability) On arrival at Nuwara Eliya, check in to your hotel, and enjoy the rest of the day at leisure

Early morning Transfer to Horton Plains National Park for a Day Hike (31Km, 1 hour by car). This is the only National Park where visitors could walk on their own in the designated tracks. Later go for City Tour of Nuwara Eliya with your guide.

Today, after breakfast at the hotel, you will check out and proceed to Arugam Bay via Ella. Nuwara Eliya – Ella (55km, 2 hours by car). • Visit to 9 Arch bridge & Mini Adams peak • Visit to Ravana Falls Later proceed to travel to Arugam Bay. (133Km, 3 hours by car). Check in to the hotel and spend the rest of the day at leisure.
After breakfast, spend the day at leisure on the beautiful beach. If you wish you may indulge in Surfing or take a lagoon Safari (at additional cost)
After breakfast, check out from the hotel and travel to Yala (191Km, 5 hours by car). On arrival, check in to the hotel, leisure, and overnight at the hotel.
Enjoy morning and evening game drives in the Yala national park. We recommend an early morning or late afternoon game drive to elevate your chances of spotting the most animals.

Early morning go for a game drive in the Yala National Park. After breakfast, check out from the hotel and get transferred to Udawalawe – One of the oldest national parks in Sri Lanka. (110Km, 3 hours by car). On arrival, check in to the hotel, leisure, enjoy the dinner and overnight at the hotel.
Go on a Jeep Safari inside Udawalawe National Park. (AM & PM Safari). Later come back to the hotel and enjoy dinner and rest of the day at leisure.

Early morning go for Safari inside the Udawalawe National Park. After breakfast, check out from the hotel and travel to Sinharaja (66Km, 2 hours by car). On arrival, check in to hotel, leisure, and overnight at hotel.
After breakfast, proceed for 01 hour trekking at Sinharaja Rainforest. Sinharaja is declared as a UNESCO World Heritage Site & biosphere reserve.
After breakfast, check-out from hotel and travel to Colombo international airport (148Km, 4 hours by car) to board your flight to your native place. (Reach International airport before 3 hours)

tourName: Sri Lanka boutique hotels holiday
