This magical place with enormous Dagobas, palaces, monasteries and monuments evidence one of the greatest civilizations in the world. The Sacred city of Anuradhapura was first Royal Kingdom and capital of Sri Lanka that lasted for 1,500 years until it was abandoned after the invasion by South Indian Cholas in 993. Today Anuradhapura is one of the world’s major archaeological sites in the world. It is covered area about 40 km² and an UNESCO World Heritage Site. This sacred city was established around a cutting from the 'tree of enlightenment', the Buddha's fig tree, brought there in the 3rd century B.C. by Sanghamitta, the founder of an order of Buddhist nuns. The ruined city hidden away in dense jungle for many years brought to life by The British in the nineteenth century. After travel to Sigiriya. Travel time approximately 2,5 hours. Location : Sigiriya Hotel : Sigiriya Kings Resort on Half Board

Sigiriya : After breakfast you will climb Sigiriya Rock Fortress. Sigiriya is a UNESCO World Heritage site which is proposed to be the 8th wonders of the World. Sigiriya, a massive rock in the green scrub jungle, is perhaps the most memorable place for visitors to Sri Lanka. The site was known from ancient times as a hermitage for Buddhist monks. A well-planned monastic complex included caved temples, bathing pools, lovely ponds and Asia’s oldest surviving landscaped gardens. Afternoon safari at Kaudulla National Park ( or Minneriya) – this National Park is the most recent to be added to the list of 15 Parks in the country. Famous for its elephants and bird population, species include the nation’s largest bird, the Lesser Adjutant and the Pompadour Green Pigeon. Built around the year 300 AD, the Tank slowly fell into disrepair and was rebuilt in 1959, and with its variety of plant life has now become home to 24 species of mammals, 25 species of amphibians and countless bird types. The endangered Rusty Spotted Cat can be spotted in Kaudulla National Park, as well as large herds of Asian elephants, elusive leopards and both Sambar and Axis Deer. Location : Sigiriya Hotel: Sigiriya Kings Resort on Half Board

Sigiriya > Dambulla > Kandy : Today you will travel to Kandy after breakfast. Travel time is approximately 1 ½ hours. En-route to Kandy you will visit to Dambulla Cave Temple. Dambulla Golden Rock Cave Temple is a vast isolated rock mass 500ft high and a 1.6 km around the base. Here is found the impressive Rock Temple dating to the First Century BC. The caves of Dambulla sheltered the King Walagamba during his 14 years of exile from Anuradhapura. When he regained the throne he built the most magnificent of Rock Temples to be found on the Island. The complex consists of five caves with over 2000 sq. meters of painted walls and ceilings. It is the largest area of paintings found in the world. It is an UNESCO World Heritage site. In the first Cave is a recumbent image of the Buddha 14 metre long cut out of the Rock. There are images of deities associated with Buddhism all around. The frescoes on the ceiling date back to the 15th - 18th Centuries. In the Second Cave, the finest and the largest of all, there are 150 life-size statues of Gods from the Buddhist religion along with numerous images of the Buddha himself. Evening you can have a short walk at Kandy City. Kandy is a beautiful historical city in the citadel of the country. It is not only known for its great kings who ruled the city for almost 225 years independently until the British took over in 1815, but it is also the place where the Sacred Tooth of Lord Buddha is laid in a magnificent temple. Strategically nestled amidst three mountain ranges, Kandy was initially built in this location as a natural fortress against attack. Kandy was not an easy target for the foreign invaders who could gain the control of coastal areas of the island without too much loss. Kandy’s main architectural monuments date mainly from the 19th Century when King Sri Vikrama Rajasinha, the last King of Kandy, constructed many new buildings. At the time of the eventual surrender of Kandy to British Rule in 1815, when King Rajasinha was captured, imprisoned and finally deported to India where he died in 1832. Location : Kandy; Hotel : Theva Residency on Bed & Breakfast

Kandy: After breakfast you will take a mountain walk to one of the most beautiful and remote villages in Heel Oya at the foothills of Knuckles Mountains with an experienced guide. You can see a breath taking sights of a village untouched by mass tourism growth or development. The walk goes through beautiful forests, Tea estates, gushing streams, jungle patches, waterfalls, terraced rice fields and domestic spice fields. So you will be able to see working spice, paddy and tea fields, interact with real locals, taste home cooked food, and see how animals are used for farming work. You can also experience a river bath in beautiful river. Location : Kandy; Hotel : Theva Residency on Bed & Breakfast

Kandy > Hatton> Kitulgala: After breakfast you will travel to Kitulgala via Hatton by train. Experience one of the most breathtaking train journeys for 2:30 hours. You will travel from Kandy to Hatton through tea plantations and rolling hills on Old Colonial train with scenic views. This train journeys recorded in the Guinness Books of Records as the one of the world best scenic train journeys. Your guide will pick you up at the Hatton Station and you will go to Kitulgala en-route visiting tea plantations. You will visit a tea plantation for Tea Estate Experience: Experience the process and lifestyle within a tea estate. Tea is known as Sri Lanka’s green gold and the tea estate provides insight into British colonial past and role of tea in Sri Lanka today. The scenic views from the tea estates are breathtaking. Afterwards you will continue your journey to Kitulgala. Location : Kithulgala; Hotel : Forest Edge on Half Board

Kitulgala > Ambalangoda Kitulgala has been famous for being the location where the award winning classic movie “Bridge on the River Kwai” directed by David Lean was filmed. The picturesque location of the movie by the river is accessible to all visitors. The river flowing through the village is exceptionably enjoyable. The name of Kitulgala is derived from the Kitul Palm tree (Sinhala: Sago Palm tree) that abound in the village of Kitulgala. Kitul palm syrup is a necessary ingredient in preparations of numerous traditional Sinhalese sweets. Optional: After breakfast you will hike for 8 kms/5 miles to reach one of the pre-historic caves in Sri Lanka. Belilena Cave is one of the largest caves in Sri Lanka and belonged pre-historic era of Balangoda Man. This Huge Cave has been home to the prehistoric ‘Balangoda Man’ (Homo sapiens balangodensis) where 12,000 year old skeletal remains have been found recently. The depths of this caves are home of thousands of bats and butterflies. The path to reach the cave is exciting as the cave as you will pass rubber plantations and untouched wilderness. Experience the white water rafting in the Kelaniya River from 5 major rapids and 4 minor rapids with the rafting stretch approximately 6.5 kilometres in length, and taking between 45 minutes to 1.5 hours to complete, depending on water levels. This is for anyone above the age of 12 with safety gear, modern rafts, and a comprehensive safety briefing provided. Or you can choose more relaxing flat water rafting if you are with small children. After the water rafting you will travel to Ambalangoda. Travel time approximately 3 ½ hours depend on the road traffics. Location : Ambalangoda; Hotel: Of your choice On Half Board
Ambalangoda : Full day at leisure on beach. Location : Ambalangoda; Hotel: of your choice On Half Board

Ambalangoda : Morning at leisure. Optional: Afternoon you will be introduced to local family after greetings and cup of tea. Let your host know if you have any allergies or meal preferences. You will visit the bustling local market with your host. In the market you will buy together with your host ingredients for your Lunch. Your host will talk you through the core ingredients of Sri Lankan cuisine such as curry leaves, coconuts, local fruit and vegetables, pandan leaves and spices. Afterwards you will visit the daily fisherman catch of the day; here you will buy fish or seafood local fisherman. From here you will drive to the host place to prepare the rice and curries. You will also discover secrets of coconut, learn to crack open and scrape out your own coconut, and taste samples of each dish as you go along. The end product is a feast of 5-7 unique dishes served in a lotus/banana leaf which you can eat local-style with your fingers if you are up for the challenge with local beer or soft drink. Location : Ambalangoda; Hotel : of your choice on Half Board

Ambalangoda > Colombo : After early breakfast you will travel to Colombo travel time approximately 2 hours. Colombo guided tour: (optional tuk-tuk tour) Starting from Fort, Independent Square, Old Parliament, Pettah Bazaar and Galle Face. You will also have time for shopping as well. Colombo Fort is the business district of Sri Lanka with skyscrapers and big international hotels. The Fort was built by the Portuguese and Dutch partly, later took control by the British. In 1870 the British destroyed the Fort for urban development, and then they rebuilt some of the remaining buildings within it now. Colombo Fort is home to Fort Railway Station, President's House and Presidential Gardens, a palatial neo- classical building which was originally the home of the British Governors and is now the residence of Sri Lanka's president. The Lighthouse Clock Tower situated in the Chatham Street commissioned by the wife of Governor Sir Henry Ward in the hope that it would teach the Ceylonese to be punctual. Around here is good for shopping tea, souvenirs, and exchange money. Independence Square is known as one of the most prominent locations in Colombo. It is commonly used as a place where Sri Lankans come together in unison for significant national celebrations and cultural activities. The Independence Commemoration Hall is also used to host ceremonies that mark national unity. This unique and outstanding monument positioned in the heart of Sri Lanka’s commercial capital Colombo, commemorates the country’s independence from foreign rule. Sri Lanka gained independence on the 4th of February 1948 from the British who were the final colonial rulers of the country. Opposite the Presidential Secretariat (old Parliament) is the Colombo breathing green space known as Galle Face. Here every walk of life comes for relaxing time. Just to sit on the grass and watch the sunset over the Indian Ocean. Next to Galle Face is the grand Renaissance-style structure of Galle Face Hotel, South Asia’s leading Grande Dame, and the Galle Face Hotel is testimony to both Sri Lanka’s colonial past and its independent present. You can enjoy the English high tea on the Victorian style Veranda or sip a martini facing the sea and enjoy the sunset. Location : Colombo Hotel: Marino Beach on Bed & Breakfast
Colombo > Airport Today you will travel to Colombo International Airport to fly to London. Travel time approximately an hour depend on the road traffics.

tourName: Sri Lanka family adventure holidays
generalInfo:
This wonderful family adventure begins with immersing you straight in to the culture and community of Sri Lanka. Enjoying sundowners with local fishermen near Negombo.
The experiences and sights will provide memories to treasure together forever!

Visit to Sigiriya. This region is home to the “Lion Rock” famous for its frescoes of ‘Celestial Maidens’ is possibly the most impressive site in Sri Lanka.

Spend time experiencing a rural community, followed by lunch. The experience includes a visit to a small school with just about 20 children below the age of 10 years. The visit is followed by a walk through the village and various plantations including Chena cultivations, ending up at a village house where you will enjoy a typical Sri Lankan rice and curry meal.

Visit the Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic of Lord Buddha.

Enjoy a scenic train ride from Kandy to Nuwara Eliya.

safari in the Udawalawe National Park.

Udawalawe is the most reliable place to see elephants in their wild habitat year-round.

A treasure hunt! Using clues and your mobile phone. This is a super-fun way of exploring Galle and its’ special sites and locations.

dayInfo.description: Arrival at Bandaranaike International Airport. Upon your arrival at the airport, you will be welcomed and assisted by a Representative of Journey In Style. You will then be escorted to your vehicle and introduced to your chauffeur and transferred to your hotel. In the evening, drive to Negombo where you will experience a boat ride to an island in the lagoon where you will enjoy a spectacular sunset while enjoying cocktails and drinks. Check into your hotel for your overnight stay.

Breakfast in the hotel. After breakfast, checkout from the hotel and proceed to Anuradhapura. Check in to you hotel. Enjoy the premises, activities and the hotel facilities as you relax for the remainder of the day. Return to your hotel for overnight stay.

Your day is at leisure to enjoy your hotel and surroundings. The hotel has lots of amazing activities on offer from Horse Riding, or discover your surroundings on a bike ride around the local village, Athungama. Kayaking or head off the beaten track with an 4x4 drive, weaving along earthen tracks through rural countryside dominated by rice paddies. Birds and buffalo are often sighted alongside other wildlife, including elephants, particularly when you reach scenic Nachchaduwa Lake, a vast reservoir framed by dense pockets of forest and the distant hills. This setting makes a great spot for enjoying sundowners before heading back to the hotel. *Elephant sightings however depend on the season, July to August being the peak.

After an early breakfast, head out to Sigiriya. This region is home to the “Lion Rock” famous for its frescoes of ‘Celestial Maidens’ is possibly the most impressive site in Sri Lanka. Enjoy a climb to the top of this sky citadel. Spend time experiencing a rural community, followed by lunch. Enjoy a stroll through a small rural village in the elephant country of Sigiriya. The experience includes a visit to a small school with just about 20 children below the age of 10 years. The visit is followed by a walk through the village and various plantations including Chena cultivations, ending up at a village house where you will enjoy a typical Sri Lankan rice and curry meal. Having completed your village experience, drive to the central hill country to arrive at your next destination, the city Kandy. Check in to your hotel for your overnight stay.

After breakfast, you will visit the Peradeniya Botanical gardens. Initially a royal park, in 1821 under British rule it became a botanical garden. Here, exotic crops such as coffee, tea, nutmeg, rubber and cinchona (quinine) – all of which were to become important to the country’s economy were first tested. The Botanical gardens are fantastic with an excellent orchid house and a wide variety of plant species from all over the world. For keen gardeners, at least a morning is recommended to visit the gardens, possibly longer. Thereafter, enjoy a tour of the city of Kandy. Wandering about in Kandy is a fun experience, with crossroads and interconnecting byroads – all forming an intertwined complex. Most pavements are dominated by vendors selling garments, lotteries, toys and various fancy items – making passing through look almost impossible, especially during festive seasons. The main market area in the heart of the town is frequented often for its array of fresh fruits, vegetables, fish and meat stalls, sweets, clothes, fancy goods and what not…! In the evening, Visit the Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic of Lord Buddha. Ever since it was founded in the 16th Century, it has housed one of the most sacred relics of Buddhism – a tooth of Buddha collected from his funeral pyre and which is now protected within the gold-roofed Temple of the Tooth. See the blessing ceremony with all the fanfare, drums, trumpets and brightly coloured Monks performing their rituals. Return to your hotel for overnight stay.

After breakfast, traverse to Nuwara Eliya. Set in the cool and misty hilly interior at an altitude of 1800m is the city of Nuwara Eliya. Developed by the British in the 19th century as an escape from the sweltering heat of the lowlands it came complete with half- timbered mock-Tudor houses with inglenook fireplaces & billiard tables, a golf course, race track, gentlemen’s clubs and botanical gardens. Now a bustling town and the vegetable garden of Sri Lanka it nonetheless gives you a glimpse into life in the colonial heyday. Check in to your hotel for overnight stay. Optional : Enjoy a scenic train ride from Kandy to Nuwara Eliya

Your next destination is the town of Udawalawe. Check into your hotel and prepare for an afternoon safari in the Udawalawe National Park. Udawalawe is the most reliable place to see elephants in their wild habitat year-round. Some 400-500 elephants live in the park and herds of up to 50 are commonly seen. The open plains are covered in thick manna grass up to the borders of the large reservoir in the centre and the Walawe river. The park is also covered by some abandoned teak plantation and a dense scrub jungle. This variety in habitat makes for a rich variety of wildlife and game. As well as elephants, leopards too live in the park (though you will be very lucky to spot one) along with toque monkeys, grey langur, spotted deer, wild pig and sambar. There are numerous bird species of course and Udawalawe is particularly rich in raptor species, among them the white bellied sea eagle and the crested serpent eagle.

After breakfast, check out from your hotel and travel to Galle. Make a stop at the elephant transit home during your journey. Supported by the Born Free Foundation (www.bornfree.org.uk), this complex is a halfway house for orphaned elephants. After rehabilitation, the elephants are released back into the wild, many into the Uda Walawe National Park. Although you can’t get up close and personal with the elephants, seeing them at feeding time (from a viewing platform) is still a lot of fun. Elephants here are not normally chained at night (unlike at other elephant 'orphanages') in Sri Lanka. Over 100 elephants have been rehabilitated at the Elephant Transit Home and subsequently released into the wild. The coastal town of Galle, the capital of the Southern Province, is best known for its impressive fort: a UNESCO World Heritage Site and the best-preserved colonial sea fortress in Asia. The fort was built and modified over 4 centuries; started by the Portuguese in the late 16th century it was later taken over by the Dutch and eventually by the British. Protected within its walls, bastions and ramparts is a complete town with narrow streets, churches and cloistered inner courtyards of shuttered mansions, which clearly bear testament to their colonial past En-route enjoy a viewing of Stilt fisherman Stilt fishing is a method of fishing unique to the island country of Sri Lanka. The fishermen sit on a cross bar called a petta tied to a vertical pole and driven into the sand a few meters offshore. ... Fishing stops entirely during the annual monsoons Check in to your hotel for overnight stay.

Breakfast in the hotel. Today you will enjoy a tour of Galle. Followed by a treasure hunt. This is a super-fun way of exploring Galle and its’ special bits and pieces. Return to your hotel for overnight stay.
After breakfast check out from your hotel and travel to Colombo. In the evening enjoy a tour of Forgotten Colombo on a Landy Check in to your hotel for an overnight stay

Transfer to the airport for your flight home or onward to your next destination. Why not extend with a beach stay in Bentota or head off to the idyllic islands of the Maldives! Sri Lanka combines perfectly with the Maldives. Ask us for more information.

tourName: Sri Lanka family holiday, 14 days
generalInfo:
Welcome to our unique 14-day Sri Lanka Family Holiday....

Sri Lanka offers something for everyone. This two-week Sri Lanka family holiday is tailor-made for you by your local guide Rajiv who has been working with tourist families for the past 20 years and has an immense knowledge of his 'teardrop' island he calls home together with his wife Gillian. Rajiv has included both touristy activities and off the beaten track locations.

Sri Lanka is a paradise that we proudly call the Pearl of the Indian Ocean. Its golden sandy beaches, majestic rainforest-covered mountains, cascading waterfalls, UNESCO heritage sites, sacred rock temples, tea plantations, and ancient royal cities offer something for everyone including the amazing local food.

On your arrival in Sri Lanka, you will be met by your local team Gillian and Rajiv. We are both passionate about travel and local food and this makes us the best local team to travel with during your holiday.

Our customized and bespoke tours give you the chance to encounter herds of wild elephants, the elusive leopards, and endangered sloth bears of Sri Lanka including hundreds of bird species in the company of a local guide or ranger.

The Sri Lanka Family Holiday includes Colombo, Kandy, Nuwara Eliya, UNESCO World Heritage Sites, national parks, beautiful beaches, and some of the key ancient cities that make up Sri Lanka's Cultural Triangle.

We have designed this holiday for you from start to end with one key element in mind which is peace of mind.

One key element which must be considered when visiting Sri Lanka on holiday is the tropical weather. We have planned this holiday so that you will enjoy bright sunshine and blue skies especially when at the beach.

We as responsible and honest travel agents recommend this holiday between November and April to minimize the chance of rain especially when you are relaxing at the beach.

Anyone can visit Sri Lanka, but not everyone gets the chance to chat over dinner or travel together with a local host, take a safari at dawn with a knowledgeable ranger, and get the best seats on one of the most scenic railway journeys in the world. You need a local specialist to provide you with insider information, make arrangements using local contacts, and advise on the best times of year to visit different areas...

Our family-operated company has been doing just that since 2004 and 50% of our business comes from personal referrals and repeat business. We strongly believe in responsible and sustainable tourism and are proud of the fact that 90% of your tour fee stays in Sri Lanka...

All hotels are locally owned and managed and you will be transported in the comfort of your own privet chauffeur-driven vehicle, where you sit back and enjoy a bespoke itinerary that is as unique and individual as you. All our vehicles are fully insured and driven by experienced chauffeurs...

Sri Lankan is ready for you... We look forward to hearing from you soon!

WELLCOME TO SRI LANKA MACHANG!

generalInfo:
