dayInfo.description: NEGOMBO: Arrive into Colombo International Airport and head straight to The Wallawwa to recuperate amidst startlingly peaceful surroundings. Set in expansive tropical grounds with a big kitchen garden, this former manor house offers family-orientated room options, varied cuisine, discreet service and a decadent spa. Be on the beach in 30 minutes, play croquet or take a private guided tour by boat or kayak through the bird-filled Muthurajawela Wetlands. Colombo’s restaurants and sights are 30-40 minutes’ away. Travel time Colombo Airport to The Wallawwa: 20 minutes. Stay 1 night at The Wallawwa.

SIGIRIYA: From The Wallawwa, make your way up into Sri Lanka’s historic Cultural Triangle, so-called for the collection of World Heritage Sites and significant attractions located up here. You’ll stay at Water Garden – Sigiriya, one of the region’s newest boutique hotels, which is within eye-sight of one of the island’s most photographed attractions, Sigiriya. This former rock-top fortress dates back to the seventh century, and is home to superb examples of ancient hydro engineering as well as well-preserved frescoes. A hike up to the summit, where the views are incredible, is a definite highlight of this trip. Younger children might wish to sit this out though, and can instead enjoy the hotel’s own water gardens – the swimming pool and separate kid’s pool. The hotel’s rooms are all freestanding villas, and offer plenty of space. Other notable local sights include Dambulla’s Cave Temples while further afield you could try your luck seeking out elephants in Minneriya National Park, or visit Polonnaruwa or Anuradhapura, two former capitals. Travel time Negombo to Sigiriya: 4 hours. Stay 3 nights at Water Garden - Sigiriya.

KANDY: Travel south from the Cultural Triangle to Kandy, a university town home to the Temple of the Tooth – Sri Lanka’s most sacred shrine – the Botanical Gardens, the British Garrison Cemetery and a tea museum. Around a 60- to 90-minute drive south west of Kandy is Taylors Hill, a spectacularly sited family-friendly boutique hotel set in acres of landscaped gardens. With just five bedrooms, this century old former planter’s residence feels like a family home and comes with a TV room, a snooker room, a kids play area, extensive gardens and plenty of outdoor activities such as tennis, badminton, croquet and swimming. There are bicycles for exploring the locality, a dedicated nature guide and nearby is Sri Lanka’s very first tea plantation, Loolecondera Estate, former home of Ceylon Tea legend James Taylor. Travel time Sigiriya to Deltota (Kandy): 4 hours. Stay 2 nights at Taylors Hill.

DEMODERA (ELLA): Travel to the western Hill Country, which is equally spectacular yet has a different feel. On your way, you could go via Nuwara Eliya to check out the colonial-era sights of this former British Hill Station and pause there for lunch. Around town are allotments bursting with leeks, potatoes, carrots and other vegetables and the region is also well known for growing strawberries. You could also take the train to Demodera from Hatton, which offers one of the most spectacular routes through the Hill Country. Demodera is close to better-known Ella (15-minutes away), yet is a secluded and much quieter place to stay. Nine Skies is located just above the railway line, and the station itself is famous for its 360-degree loop of track while nearby is the Nine Arch Bridge, after which the bungalow was named. The bungalow has been beautifully refurbished and offers plush contemporary comforts including butler service, excellent food and a garden with swimming pool. Attractions include tea factory visits, tea trails, waterfall swims and hill walks. Travel time Deltota (Kandy) to Demodera (Ella): 4.5 hours. Stay 2 nights at Nine Skies.

YALA NATIONAL PARK: Travel south to Yala National Park and to Noel Rodrigo’s Leopard Safaris. After reaching Wellawaya, just beyond Ella, you could make a small detour to Buduruwagala – a series of seven well-preserved Buddhist figures carved into sheer rock. Yala National Park is the island’s premier wildlife preserves, home to a dense population of leopards, as well as elephants and sloth bears. Camping at the edge of the park is a magical once-in-a-lifetime experience that all the family will enjoy; Noel Rodrigo’s Leopard Safaris has family tents, and aside from game drives there are wildlife art classes and animal identification games for the kids. Travel time Kandapola (Nuwara Eliya) to Yala National Park: 4.5 hours. Stay 2 nights at Noel Rodrigo’s Leopard Safaris.

GALLE: Travel west along the picturesque cove-sprinkled southern coastline to Galle, famed for pretty beaches, a 17th century Dutch fort and a cosmopolitan vibe. Here you’ll stay at Why House, an idyllic country-style boutique hotel with big garden and expansive swimming pool. The hotel has an excellent restaurant (with plenty of kids items to choose from, or dishes that can be customised), and there are many others in the local area. Aside from sculpting sandcastles on one of the region’s pretty beaches (the nearest is just a few minutes away), family activities include guided bicycle rides along scenic rural inland lanes, boat trips (on Koggala Lake), seasonal whale and dolphin watching or surfing. Travel time Yala National Park to Galle: 4 hours. Stay 4 nights at Why House.
DEPART SRI LANKA: Travel time Galle to Colombo Airport: 3 hours

tourName: Sri Lanka family holiday, tailor made
generalInfo:
PLEASE NOTE THAT WE CAN ADJUST/CHANGE DETAILS OF THIS TOUR FOR YOU AS YOU WISH. THIS IS NOT A GROUP TOUR, BUT PRIVATE TOUR WITH YOUR OWN DRIVER.
Tropical discovery Tour covers best of Sri Lanka has to offer in short space of time. You will be discovering the 2000 years old ancient temples, spotting elephants, leopards, sloth bears and more wildlife, exploring the tea plantations and waterfalls, and finally unwinding in the sandy beaches. You will have your own personal chauffeur guide with car or van, so you can experience Sri Lanka at your own pace.
TOUR HIGHLIGHTS:
- Spectacle of Elephants Gathering –Minneriya National Park
- Watch the elephants at Elephant Transit Home
- Spotting Leopards at Wilpattu National Park
- Scenic train journey through tea hills and waterfalls above 1500 meters
- Experience Dambulla Golden Rock Cave Temple (UNESCO World Heritage Site)
- Discovering Galle Dutch Fort (UNESCO World Heritage Site)
- Relax and unwind in Golden sandy beaches of East Coast
- Enjoy Ayurveda Traditional massage
- Taste fresh sea food and Sri Lankan curry

dayInfo.description: Departure to Colombo, Sri Lanka. Today you will fly to Colombo with Sri Lankan Airlines Direct from Heathrow

Arrival > Ambalangoda “Ayubowan” & ‘’Vanakkam’’ Welcome to tropical paradise. You will be welcomed & greeted by your guide or The Earth Trip representative on arrival at the Waiting Area at Colombo International Airport. You will travel to Ambalangoda. Travel time approximately 2 hours depends on the road traffic. Rest of the day you can relax & enjoy. Location : Ambalangoda Hotel : Bed & Breakfast

Ambalangoda : In the morning Madu Ganga river safari to spot birds and reptails ( and sometimes crocodile) and visit few islands on the river: One with stunning temple and one with locoal cinnamon production. Afternoon you will visit the Galle Dutch Fort. There are many boutique shops along the narrow streets of the Fort as well as antiques, art and craft shops. Galle is situated in the southern Sri Lanka. It is the best example of a fortified city built by Europeans in south and Southeast Asia, showing the interaction between European architectural styles and south Asian traditions. The Galle fort is a UNESCO world heritage site and the largest remaining fortress in Asia built by European occupiers. Other prominent landmarks in Galle include the natural harbour, the National Maritime Museum, St. Mary's Cathedral founded by Jesuit priests, one of the main Shiva temples on the island. Galle offers a unique opportunity to create a visible demonstration of the conservation of its inheritance. Location : Ambalangoda Hotel : Bed & Breakfast

Ambalangoda > Haputale After breakfast you will travel to Galle, along the way near the village of Weligama, where you can see the Stilt Fisherman. Weligama literally translating as ‘sandy village,’ Weligama has a long stretch of fine golden sand. Famous for its stilt fishermen, visitors can see this unique sight only in this part of Sri Lanka. No-one knows where, or even when this form of fishing originated, but it is an old tradition which lives on in a modern world today. This centuries old traditional method of fishing is one of the best sustainable practices to catch the fish. The Stilt Fisherman spends 2-4 hours sitting on a thin plank, hoping to catch one or two fish for their family’s lunch or dinner. Afterwards you will travel to Udawalawe. Travel time is approximately 2 hours. In the evening you will visit Elephant Transit Home en-route to Haputale. Elephant Transit Home (ETH), where the orphan wild elephants are treated, raised and released back to the wild, also is located at Udawalawe. Visitors to this place can observe how the elephants are taken care of, twice a day. Total number of orphaned elephants exceeds 40, of which most of them are calves and juveniles. The animals become matured enough to live on their own, are released back to the wild. Park authorities keep constant vigilance on the newly released animals, until they get used to the new life in the wild. Click the link for BBC Natural World Documentary (Elephant Island) 2013 Afterwards you will travel to Haputale. Travel time is approximately 3 hours. Location : Haputale Hotel : Breakfast & Dinner

Haputale : In the morning you can visit the Nine Arch Bridge. This magnificent Nine Arch Bridge between Ella and Demodara stations are just a few kilometres along the track from the Demodara station. This viaduct bridge built during the British Colonial period is the largest in Sri Lanka has been built with blocks of stone and cement without any reinforcing iron or concrete. The tall arches take the bridge on a semicircular path to connect to mountains. Located almost 3100 feet above the sea level, this 99.6ft high bridge is called "Ahas namaye palama" (Nine skies bridge) in Sinhala. When one stands underneath it and looks up there is a beautiful sight of 'nine skies' through the nine arches, hence the Sinhala name. This bridge is also called 'The Bridge in the sky' due to the sheer height. You can have a walk through the lush tea plantations and feel the green nature at your own phase and see many water falls. Location : Haputale Hotel :Breakfast & Dinner

Haputale : Early morning hike to see the sunrise from Little Adam’s Peak. Little Adam’s Peak resembles the main Adam’s Peak near Hatton. By foot it takes about 35-40 minutes. Here you will be able to enjoy the breath-taking views of an endless valleys, tea plantations and waterfalls. After breakfast at 09.20hrs you will experience of the most scenic train journeys for 2:20 hours. You will travel from Ella to Nanuoya through tea plantations and rolling hills on Old Colonial train known as Podi Manike (the little precious wife) with scenic view. This train journeys recorded in the Guinness Books of Records as the one of the world best scenic train journeys. Your guide will pick you up at the Nanuoya and drive back to the hotel. Rest of the day you can relax. Location : Haputale Hotel : Breakfast & Dinner

Haputale > Kandy In the morning you will travel to Kandy. Travel time is approximately 4 hours. Afterwards you will visit The Temple of the Tooth & Buddhist Museum, Sri Dalada Maligawa dates back to the 16th century, though most of the present buildings were built in the 19th century. Venerated as the most important object in the Buddhist world, the Sacred Relic of the Tooth of Buddha is enshrined at the Temple. Brought from India 2500 years ago, it is said that the possessor of the Relic had the right to rule the country. The Relic is kept in a gold casket and stored amidst great security in the Inner Chamber. In the evening you will take a city tour at Kandy. Kandy is a beautiful historical city in the citadel of the country. It is not only known for its great kings who ruled the city for almost 225 years independently until the British took over in 1815, but it is also the place where the Sacred Tooth of Lord Buddha is laid in a magnificent temple. Strategically nestled amidst three mountain ranges, Kandy was initially built in this location as a natural fortress against attack. Kandy was not an easy target for the foreign invaders who could gain the control of coastal areas of the island without too much loss. Kandy’s main architectural monuments date mainly from the 19th Century when King Sri Vikrama Rajasinha, the last King of Kandy, constructed many new buildings. At the time of the eventual surrender of Kandy to British Rule in 1815, when King Rajasinha was captured, imprisoned and finally deported to India where he died in 1832. Location : Kandy Hotel : Bed & Breakfast

Kandy > Sigiriya Today you will take a mountain walk to one of the most beautiful and remote villages in Heel Oya at the foothills of Knuckles Mountains with an experienced guide. You can see a breath taking sights of a village untouched by mass tourism growth or development. The walk goes through beautiful forests, Tea estates, gushing streams, jungle patches, waterfalls, terraced rice fields and domestic spice fields. So you will be able to see working spice, paddy and tea fields, interact with real locals, taste home cooked food, and see how animals are used for farming work. You will take a fresh and compatible bath at a river if you like. Optional: You would be able to visit a real home in the mountains where one could witness or join cooking with the locals. The home cooked meal will be served as your lunch complimented with fresh home grown fruits such as Mangoes and Bananas. Afterwards you will travel to Sigiriya. Travel time is approximately 2 hours. En route to Sigiriya you will visit to Dambulla Cave Temple. Dambulla Golden Rock Cave Temple is a vast isolated rock mass 500ft high and a 1.6 km around the base. Here is found the impressive Rock Temple dating to the First Century BC. The caves of Dambulla sheltered the King Walagamba during his 14 years of exile from Anuradhapura. When he regained the throne he built the most magnificent of Rock Temples to be found on the Island. The complex consists of five caves with over 2000 sq. meters of painted walls and ceilings. It is the largest area of paintings found in the world. It is an UNESCO World Heritage site. In the first Cave is a recumbent image of the Buddha 14 metre long cut out of the Rock. There are images of deities associated with Buddhism all around. The frescoes on the ceiling date back to the 15th - 18th Centuries. In the Second Cave, the finest and the largest of all, there are 150 life-size statues of Gods from the Buddhist religion along with numerous images of the Buddha himself. Location : Sigiriya Hotel : Breakfast & Dinner

Sigiriya : After breakfast you will visit to Sigiriya Rock fortress. Sigiriya is a UNESCO World Heritage site which is proposed to be the 8th wonders of the World. Sigiriya, a massive rock in the green scrub jungle, is perhaps the most memorable place for visitors to Sri Lanka. The site was known from ancient times as a hermitage for Buddhist monks. A well-planned monastic complex included caved temples, bathing pools, lovely ponds and Asia's oldest surviving landscaped gardens. The "Lion stairway", the "mirror wall" and the "water gardens" are its other highlights. The ruins of the capital built by the parricidal King Kashyapa I (477–95) lie on the steep slopes and at the summit of a granite peak standing some 370 m high (the 'Lion's Rock', which dominates the jungle from all sides). Afterwards enjoy Ayurveda massage one hour each per person to rejuvenate your bodies. Ayurveda is the ancient health care system in South Asia that has been passed down from father to son and based on herbs and diet. It is one of the world’s oldest forms of healing and treatment. You will find some of the best Ayurveda practitioners in Sri Lanka. Ayurveda is a well-known treatment for stress, diabetes, migraine, asthma, arthritis, immune system and high blood pressure. Ayurveda is derived from Sanskrit for life (Ayuh) and knowledge (Veda), means ‘the science of life’. Therefore, Ayurveda is one of the oldest medical sciences of the world and its origins date back as far as 5,000 years South Asia. After lunch around 2pm: Enjoy a Jeep Safari at Minneriya National Park (Duration – 2 hours). It’s on the banks of the Minneriya reservoir, which was built in the 4th century A.C. Minneriya is a hide-out for many elephants, where you could see herds of elephants approximately 50 to 60 elephants in a herd. Here in July to September one of the World top ten wild life spectacles takes place known as ‘The Gathering’, more 250 elephants gather around Minneriya water tank in search water and food. Apart from elephants, it is a habitant for migrant and resident bird species like Grey heron, Open built storks, Painted storks …etc. And also you could see 3 different species of monkeys like Silica make, Pink faced leaf monkey and Grey Langer. Location : Sigiriya Hotel : Breakfast & Dinner

Sigiriya > Trincomalee After breakfast you will travel to Nilaveli. Travel time is approximately 2 ½ hours. En- route to Sigiriya you can visit to Polonnaruwa. Polonnaruwa was the mediaeval capital of Sri Lanka, and today it is one of the most beautiful centres of Sri Lanka’s cultural heritage and UNESCO Heritage site. With its comparatively brief history and a dozen rules, it is far more completely preserves ruin than Anuradhapura. Visit the ancient ruins and Gal Vihara complex, where 3 gigantic Buddha's statues are carved out of a single rock. You also will be able to see the toque macaque monkeys found only in Sri Lanka. Location : Trincomalee Hotel : Breakfast & Dinner

Trincomalee : Morning at leisure. Afternoon you will visit Koneshwaram Temple and discover Trincomalee, is a port city and has the fifth largest natural harbour in the world. The city is surrounded by lagoons, bays and hills and situated in a peninsula. The white powder golden sandy beaches spread across the area offer its visitors calm azure waters to immerse themselves in the water. This is a perfect place for snorkelling, scuba diving and surfing. This port city has a history worth exploring, the strategic location of the natural harbour made it a city worthwhile conquering, and hence it was conquered by the Portuguese, Dutch and the British. Trincomalee is fondly referred to as Trinco by the locals; the Anglicized Tamil word 'Trincomalee' denotes the meaning lord of the sacred hill. Optional: Trincomalee, the most popular east coast seaside hamlet in Sri Lanka famous for its powdery sandy beach and turquoise blue shallow waters. During the months from July to September calm seas provide the best opportunities to go to deep waters to see these marine giants, Blue Whales of Sri Lanka. You will see Blue Whales in the East coast of Sri Lanka by sailing to their resident colonies. Whale watching boat trip off the coast of Trincomalee will last for 4 to 5 hours. The speed boat leaves the shore of Trincomalee by 6.30 AM and mineral water bottles will be provided complimentary. Location : Trincomalee Hotel : Breakfast & Dinner

Trincomalee : In the morning you travel by boat to Pigeon Island Marine National Park. It is fantastic place for snorkelling to see the spectacular marine life with over 100 species of colourful corals teeming with 300 types of reef fish. This Pigeon Island National Park has one of the best remaining coral reefs with high live coral cover in the country and is an ideal location for scuba diving and snorkelling. Pigeon Island National Park consists of two small islands off the east coast north of Trincomalee. The island gets its name from Blue Rock Pigeon, a native endangered bird that lives within the rocks in these islands. The islands were declared a sanctuary in 1963 for the purpose of protecting these birds. In 2003 this area was upgraded to the status of a National Park and the boundaries were extended to include coral reef around them. The islands are situated about 1 km off the Nilaveli coast in Trincomalee District. Location : Trincomalee Hotel : Breakfast & Dinner

Trincomalee > Anuradhapura : After breakfast s you will travel to Anuradhapura. Travel time is approximately 2 ½ hours. You will take a bicycle tour to The Sacred City of Anuradhapura. Anuradhapura stands equal to Pyramids at Giza on the architectural level during their time. This magical place with enormous Dagobas, palaces, monasteries and monuments evidence one of the greatest civilisations in the world. The Sacred city of Anuradhapura was first Royal Kingdom and capital of Sri Lanka that lasted for 1,500 years until it was abandoned after the invasion by South Indian Cholas in 993. Today Anuradhapura is one of the world’s major archaeological sites in the world. It is covered area about 40 km² and an UNESCO World Heritage Site. This sacred city was established around a cutting from the 'tree of enlightenment', the Buddha's fig tree, brought there in the 3rd century B.C. by Sanghamitta, the founder of an order of Buddhist nuns. The ruined city hidden away in dense jungle for many years brought to life by The British in the nineteenth century. Location :Anuradhapura Hotel : Breakfast & Dinner

Anuradhapura > Negambo : In the morning you will travel to Wilpattu National Park. Travel time is approximately an hour. You will take a safari to discover Wilpattu National Park. Wilpattu National Park (‘Land of Lakes’) is situated in the Northwest coast near the ancient city of Anuradhapura. It is the largest and oldest National park in Sri Lanka consisting 140,000 hectares of mostly dry zone evergreen forest cover and coastal belt to the West. This is one of best places see leopards in Sri Lanka alongside Yala National Park. The open grassy plains set within the thick dense scrub jungle. The wetland includes around 48 shallow natural lakes known as Villus, natural basins that are filled up with rainwater and two salt water lakes. These natural lakes are the most important parts of the complex eco-system in the park. The park is home to elusive Leopards, elephants, Sloth bears, Water Buffalos, Mugger Crocodiles, Spotted and Barking Deer, Wild Boar and Pythons. Alongside these wild animals you will be able to see many endemic birds include the Ceylon Jungle fowl, Brown-capped Babbler, Ceylon Wood shrike and Black-capped Bulbul in riverine habitats. Butterflies recorded include the Great Egg fly, Great Orange Tip, Glad-eye Bush brown, Blue Mormon, Common Mormon, Common Rose and Crimson Rose. As well diverse varieties of colourful butterflies can be seen in the park as well. You will see the wild animals particularly elephants near lakes in the early morning and late afternoons. The wild life id abundant around lakes and coastal belt such as White Ibis, Open Bills, Painted Storks Spoonbills, Egrets, Whistling Teals, Kingfishers and you can also see the water buffalos, monitors and crocodiles. Afterwards you will travel to Negombo. Travel time is approximately 3 ½ hours. Location : Negambo Hotel : Bed & Breakfast
Negombo > Airport. Today you will travel to the airport and travel time will be approximately 30 minutes. Departure to your destiation.

tourName: Sri Lanka family holiday
placesVisited: Colombo, Negombo, Wilpattu National Park, Sigiriya, Dambulla Cave Temple, Polonnaruwa, Kandy, Temple of the Tooth, Knuckle Ranges and tea plantations, Trincomalee, Galle
generalInfo:
This two week Sri Lanka family holiday offers families a rich and varied range of activities, excursions and things to do all within a relatively short distance of each other which cuts down on travel time and the ‘are we there yets?’ Opportunities to rest, relax and enjoy the scenery come thick and fast on this tailor made trip, with everything from waterfalls and tea plantations to beaches and rainforests providing an exotic backdrop from where to search for wild animals and fabulous photographs. Cultural sites are just as fascinating and beautiful as their natural equivalents with the statues at Sigiriya, the ancient ruins of Polonnaruwa and numerous remote jungle villages bound to inspire the imaginations of young Lara Crofts and Indiana Joneses.

Thanks to a customisable itinerary this family holiday puts you in the driving seat with giant Buddha statues and hidden caves one day followed by river camps and hot coal dances the next. This style of trip will appeal to families who like to be flexible and depending on the age range of your children, we can help you organise a unique and really special tour that everyone will remember long after the tans have faded.

The south coast, for instance, is ideal for families who prefer beach time within quieter districts with white sands and whale watching the perfect recipe for a day well spent. Alternatively, hiking deep into the Knuckles mountain range and spending nights in remote mountain villages may well appeal to other families who love the thought of plotting their own path and distances leading to waterfalls, paddy fields and those all important mountain views.

No matter what you’re looking for from this family holiday in Sri Lanka one thing is for sure enjoying some cool down time in the converted small boutique hotels amongst the highland tea plantations is a real joy and there’s nothing better than a Sri Lankan welcome to make you all feel right at home. Sri Lankans love children and you’ll find the smiles grow if you’ve got kids in tow, with stall holders, hoteliers and local people falling over themselves to ensure you and your family are made to feel well and truly welcome.

dayInfo.description: COLOMBO - NEGOMBO When you arrive at the airport in Colombo you will be met by one of our representatives and transferred to your hotel. The rest of the day is free for you to relax and unwind.

NEGOMBO This morning you take a boat ride in the Muthurajawela Nature Reserve. This huge area covers 7,000 hectares and is located within the tropical wetlands between Colombo and Negombo. The area is gorgeous, with endless small water channels, thick mangrove forest, swaying palm trees and abundance of birds and butterflies. You may be able to spot herons, storks, waders and brilliantly coloured kingfishers. The children will enjoy keeping their eyes peeled for larger animals including monitor lizards and an occasional python and crocodile. The afternoon is free for you to relax.

NEGOMBO - WILPATTU NATIONAL PARK You will have a free morning at the Horathapola. Later drive to Wilpattu where you will spend the night in a tented camp. Children will love sleeping beneath the stars.

WILPATTU Today you will have a full day jeep safari in the Wilpattu National Park. This is the largest in Sri Lanka and is spread across a large area that is home to more than 50 natural lakes. These prove a magnet for wildlife and the park is home to a significant leopard population although exact numbers are not known. There are also a wide range of other animals including wild elephant, sloth bear and a variety of deer.

WILPATTU - SIGIRIYA Head through picturesque countryside of coconut plantations and lush green paddy fields, en route the ‘cultural triangle’. In the afternoon you will visit Sigiriya, a huge rock fortress built in the 5th century on top of an enormous, sheer sided rock. It is quite a steep climb up to the top but the views are immense and you can stop along the way at the ‘open air art gallery’ where beautiful frescoes adorn the sides of the rock. There are also extensive ruined gardens around the base of the rock so make sure that you allow time to wander around these to get a real sense of the scale of the palace.

DAMBULLA After breakfast join pilgrims in Dambulla to climb up to a vast series of caves covered in brightly coloured frescoes and statues of Buddha and his disciples that date back more than 2,000 years. This is a UNESCO world heritage site and is very impressive. Along the way you will see a large number of playful monkeys that live in and around the temple; a fantastic photo opportunity. The rest of the day is your own to relax and unwind.

POLONARRUWA - MINNERIYA This morning you visit the magnificent remains of Sri Lanka’s medieval capital at Polonnaruwa. The ruins are quite extensive and include a number of exquisite temples, giant Buddhist carvings and huge lakes which formed the basis of a remarkable irrigation system. In the afternoon you will take a safari in Minneriya National Park. The park is famous for its large herds of wild elephants as well as deer, wild boar, water buffalo and jackals. This is one of the best places in Asia to see wild elephants and you can get remarkably close to large numbers of the animals; the herds are sometimes 150-200 strong.

TRINCOMALEE Drive to Trincomalee, a bustling town in the North East of Sri Lanka which has been off limits for many years but has recently opened up to tourism again. You will stay just outside the town on the beach. You will visit the Fort Fredrick, first built by the Portuguese to protect this valuable deep water port, and also the colourful Koneswaram Temple.

TRINCOMALEE - ELKADUWA After breakfast you will drive to the edge of the Knuckles Ranges where you will stay for two nights in a 1930s tea planter’s bungalow with incredible views. The estate covers an area of around 98 acres, most of it used to grow tea although there are also a number of cows and a small pepper plantation. The area around the estate is lovely and if you are feeling active you can follow peaceful trails through the tea fields, down to a waterfall at the base of the valley where you ca swim. Alternatively you can just relax by the swimming pool and enjoy the views over the Knuckles Ranges. If you prefer, you can keep the day free to laze by the pool, take part in a cookery demonstration or wander down to the local village, explore the temple and meet the locals.

ELKADUWA You have a full free day to relax and enjoy the beautiful views or to head out exploring the estate. The children will love swimming in the pool at the base of the waterfall on the estate, getting a ‘power shower’ from the cascade.

KNUCKLE RANGES - KANDY After breakfast you will depart for Kandy. You will visit The Temple of the Tooth, which is believed to hold one of Buddha’s teeth and is one of the most important Buddhist pilgrimage sites in the world and will also head to the Royal Botanical Gardens. These are some of the most extensive in Asia with more than 5000 different species of flora and the area is essentially a huge and extremely beautiful park. This is a great place to just wander at will. In the evening you will see a cultural performance of traditional Kandyan dancing and devotional fire walking. It is fascinating to watch as hot coals are brought out and laid on the stage before the dancers walk briskly over them. Afterwards, drive on to Negombo, for a final day at this friendly fishing town.

KANDY - NEGOMBO This morning rise with the sun for a hike in the Udawattakella Nature Reserve which encompasses the sacred woods bordering the Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic in Kandy. This is an interesting sanctuary and the lush and relatively untouched rainforest provides a haven for birds and monkeys.
NEGOMBO Time to say goodbye to Sri Lanka and head home.

tourName: Sri Lanka Family Holidays
placesVisited: 6 World Heritage Sites, Negombo, Galle, Elephant Orphanage, Ella, Horton Plains National Park, Hike to World’s End, Kithulgala River Rafting, Local Train Ride, Kandy, Dambulla, Minneriya Elephant Gathering, Sigiriya, Polonnaruwa, Nilaveli, Wilpattu Jeep Safari, National Park Camp
generalInfo:
A 2 week, escorted but private Sri Lanka family tour. Rich culture, history, flora and fauna, varied landscapes and a range of activities - plus of course, wonderful curries and super-friendly locals - make Sri Lanka the perfect family holiday destination.

This highly varied, exciting family tour of Sri Lanka takes in 6 of the island’s 8 World Heritage Sites as well as some of its lesser-known highlights while maintaining a leisurely pace with plenty of time to just relax and take in the views or do your own thing. Destinations include the historic towns of Galle, Kandy and Trincomalee, the picturesque Hill Country, the ancient Cultural Triangle sites of Sigiriya, Polonnaruwa and Dambulla, Nilaveli’s unspoilt coastline and the National Parks of Wilpattu, Horton Plains and Minneriya.

Among activities along the way are; a jeep safari in Wilpattu, a hike to ‘World’s End’, a scenic local train through the Hill Country, bicycle tour of Anuradhapura ancient city, an exciting rafting expedition down the jungle-lined Kelani River, snorkelling and whale-watching options from a Nilaveli beach resort. Last but not least, is Minneriya’s awe-inspiring ‘Elephant Gathering’ where huge herds spectacularly congregate around the area’s last watering hole.

A perfect introduction to this magnificent island and a wonderful experience for all the family.

Features:

1. Our Sri Lanka tour includes no less than 6 UNESCO-listed World Heritage Sites
2. The spectacular Botanical Gardens and prestigious Temple of the Tooth in Kandy
3. Cycling tour of the ancient ruined capital of Polonnaruwa
4. Jeep safari and overnight camp in Wilpattu National Park
5. Nilaveli beach stay including whale watching and snorkelling trip options
6. Sample the fantastic local cuisine and meet the super-friendly residents

Optional extensions

1. Spend a few days quality island time at a well-appointed Maldives eco-resort
2. Hidden Maldives - discover the local life, culture, food and unique island capital Malé, join a marine conservation project and explore its fabulous reefs and turquoise seas

Note; this is a private family tour for a minimum of 4 persons and includes certain meals (local-style) and accommodation in 3 to 4* hotels.

dayInfo.description: Arrival in Colombo and transfer to the nearby port and beach town of Negombo for some relaxation time after your flight before a local-style welcome dinner introduces you to the Island's justifiably famous cuisine.

Optional early morning tour of Negombo's lively fish market before a short tour of some of the sites of nearby Colombo including the National Museum and some of the city's fine colonial period buildings. After a local-style lunch in the capital, we’ll continue south to the famous walled city of Galle for a late afternoon walking tour of the ramparts of the old Dutch fortress built on a rock jutting into the Indian Ocean.

Some free time in the morning to explore the UNESCO World Heritage town and check-out the narrow lanes of the old Moorish Quarter. Late morning departure for Udawalawe for a visit to the famous Transit Home (elephant rehabilitation centre) before continuing into the hill country and the mountain town of Ella. Time permitting, we can visit the mountain railway's famous ‘Nine Arch Bridge’ and/or take a sunset hike to Little Adam’s Peak.

An early start for a hike across the Horton Plains National Park to the famous, and aptly named, World’s End where the plains abruptly drop over 1,000 metres to lush forests below. Opportunities to discover the region’s fantastic flora and fauna and take in the beautiful Baker’s Falls with a short afternoon drive to Kithulgala and a stay at a riverside jungle lodge.

Morning jungle hike to explore Kithulgala’s lush Kelanivally rainforest area as well as a visit to a local village with an afternoon rafting trip down the picturesque Kelani River, (the actual filming location for the old Bridge on the River Kwai movie).

Back into the hill country with a morning visit to one of the area’s celebrated tea plantations before a departure by local train for a picturesque ride through the hills to Kandy, the country’s second city and capital of the hill country. Afternoon arrival in Kandy where you’ll have the chance to actually learn some local-style, traditional dance and drumming with one of Kandy's celebrated dance troops!

In the morning, experience the Buddhist puja (blessing ceremony) at the famous and highly prestigious Temple of the Tooth, which houses Sri Lanka’s most revered religious relic - one of Buddha’s teeth. After a local-style lunch in town, we’ll head out to the beautiful Peradeniya Botanic Gardens.

Time to head north to discover the UNESCO World Heritage site of Dambulla - whose cave temples date to the 1st century BC. In the afternoon we’ll take a jeep safari in Minneriya National Park where we can see elephants, langurs and a spectacular array of Sri Lankan birdlife. During the July to October period, we may be lucky enough to see the 'Gathering', where herds of hundreds of elephants congregate around Minneriya Lake.

Early morning ascent of the dramatic rock fortress of Sigiriya. This ancient site is built atop a sheer-sided rock outcrop, and we’ll take in the amazing Maidens of the Clouds on our way up the summit for some equally amazing views of the surrounding countryside. Another World Heritage Site is on the afternoon’s menu with a cycling (or tuk-tuk) tour of the historic temples and exquisitely carved statues of the ancient capital of Polonnaruwa.

Today we’ll travel north to the coastal town and ancient port of Trincomalee. Our tour will include China Bay, the old Dutch Fort Frederik, and the town’s lively bazaar, before continuing a short distance up the coast to the beach-side town of Nilaveli for accommodation in a small resort looking onto the Indian Ocean.

A day at leisure in this charming spot. Laze on the magnificent beach or explore the local area. More adventurous options include whale watching, (sperm and blue whales are regularly sighted off the coast), a snorkelling trip on the colourful reef around Pigeon Island, or even scuba diving.
Late morning departure to Wilpattu National Park - Sri Lanka’s largest, yet one of its least visited national parks or a late afternoon jeep safari and overnight stay in a comfortable tented camp.
An optional early morning safari in the park is also on offer before breakfast at the camp and a leisurely return drive south to Negombo Town. Free time in the afternoon before our farewell dinner.
Morning at leisure in Negombo. Relax by the pool; a last dip in the Indian Ocean, or pick up some last-minute souvenirs and departure at your convenience.

tourName: Sri Lanka family tour, Christmas departure
generalInfo:
Looking for ancient ruins and jungle safaris to golden beaches and scenic train rides, local flavour, and memories that’ll last a lifetime! This Sri Lanka Family Adventure is for you!

Inclusions:

- A bilingual, epic Adventure Leader throughout the entire trip
- All transport within Sri Lanka
- Accommodation (hotels)
- Meals provided: 9 breakfasts & 1 lunches

Included activities:

Negombo to visit ‘Lellama’ – the local fish market
Cycle tour of Polonnaruwa – Sri Lanka’s second-oldest kingdom and a UNESCO World Heritage Site
Dambulla Cave Temple visit
Safari around Minneriya National Park
Guided tour of Sri Lanka’s hill country – Kandy, including Temple of the Tooth visit
Journey on ‘The Most Beautiful Train Ride in the World’
Little Adam’s Peak hike
Guided tour of Handunugoda Tea Estate
Galle Fort walking tour

dayInfo.description: Colombo-Negombo: Ayubowan – and welcome to Sri Lanka! After landing in Colombo, your journey begins with a short transfer to the relaxed coastal town of Negombo, just 20 minutes from the airport. This first afternoon is all about settling in – whether that means unwinding by the pool, dipping your toes in the Indian Ocean, or taking a gentle stroll along the beach. Come evening, why not dive straight into Sri Lankan flavours? Try a traditional curry and rice, or sample Kottu – a sizzling street food dish made with chopped roti, vegetables, and plenty of spice. It’s a local favourite for a reason! You’ll also meet your Adventure Leader and fellow travellers for a welcome briefing, where we’ll walk you through the trip, go over safety info, and get you excited for the journey ahead. For now, take it slow, shake off the jet lag, and enjoy this laid-back start to your Sri Lankan adventure.

Negombo-Habarana: After breakfast, we’ll kick off day two of your Sri Lanka family adventure with a visit to the famous Negombo fish market, known locally as ‘Lellama’. Set right on the beach, this lively market is the hub of the local fishing community. Watch as fishermen haul in their morning catch, experience the fast-paced auction atmosphere, and get a glimpse of everyday life in coastal Sri Lanka. From here, we hit the road and make our way to Habarana – a peaceful rural village surrounded by lush greenery, lakes, and rice paddies (approx. 3.5 hours). On arrival, we’ll jump straight into an immersive village experience. You’ll hop aboard a traditional farm tractor, paddle across a scenic lake in a canoe, wander through the fields, and meet the locals who call this beautiful place home. After all that exploring, we’ll settle in for a well-earned, home-cooked lunch. Made from fresh, local ingredients using traditional techniques, you’ll get to see (and taste) how Sri Lankan meals are lovingly prepared – just as they have been for generations.

Polonnaruwa: After breakfast, the morning is yours to enjoy at your own pace. If you're feeling adventurous, you can opt for a visit to one of Sri Lanka’s most iconic landmarks: Sigiriya. This ancient rock fortress, built by King Kashyapa in the 5th century, rises dramatically from the jungle and rewards climbers with incredible panoramic views and a glimpse into Sri Lanka’s royal past. Travelling with little ones or just after a gentler climb? Pidurangala Rock, right next door, offers a quieter route with equally impressive scenery – and fewer steps. Later in the afternoon, we’ll come together and head to the ancient city of Polonnaruwa – Sri Lanka’s second-oldest kingdom and a UNESCO World Heritage Site. We’ll explore the ruins by bike, weaving through centuries-old temples, palaces, and sacred statues that tell the story of a once-glorious royal capital. After a big day of discovery, we’ll make the one-hour journey back to the hotel to unwind, relax, and gear up for the next leg of the journey.

Dambulla Cave Temple: We’ll start the day with a visit to the awe-inspiring Dambulla Cave Temple – one of Sri Lanka’s most impressive UNESCO World Heritage sites. Tucked into a towering rock face, this ancient cave complex is filled with over 150 Buddha statues and vibrant murals, offering a fascinating glimpse into more than two millennia of spiritual history. After exploring the caves, it’s time to take things slow with a relaxing break back at the hotel. Whether you fancy a swim, a quiet moment with a book, or a quick power nap, the midday hours are yours to enjoy at your own pace. In the late afternoon, get ready for a real adventure as we head out on safari in Minneriya National Park. Known for its large herds of wild elephants, the park is also home to deer, crocodiles, and an incredible variety of birdlife. Keep your eyes open – you never know what you might spot! The evening is free for you to unwind however you like, ready for another great day ahead.

Kandy: After breakfast, we’ll set off on a scenic 2.5-hour drive to Kandy – Sri Lanka’s cultural heart and hill capital. Nestled among lush green hills, Kandy is a vibrant mix of tradition and modern life. This afternoon, we’ll dive into it all with a guided tour of the city. Wander through bustling local markets, enjoy a peaceful walk along the lakefront, and explore one of the country’s most revered sites: the Temple of the Tooth. Once the royal residence of ancient kings, this sacred temple now houses a relic believed to be the tooth of Lord Buddha – making it one of the most important religious sites in Sri Lanka.

Kandy-Ella: After breakfast, we’ll begin a scenic journey up into Sri Lanka’s lush highlands, making our way toward the picturesque town of Ella. The drive takes around three hours, but with sweeping views, tea plantations, and photo stops along the way, the time will fly by. One of today’s highlights is the famous train ride to Ella – a true bucket-list experience. Considered one of the most beautiful train journeys in the world, this ride winds through rolling hills, misty forests, and quiet rural villages, offering a front-row seat to the breathtaking landscapes of the hill country. Train travel in Sri Lanka can be unpredictable, with seasonal timetable changes and occasional delays or cancellations, particularly in the tourist carriages. We’ll do everything we can to secure seats and confirm availability in advance, but a little flexibility might be needed on the day. By late afternoon, we’ll arrive in Ella – a chilled-out mountain town known for its cool climate, hiking trails, and welcoming atmosphere. Spend the evening as you like: take a walk through town, try some local food, or relax and soak up the fresh mountain air.

Ella-Hikkaduwa: Day 7 of your Sri Lanka family tour begins bright and early with a rewarding hike up Little Adam’s Peak. This gentle trail is great for all ages and offers incredible panoramic views over Ella’s rolling hills and valleys – a picture-perfect moment to capture with the family. After breakfast back at the hotel, we’ll begin our journey down to the south coast, with a key stop along the way: Handunugoda Tea Estate. No trip to Sri Lanka is complete without diving into its tea heritage, and this family-owned estate offers a fascinating insight into how tea goes from leaf to cup. We’ll walk through the lush tea fields, tour the working factory and museum, and learn all about the production process. As a bonus, the estate also grows cinnamon, coconut, and rubber – giving you a full flavour of southern Sri Lanka’s agricultural life. By late afternoon, we’ll reach the coastal town of Hikkaduwa – your new home by the sea. With golden beaches, chilled cafés, gentle waves, and a coral-rich bay full of marine life, it’s the perfect place to relax and recharge after your time in the highlands.

Hikkaduwa: After a few adventure-filled days, it’s time to slow things down and enjoy the best of Sri Lanka’s beautiful coastline. Today is all about beach vibes, sea breezes, and soaking up some well-deserved rest and relaxation in Hikkaduwa. Whether you’re lounging under a palm tree with a fresh coconut, paddling in the warm waves, or grazing your way through beachfront cafés, this laid-back surf town is the perfect spot for some quality family downtime. But if you're not quite ready to hit full chill mode – no problem! Hikkaduwa is packed with activities to keep the energy going. Think surf lessons, snorkelling trips, glass-bottom boat rides, and even scuba diving for the adventurous. Just have a chat with your Adventure Leader – we’ll need around 24 hours’ notice to get you booked in. \*Want more details? Reach out to our team for full activity pricing and availability.

Galle & Hikkaduwa: This morning (or afternoon – we’ll go with the group flow), we’ll set off on a walking tour of the iconic Galle Fort, one of Sri Lanka’s most charming UNESCO World Heritage Sites. Picture cobbled streets, ocean views, and a unique blend of colonial history and laid-back island life. Originally built by the Portuguese in the 16th century, Galle Fort is a fascinating fusion of European architecture and South Asian flair. As you wander past centuries-old ramparts, the lighthouse, the clock tower, and colonial churches, you’ll also find trendy cafés, art galleries, boutique shops, and beautifully restored villas. It’s a perfect mix of old-world charm and modern-day cool. The rest of the day is yours to enjoy back in Hikkaduwa – whether that’s hitting the beach one last time, squeezing in a scuba dive, or tucking into some incredible seafood. And now, for the grand finale – exclusive to this tour date! It’s New Year’s Eve, and we’re going big. Expect a night to remember, with a celebratory dinner, fireworks on the beach, and plenty of fun for the whole family. It’s the perfect way to ring in the New Year in style!

Colombo: Sadly, today marks the end of your Sri Lanka family adventure. After breakfast, we’ll transfer you back to Colombo Airport (approx. 2-hour drive), where it’s time for final goodbyes and one last group hug. If you’re not quite ready to leave paradise (and we don’t blame you!), let us know – we’d be happy to help arrange post-trip accommodation or onward travel plans. Thanks for joining us on this incredible journey – we hope it’s been an unforgettable experience for the whole family!

tourName: Sri Lanka family tour
generalInfo:
Negombo - Sigiriya - Trincomalee/Arugam Bay - Kandy - Ella - Yala - Colombo:

We’ve made cruising across Sri Lanka even more affordable with our “shoe-string” family trip. If you are an adventurous bunch, enjoy plenty of free time and don’t mind being in charge of your own entertainment, this exciting itinerary might be just the perfect match for you! With private point-to-point transfers and our selection of family-friendly hotels combined, you won’t need to worry about the logistics or missing out any highlights. During this trip, you will explore quaint streets of Negombo, climb up the Lion’s Rock in Sigiriya, admire spectacular views in Ella and (hopefully) spot wildlife in Yala. Top it up with a blissful beach stay, and your whole family will fall in love with stunning Sri Lanka in no time!

dayInfo.description: Fishing Boats in Negombo: Negombo is the perfect starting point for your family trip to Sri Lanka. Just up the road from Colombo, it has a lot to offer, and you’ll get to experience the fisherman’s way of life! Amble along the Dutch canals, explore colourful stalls at the fish markets or wander through the quaint streets of this charming colonial town – you are completely in charge of your own time. Your guesthouse is within walking distance of the beach and local restaurants, so you could take a gentle stroll or hop in a tuk-tuk to explore the town. Next, you’ll travel from Negombo towards Sigiriya by private car. Your journey will take around 4 hours.

Rock Up to the Lion Fortress: Today you’ll travel to Sigiriya. We have found a charming hotel with fantastic countryside views and only a few miles away from the giant Sigiriya Rock. After checking in, have a refreshing dip in the pool and enjoy the views around! The next day you’ll be climbing up to the top of Lion Rock and it’s a fun walk up as you’ll pass cheeky monkeys, countless frescoes, and Buddha images. Once you’ve made it to the top, you’ll be glad you put in the effort, as the panoramic view of the emerald green jungle below is truly remarkable! Next, you will venture off to the blissful East Coast. Journey to Trincomalee will take around 2.5 hours.

Sea Shells on Coral Islands: The east coast is the best place weather-wise for a beach stay in Sri Lanka during the summer school holiday months. The sandy beaches are long, wide and it’s the perfect place to unwind for a few days. You’ll be staying in resort by the beach, with a nice swimming pool. The time here is free, but if you want do add a little adventure to your otherwise relaxing stay, why not visit the nearby Pigeon Island for some first-class snorkelling?

Experience Local Life in Kandy: Over the next few days, you’ll stay in the heart of Kandy. There is a lot to see and do in the city and your location is perfect for exploring the main attractions on foot, see the highlights and marvel at the Temple of the Tooth. For a real cultural immersion, we recommend getting to the temple in time for the evening pooja ceremony! And if you and your family feel slightly overwhelmed with the city buzz, the Royal Botanical Gardens are pretty spectacular and only a couple of miles away from the city centre – a perfect escape. Today, you will make your way to the local train station to get your tickets to Ella and hop on one of the most spectacular train rides through the green hills and right into the heart of the Hill Country – a true local experience! The journey takes around 5 hours and although it gets crowded on the train, you will be rewarded with spectacular views of the countryside. If you’d rather travel by car, please let us know and we can arrange it for you instead.

Hike Through the Hills of Ella: Ella is a small laid-back village located in-between tea plantations amidst the mountains. You and your family will have plenty of time to take in the beauty of this area. Your hotel is located high in the hills, offering a stunning view for you all to look out on. Whilst you’re here you have the chance to explore the hill-country at your own pace; take a walk around the countryside, have a picnic with a view or take the Little Adam’s Peak hike. Today, you will head to Yala National Park in a private car. The journey will take about 3.5 hours.

Wildlife Encounters in Yala: Elephants, monkeys, crocodiles and maybe even a leopard or black bear – this the part of Sri Lanka which the kids will be most excited about. Welcome to Yala National Park! You’ll spend the night in a simple but comfortable hotel not far from the park, with the noises of nature all around you. You’ll set off on a jeep safari with a local guide to seek out some of the country’s most famous residents. It’s an experience the whole family will remember forever. Today you will leave Yala behind and go back to Colombo for one more night in Sri Lanka. The journey will take about 6 hours.

Colombo's Tuk-tuks and Temples: OK, so maybe Colombo isn’t the place you’re most excited about in Sri Lanka, but the country’s capital has plenty to offer and is a real eye-opener for kids to see daily life in a big working city. Hustle, bustle and honking horns fill the streets, and if you’re after a little culture-shock then it’s a great place to spend a night….the food is amazing too! At the end of your trip, we’ll arrange a transfer to collect you from your hotel in Colombo and take you to the airport ready for your international flight home.

tourName: Sri Lanka family tours
generalInfo:
Embark on an unforgettable family holiday that immerses you in Sri Lanka’s vibrant nature, rich wildlife, and local traditions. This journey is designed for both learning and adventure, making it a perfect blend of fun and discovery for the whole family. Begin in the heart of Sri Lanka's Cultural Triangle, home to ancient cities and two of the country's largest national parks. Experience the thrill of encountering wild elephants on safari, delve into Sri Lanka’s history in the ancient city of Polonnaruwa, and enjoy a unique opportunity to observe and learn about the local monkey populations with expert guidance.

Next, venture to the tranquil east coast, a region once off-limits but now flourishing with warm hospitality and cultural diversity. Here, you’ll step away from the typical tourist path and connect with local families, share in their daily lives, try your hand at traditional fishing, and enjoy a homemade meal with your gracious hosts.

On your return journey, you'll visit Udawalawe National Park, renowned for its large elephant herds, before arriving in the historic city of Galle. Galle’s impressive colonial fort, built by the Portuguese and later fortified by the Dutch, showcases the island’s colonial past and its enduring blend of cultures, religions, and ethnicities.

Throughout your journey, we aim to showcase the beauty and diversity of Sri Lanka, leaving you with cherished memories and a deeper understanding of this incredible island.

dayInfo.description: Airport to Habarana: On arrival, we will meet you at the airport and drive to Habarana (3.5hrs). Spend some time to relax after your flight. Explore the grounds and listen to the bird calls. Accommodation: The Other Corner or Similar

Safari at Minneriya: With information about the elephants from the locals, we can decide to go on a morning or afternoon Safari at the nearby Minneriya or Kaudulla National Park. The ‘Gathering’, the largest concentration of Elephants in Asia, happens when over 300 gather on the grassland that sprouts on the receding shores of Minneriya Lake. The Gathering at Minneriya is now ranked sixth amongst the world’s greatest wildlife spectacles by Lonely Planet and occurs every year from around June to October, with numbers peaking from August onwards. During the onset of the North-east monsoon in Ocotber, which signals the onset of the wet season, the elephants disperse to the surrounding jungles and at Hurulla Eco Park close to Habarana, anywhere up to about 50 – 75 elephants maybe seen during the late afternoons.. Accommodation: The Other Corner or Similar

Polonnaruwa: Today we take a trip to Polonnaruwa. A historical capital of ancient Sri Lanka. We can explore the ruins on bicycles. Post lunch we can visit the Smithsonian Primate Centre. Walking around the site, you’ll see how many monkeys have made their homes within the ruins. Your host will guide you around a small area of the complex, where you will be able to stand just meters away from large groups of toque macaques and grey. Your host will take you on a walk to follow the monkeys on foot and learn about monkey behaviours and the various challenges of monkey conservation. Accommodation: The Other Corner or Similar

Kalkudah: Today we head to the scenic eastern coast of Sri Lanka. The beaches on the East Coast are ideal from May to September. With the sea being very calm. Accommodation: Giman Free Beach or Similar

Fish and Cook: Today we spend the whole day out learning how to fish and cook the local style. We will learn good recipes of delicious curries to bring back home and get in touch with local fishermen willing to share their ancestral way of fishing with you. After a visit to the market, you will reach the family that will teach you Sri Lankan cooking, take your lunch with them, and after a relaxing chat, have a ride along our enchanting lagoon before meeting the fishermen on the lagoon for a refreshing fishing class. Accommodation: Giman Free Beach or Similar
Whale Watching or Snorkeling: Today is an optional day to explore the sea! We can go either whale watching or snorkelling. Accommodation: Giman Free Beach or Similar

Arugam Bay: Arugam Bay is mostly known as surfing destination however what most people don’t know is the amazing wilderness inland. We spend the next 2 days on nature walks through the jungles and around the tanks. Accommodation: Kudakaliya or Similar

Udawalawe: Today we take the scenic drive to Udawalawe. Udawalawe National Park lies on the boundary of Sabaragamuwa and Uva Provinces in SriLanka. The national park is home to a variety of wildlife including herds of elephants, wild buffalo, sambar, spotted deer, grey langurs and peacocks. Accommodation: Nature House Homestay or Similar Meal Plan: Dinner and Breakfast

Galle: We begin the day with a Safari in the Park. Keep your eyes open for elephants, numerous birds, crocodiles and bison. After the safari, we head to beautiful Galle. The 17th century Dutch Fort town is a UNESCO heritage site. Galle is an interesting mix religion, cultures and ethnicities. Once settled in we can spend the evening exploring the fort and catching the sunset from the ramparts. Accommodation: Fort Bliss Galle or Similar

Artists at Galle: Hosted in the residence of a local school teacher in Galle, the DIY experience is designed to engage kids through creative work whether it’s arts or crafts and help them explore their imagination while on holiday so that their parents can have some much needed time off. Accommodation: Fort Bliss Galle or Similar

tourName: Sri Lanka Grand Tour
generalInfo:
Welcome to our unique 14-day Grand Tour of amazing and wild Sri Lanka.

Sri Lanka offers something for everyone. This two-week Sri Lanka holiday is tailor-made for you by your local guide Rajiv who has been working with tourists for the past 20 years and has an immense knowledge of his 'teardrop' island he calls home together with his wife Gillian. Rajiv has included both touristy activities and off the beaten track locations.

Sri Lanka is a paradise that we proudly call the Pearl of the Indian Ocean. Its golden sandy beaches, majestic rainforest-covered mountains, cascading waterfalls, UNESCO heritage sites, sacred rock temples, tea plantations, and ancient royal cities offer something for everyone including the amazing local food.

On your arrival in Sri Lanka, you will be met by your local team Gillian and Rajiv. We are both passionate about travel and local food and this makes us the best local team to travel with during your holiday.

Our customized and bespoke tours give you the chance to encounter herds of wild elephants, the elusive leopards, and endangered sloth bears of Sri Lanka including hundreds of bird species in the company of a local guide or ranger.

The Sri Lanka Grand Tour Holiday includes Colombo, Kandy, Nuwara Eliya, UNESCO World Heritage Sites, national parks, beautiful beaches, and some of the key ancient cities that make up Sri Lanka's Cultural Triangle.

We have designed this holiday for you from start to end with one key element in mind which is peace of mind.

One key element which must be considered when visiting Sri Lanka on holiday is the tropical weather. We have planned this holiday so that you will enjoy bright sunshine and blue skies especially when at the beach.

We as responsible and honest travel agents recommend this holiday between November and April to minimize the chance of rain especially when you are relaxing at the beach.

Anyone can visit Sri Lanka, but not everyone gets the chance to chat over dinner or travel together with a local host, take a safari at dawn with a knowledgeable ranger, and get the best seats on one of the most scenic railway journeys in the world. You need a local specialist to provide you with insider information, make arrangements using local contacts, and advise on the best times of year to visit different areas.

Our family-operated company has been doing just that since 2004 and 50% of our business comes from personal referrals and repeat business. We strongly believe in responsible and sustainable tourism and are proud of the fact that 90% of your tour fee stays in Sri Lanka...

All hotels are locally owned and managed and you will be transported in the comfort of your own privet chauffeur-driven vehicle, where you sit back and enjoy a bespoke itinerary that is as unique and individual as you. All our vehicles are fully insured and driven by experienced chauffeurs.

Sri Lankan is ready for you... We look forward to hearing from you soon!

tourName: Sri Lanka guided country tour
generalInfo:
You haven't truly seen an island until you've experienced the Teardrop of India - Sri Lanka. Pack your bags and come away with us on a journey through South Asia's own Emerald Isle.

Known since antiquity from as far away as Buddhism's heartlands of Northern India, the island formerly known as Ceylon really is India without the clamour, or the hustle and bustle. Wander through a myriad of sacred dagobas and temples in the UNESCO heritage site of Anuradhapura. Climb the iconic Sigiriya Rock Fortress for panoramic views across mist-shrouded forests, as well as visiting the wonderful cave temple complex of Dambulla to find out why few belief systems are quite as organic as Buddhism.

Venture into the wilderness of Sri Lanka's national parks in search of the mystic leopard. Relive old England herself in Nuwara Eliya. Stand staring at the panoramic beauty of oblivion at the World's End. Feel the gloriously damp chill of English weather high on Horton Plains. Stare up at emerald-tinted tea plantations in Sri Lanka's highlands, and go on a Celyon tea tasting while you're at it. Savour the sweet taste of Kandy.

And to round off an unforgettable fortnight, hit the streets of cool Colombo to taste food as nature intended.

Sri Lanka is all this, and much more.

The UNESCO World Heritage site of Anuradhapura
UNESCO-listed Sigiriya Rock Fortress
Golden Temple Complex in Dambulla
Home of ancient Sri Lankan kings at Kandy
Tea plantations in the Horton Plains
Leopards in Yala National Park
Galle's Dutch-built UNESCO-listed Fort.
Colombo's thriving streetlife
Places Visited
Colombo - Anuradhapura - Minneriya National Park - Ritigala Monastery - Dambulla - Kandy - Nuwara Eliya - Horton Plains - Tissamaharama - Yala National Park - Galle Fort

dayInfo.description: Arrival into Colombo International airport, where you will be met by a Travel the Unknown representative and transferred to your hotel in Negombo, a small fishing village in the western coast. Not far from the airport, it is the ideal place to spend your first night after a long flight. Check in to your hotel and spend the rest of the evening at leisure. Take a stroll on the beach, dip in the pool or simply read a book. Overnight in Goldi Sands Hotel, Negombo Meal plan: Dinner

After breakfast, we head out to ancient Anuradhapura, the city of kings. Anuradhapura is one of Sri Lanka’s most ancient capitals, and the birthplace of Theravada Buddhism. You'll find it not only home to many ancient archaeological sites, but also an important pilgrimage site for Theravada Buddhists who flock there honour the many stupas, and other religious monuments. Highlights include a stop at what many consider to be the world's oldest documented tree, a bodhi (aka bo), brought to the island by Emperor Asoka's daughter in the 3rd century BC. Later we move on to atmospheric Kaludiya Pokuna, a dense, hilly jungle concealing 1,500 year-old ruins. Leisurely evening, and dinner at your hotel. Overnight in Rajarata Hotel, Anuradhapura Meal plan: Breakfast & dinner

En route to our destination at Habarana, we'll stop for a remarkable roadside attraction: the Avukana Buddha statue. One of best standing statues in all Sri Lanka, debate rages about the date of its construction, but it's at least 1,300 years old. After an early check-in at your villa, we'll head out on a jeep safari through Minneriya National Park, before returning to Habarana for a relaxing evening on the grounds with dinner. Overnight in Sevanagama Villa, Habarana Meal plan: Breakfast & dinner

Rising over the dry plains of the Sigiriya district is the Lion Rock. That will be our first port-of-call today, and an early start, too. The tough climb of 1200 footsteps up this flat-topped monolith ends with the most scenic bird’s-eye view of the emerald plains and leafy villages beneath. After a late morning return to Habarana to allow you to hit pause for a while after an invigorating climb, in the late afternoon we hit the trail again, this time to see first hand the Ritigala Archaeological Monastery. But arguably even better than the sight of monastery walls is the forest walk you will take down meditation pathways. Back to the villa in Habarana in the evening to rest and to dine. Overnight in Sevanagama Villa, Habarana Meal plan: Breakfast & dinner

On the way to delightful Kandy, we'll stop in at another remarkable roadside attraction: the Dambulla Cave Temple. A UNESCO world heritage site, Dambulla is considered to be the largest and best-preserved cave temple complex in the country. On arrival in Kandy, check in to your hotel where dinner will be served. The evening is at your leisure to enjoy nightfall over the Hantana hill range, just out of town. N.b. When you’re visiting Dambulla, few things to keep in mind: make sure to carry socks because shoes you wear should be left at the temple entrance down the hill. The time you decide to take the minor climb, the rocky surface can be hot under the day time sun. So, we suggest to visit early morning when the sun is milder. Overnight in Fox Resort, Kandy , Deluxe Meal plan: Breakfast & dinner

A morning being a sous-chef, and an afternoon out and about in one of the best urban spaces on the whole island. What more could you want? First off, we're going to transport ourselves to a homestay in Kandy, where the lady of the house is waiting to deliver a cookery tutorial, starting with an in-depth introduction into the Sri Lankan spices and how best to combine them to conjure the perfect curry. At the end of it all, your efforts will be rewarded with a mouth-watering lunch! In the afternoon, we'll see why Kandy was the last stronghold of Sinhalese royalty to resist British imperial power. Join in on our discovery of why the Temple of the Tooth is fundamental to Sinhalese Buddhist identity. You'll find out whose famous mouth the tooth long ago occupied, as well. Evening back at your hilltop resort. Dinner included. Overnight in Fox Resort, Kandy Meal plan: Breakfast & dinner

Our day's destination is the very British-themed Nuwara Eliya: Sri Lanka's own hill station, nestled among the trademark tea plantations of Sri Lanka's gorgeous highlands. En route to so-called 'Little England', we cannot but stop at the imposing sight of the 109m-high Ramboda Falls. If you're lucky there you might see butterflies mass through the mist-laden spray that comes off the cascades. Nuwara Eliya will entrance you with its Home Counties-style cottages, its Scottish bungalows, as well as its English village green. Its climate is even rather British. Evening at your hotel with dinner included. Overnight in St. Andrew's Hotel , Nuwara Eliya Meal plan: Breakfast & dinner

The high watershed of the entire island, Horton Plains N.P. stands at about 2,300m above sea level. After driving from our base in Nuwara Eliya, we'll do an easy trek over swathes of grassland and under cloud forest through what must be the coldest place in all Sri Lanka. Our 10km stroll (without too much elevation) ends abruptly at the World's End, a sheer drop of hundred of metres. A place of mystifying beauty, at World's End you'll feel you're at the beginning of something quite unique. Back to Nuwara Eliya before embarking on a second excursion to a tea plantation, to do a tasting and to gain an inkling into the trade that powered Britain's great empire. Back to Nuwara for an evening of relaxation and dinner at the hotel. n.b. Bring adequate clothing to Horton Plains, for the weather can be as damp and changeable as it is in Britain. Overnight in St. Andrew's Hotel , Nuwara Eliya Meal plan: Breakfast & dinner

On leaving Nuwara, our lowland destination is Tissamaharama, which abuts the undisputed queen of Sri Lanka's National Parks, Yala. Inevitably, we take the scenic route past the Ella Gap to see the plains expand below us. Afterwards, the journey continues on with a stop at the Rawana Falls, a landmark mentioned in the Hindu epic, the Ramayana. Heading downhill to our resort, it's around now that the wildlife starts to get rather interesting. Evening and dinner at your lakeside retreat in Tissamaharama. Overnight in EHKO Safari Tissa, Tissamaharama Meal plan: Breakfast & dinner

Rising pre-breakfast, we first travel into the town of Tissamaharama to get a feel for the place. We'll look on, curious, as experts demonstrate how to make 'curd', Sri Lanka signature dessert. Then it's a trip to a potter's house to see how ceramics are made. Lastly, what we've all been waiting for: an archetypal Lankan breakfast at a local house. Later in the day, we travel to Yala National Park. Home to an amazing range of wildlife, Yala boasts splendid natural sights: enormous elephants, preening peacocks, bulky black bears and lean leopards that steal away into the shadows. Not for nothing is this Sri Lanka's preeminent sanctiuary of nature as it should be. Spend the rest of the evening at your leisure in your Tissamaharama retreat, where dinner is included. Overnight in EHKO Safari Tissa, Tissamaharama Meal plan: Breakfast & dinner

From the fringes of Yala national park, we embark on a 3-hour journey down to Galle on the south coast. This historic, maritime town has been variously settled and administered by the Portuguese, the Dutch, and the British. Many others mariners, including Arab merchants, have passed through. Today it is resolutely Sri Lankan. You'll stay at Galle Fort, the most historically significant area. Its ramparts jut out into the Indian Ocean, and the promenade along the old sea walls is a place of vibrant human interaction. Let yourself be carried away by the atmosphere of the place Evening dinner and rest at your Galle Fort heritage hotel. Overnight in Yara Galle Fort, Galle Meal plan: Breakfast & dinner

A coastal drive from Galle brings us to Sri Lanka's thrumming capital, Colombo. Check in and take in your lovely new surroundings overlooking the Indian Ocean. Later in the day, get a true insider's view of the nation's biggest city. Escorted by a specialist, we'll explore the centrality of food in the socio-cultural landscape of this country. On our Colombo street food tour, we'll get an appreciation for the eclectic influences that permeate the food scene here. Try dosai, vadai, biryana, kottu roti, topped off with the ubiquitous taste of tea. A 'real' dinner among locals on the streets of Colombo, before returning to your hotel to chill. Overnight in Granbell Hotel Colombo, Colombo Meal plan: Breakfast & dinner

The penultimate day of this tour will entail a more gentle rhythm. In the morning, your guide with chauffeur you around select parts of downtown Colombo. The afternoon is yours to do as you please. Evening and dinner at your hotel. Overnight in Granbell Hotel Colombo, Colombo Meal plan: Breakfast & dinner
Round off an exhiliirating tour with a last Sri Lankan breakfast before departing for the airport to catch your flight home. Meal plan: Breakfast

tourName: Sri Lanka highlights holiday for families, 13 days
generalInfo:
This trip is ideal for families, especially those with pre-teen children, and includes all the must-see highlights of Sri Lanka. Follow elephants roaming freely in the wild, explore the rich heritage and culture of Kandy and Sigiriya Rock and watch monkeys play among ancient temples. You’ll journey through lush tea plantations, ride the famous highland train and unwind with a few relaxing days on the beach. A visit to a traditional village and a local school, both supported through our community partnerships, is often a memorable highlight for families.

To keep travel relaxed, we’ve limited the number of stops so you won’t be changing hotels every night and we’ve built in free days and optional activities for when you need some downtime. We've also chosen the beach at Pasikudah, with its calm shallow waters, golden sands and snorkelling opportunities, as it's perfect for younger children.

The holiday is designed to be full of new experiences of nature and culture, while ensuring that every moment remains engaging, relaxing, and above all... fun!

dayInfo.description: Upon arrival, meet your private chauffeur guide, who will accompany you throughout your trip. Your Sri Lankan adventure begins with a scenic 3.5–4 hour drive to the cultural heartland of Sigiriya, where you’ll experience your first taste of Sri Lankan hospitality and enjoy the rest of the day at leisure. You can also stay in Colombo for the first night.

Begin your day with a relaxing morning at the hotel, unwinding by the pool or choosing an optional visit to the UNESCO-listed Dambulla Cave Temple, famous for its ancient Buddha statues and stunning frescoes. In the afternoon enjoy a thrilling safari in Minneriya National Park, home to herds of wild elephants, before returning to the hotel for a refreshing swim and dinner (B).

After breakfast ascend the UNESCO-listed Sigiriya Rock Fortress, where you can admire ancient frescoes, water gardens and breathtaking panoramic views from the summit. Continue with a guided visit to a nearby village that works exclusively with our partners, to get a taste of authentic rural life. You'll meet local people and learn about traditional cultivation, visit a school, enjoy lunch with a family and plant a tree to help with the village’s reforestation efforts. Afternoon free at leisure (B).

Depart for the east coast with a stop at the UNESCO-listed medieval capital of Polonnaruwa, where playful temple monkeys roam amongst its well-preserved temples, colossal Buddha statues and ingenious irrigation systems. In the afternoon, continue to the tranquil beaches of Pasikudah, whose calm shallow waters and golden sands are perfect for younger children (B).

Spend a last morning relaxing on the beach with a leisurely breakfast before embarking on a scenic drive to Haputale, winding through lush tea plantations, rolling hills and picturesque villages. Nestled 1400m above sea level, Haputale offers breathtaking views, a more authentic highland experience and easy access to sights like Lipton’s Seat and Diyaluma Falls. Evening free to relax at your charming countryside accommodation (B).

Start your day with a scenic excursion to Lipton’s Seat viewpoint, perched above the Haputale tea estates, where you can savour freshly brewed Ceylon tea and learn about the region’s rich tea heritage, including a visit to the historic Dambatenne factory. In the afternoon, hike to Diyaluma Falls, Sri Lanka’s second-highest waterfall, and explore its lush jungle trails, rock pools, and endemic wildlife, with the option to reach the top for more stunning views and a natural infinity pool (B).

After breakfast, board the train to Kandy for one of the world’s most scenic journeys, passing rolling tea plantations, misty mountains, waterfalls and charming villages, with reserved seating in 2nd or 3rd class (1st class can be requested in advance). Upon arrival, your driver will transfer you to your hotel, leaving the rest of the day free to relax (B).

Start your exploration of Kandy with a calming and education visit to the Royal Botanical Gardens and Orchid House in Peradeniya, before exploring the city’s cultural highlights, including the sacred Temple of the Tooth Relic. In the evening, enjoy a traditional Kandyan dance performance with rhythmic drumming and elaborate costumes, or opt for a private performance for a more personal experience (B).

Travel to Negombo, enjoying the scenic journey through Sri Lanka’s central plains, dotted with villages, coconut groves and paddy fields, and spend your final night conveniently near the airport for a stress-free departure. Time permitting, take an optional boat tour of Negombo Lagoon to spot water birds, explore mangrove forests and observe traditional fishing methods, offering both a fascinating insight into traditional livelihoods and excellent photo opportunities (B).
Sadly all good things come to an end… today it’s time to transfer to the airport (15 mins) for your onward flight, leaving Sri Lanka with lots of amazing memories and photos! (B)

tourName: Sri Lanka highlights holiday
placesVisited: Negombo, Sigiriya, Polonnaruwa, Dambulla, Kandy, Nurwara Eliya, Ella, Yala National Park, Overnight stay in safari tents, Unawatuna beach, Galle, Colombo, Private chauffeur guide
generalInfo:
This two week, Sri Lanka holiday is a tailor made trip and so this is only our suggested itinerary, which of course we can adapt according to your interests. Although we believe it captures many of Sri Lanka’s highlights, both cultural and coastal, national parks and wildlife.
