You could pick from a few accommodation options in Galle. Couples might like Kahanda Kanda, set on its own 12-acre hilltop tea estate, a 30-minute drive inland from Galle. Nearly all of the ten exquisite suites here are freestanding (immensely private Dubu, with its own pool, is fabulous, although there are three suites with pools) and from furnished terraces enjoy views over the bird-filled tropical gardens, the tea fields and distant Koggala Lake. Dine alfresco, relax poolside, enjoy a spa treatment, take a guided bicycle ride through picture-postcard rice fields, make for the beach or privately tour the hotel’s own tea estate. Families and couples seeking beaches, restaurants and shops close by, might prefer Why House, an idyllic country-style boutique hotel with big garden, excellent restaurant and expansive swimming pool. Aside from sculpting sandcastles on one of the region’s pretty beaches, family activities include guided bicycle rides, boat trips, gentle river kayaking, seasonal whale and dolphin watching and surfing. History buffs might like to stay in the heart of Galle Fort itself, at the very stylish Fort Bazaar spa hotel. Travel time Tangalle to Galle: 1.5 hours. Stay 4 nights at Kahanda Kanda, Why House or Fort Bazaar.

BALAPITIYA: From Galle, it’s just an hour’s drive to Kumu Beach in Balapitiya, a small coastal village on Sri Lanka’s sunset coast. The hotel is located above a sandy stretch of beach edged by huge boulders, and is set in its own private palm-shaded garden with a 23-metre swimming pool. The hotel was completed in 2017, and offers 10 bedrooms, four of which are very spacious Oceanview Suites with private lounges and superb sea views. This is a lovely place to relax and unwind; the hotel has a contemporary design style, and its kitchen produces fabulous local and fusion cuisine for enjoying on the long timber deck, beside the swimming pool or anywhere in the garden. The region is a centre for Sri Lankan folk culture with mask museums nearby at Ambalangoda and a number of attractions within reach including Lunuganga, the home and garden of the late Geoffrey Bawa, and Bentota for water sports action. Travel time Galle to Balapitiya: 1 hour. Stay 3 nights at Kumu Beach.

NEGOMBO: Make your way north from Galle all the way to The Wallawwa, an 18-room boutique hotel, which is located just 15-minutes from the airport, to recuperate amidst startlingly peaceful surroundings. Set in an expansive tropical garden, this former manor house once played host to the Royal Airforce under Lord Mountbatten during World War Two. Guests are indulged with its chic collection of guestrooms, its gourmet cuisine, its discreet service and its decadent spa. Be on the beach in 20 minutes, play a round of croquet in the garden or take a private guided tour by boat or kayak through the pretty bird-filled Muthurajawela Wetlands. Colombo’s restaurants, shops and sights are a mere 30-40 minutes’ drive away. Travel time Galle to Negombo: 3 hours. Stay 1 night at The Wallawwa.
DEPART SRI LANKA: Travel time Negombo to Colombo Airport: 20 minutes

tourName: Sri Lanka holiday, tea, trains and elephants
generalInfo:
** All details of this holidays will be fully personalised for you. If you like longer or shorter itinerary, different hotels, different attractions we will customise for you! Contact us for free quote.
During this tour you will experience most significant places of Sri Lanka. You will be discovering the 2000 years old ancient cities, remote villages, discovering colonial legacy, spotting elephants, buffalos, sloth bear, blue whales and leopards, exploring the tea plantations and waterfalls, and finally unwinding in the sandy beaches. You will have your own personal chauffeur guide with car or van, so you can experience Sri Lanka at your own pace.

Tour Highlights
- Climb up the stunning Sigiriya Rock fortress (UNESCO World Heritage Site)
- Explore Cave temple of Dambulla (UNESCO World Heritage Site)
- Visit Kandy’s Temple of the Tooth (UNESCO World Heritage Site)
- Tea plantation Experience & Learn the process of tea making
- Panoramic train journey through tea hills and waterfalls above 1500 meters
- Watch the feedings of elephants in Elephant Transit Home
- Spotting elephants in Udawalawe National park Safari
- Discover the bustling capital city of Colombo
- Explore Dutch Galle Fort (UNESCO World Heritage Site)
- Relax and unwind in Golden sandy beaches
- Taste fresh sea food and Sri Lankan curry

dayInfo.description: Arrival - Negombo: “Ayubowan” & ‘’Vanakkam’’ Welcome to tropical paradise. You will be welcomed & greeted by your guide or our representative on arrival at the Waiting Area at the recently refurbished Modern BIA International Airport. You will travel to your hotel in Negombo. Travel time approximately 30 minutes depend on the road traffic. Location: Negombo; Hotel: Goldi Sands on Breakfast & Dinner

Sigiriya: You will travel to Sigiriya. Travel time approximately 3 hours depend on the road traffic. En-route you will visit Dambulla Cave temple. Dambulla Golden Rock Cave Temple is a vast isolated rock mass 500ft high and a 1.6 km around the base. Here is found the impressive Rock Temple dating to the First Century BC. The caves of Dambulla sheltered the King Walagamba during his 14 years of exile from Anuradhapura. When he regained the throne he built the most magnificent of Rock Temples to be found on the Island. The complex consists of five caves with over 2000 sq. meters of painted walls and ceilings. It is the largest area of paintings found in the world. It is an UNESCO World Heritage site. In the first Cave is a recumbent image of the Buddha 14 metre long cut out of the Rock. There are images of deities associated with Buddhism all around. The frescoes on the ceiling date back to the 15th - 18th Centuries. In the Second Cave, the finest and the largest of all, there are 150 life-size statues of Gods from the Buddhist religion along with numerous images of the Buddha himself. Location: - Sigiriya; Hotel : Kings Resort on Breakfast & Dinner

Sigiriya: After breakfast you will climb Sigiriya Rock Fortress. Sigiriya is a UNESCO World Heritage site which is proposed to be the 8th wonders of the World. Sigiriya, a massive rock in the green scrub jungle, is perhaps the most memorable place for visitors to Sri Lanka. The site was known from ancient times as a hermitage for Buddhist monks. A well-planned monastic complex included caved temples, bathing pools, lovely ponds and Asia's oldest surviving landscaped gardens. The "Lion stairway", the "mirror wall" and the "water gardens" are its other highlights. The ruins of the capital built by the parricidal King Kassapa I (477–95) lie on the steep slopes and at the summit of a granite peak standing some 370 m high (the 'Lion's Rock', which dominates the jungle from all sides). Afterwards enjoy Ayurveda massage to rejuvenate your bodies. Ayurveda is the ancient health care system in South Asia that has been passed down from father to son and based on herbs and diet. It is one of the world’s oldest forms of healing and treatment. You will find some of the best Ayurveda practitioners in Sri Lanka. Ayurveda is a well known treatment for stress, diabetes, migraine, asthma, arthritis, immune system and high blood pressure. Ayurveda is derived from Sanskrit for life (ayuh) and knowledge (veda), means ‘the science of life’. Therefore, Ayurveda is one of the oldest medical sciences of the world and its origins date back as far as 5,000 years South Asia. Afternoon safari at Kaudulla National Park – This National Park is the most recent to be added to the list. Famous for its elephants and bird population, species include the nation’s largest bird, the Lesser Adjutant and the Pompadour Green Pigeon. Built around the year 300 AD, the Tank slowly fell into disrepair and was rebuilt in 1959, and with its variety of plant life has now become home to 24 species of mammals, 25 species of amphibians and countless bird types. The endangered Rusty Spotted Cat can be spotted in Kaudulla National Park, as well as large herds of Asian elephants, elusive leopards and both Sambar and Axis Deer. Location: - Sigiriya; Hotel : Kings Resort on Breakfast & Dinner

Kandy: If you like along the way to Kandy you can stop at many spice gardens along the way. SPICE GARDENS – Spices have long been important in the commercial history of Sri Lanka. With so many spices and herbs growing on the island’s shores, it is unsurprising that they were used to barter and trade between the sea-faring merchants, and have been a main export of Sri Lanka down through the ages. For centuries the indigenous herbs and spices have been used for both medicinal purposes and in traditional Sri Lankan cuisine. To visit a Spice Garden is to open up your senses to smells and tastes, old and new. Cinnamon, ginger, vanilla and cardamom are just some of the spices available in the numerous Spice Gardens between Dambulla and Kandy. Afterwards you will visit The Temple of the Tooth. Sri Dalada Maligawa dates back to the 16th century, though most of the present buildings were built in the 19th century. Venerated as the most important object in the Buddhist world, the Sacred Relic of the Tooth of Buddha is enshrined at the Temple. Brought from India 2500 years ago, it is said that the possessor of the Relic had the right to rule the country. The Relic is kept in a gold casket and stored amidst great security in the Inner Chamber. In the afternoon you explore the Kandy City & markets. It is great place for shopping or just walks around the Lake and enjoys the beautiful scenery and narrow streets. In the evening you will see Traditional Kandyan Dance – Kandy, Sri Lanka’s second largest city is home to a Sinhalese cultural tradition of which Sri Lankans are justifiably proud. Rich in colour and agile in their movements, the Kandyan Dancers evoke images of pageantry and traditions past. Lively and exuberant, spellbinding and hypnotic, a Cultural Show is a spectacle to remember with its nimble dancers, energetic drummers and fireproof firewalkers. Location: - Kandy; Hotel: Golden Crown; Board: Breakfast

Kandy > Haputale After breakfast you will travel to Haputale in the tea hills part by road and part by train. As the road winds up, you will pass picturesque waterfalls, tumbling down hillsides and vantage points, which afford views over a panorama of rugged hills stretching far into the distance. This is the home of the Sri Lankan tea industry and as you gain in altitude, neatly manicured tea estates become a familiar part of the landscape, acres of tea bushes extending over the hills on either side of the road. There are many view points to stop and enjoy the breath taking views along the way. In the afternoon at 13.30hrs you will experience of the most breathtaking train journeys for 2.50 hours. You will travel from Nanuoya to Haputale through tea plantations and rolling hills on Old Colonial train with panoramic view. This train journeys recorded in the Guinness Books of Records as the one of the world best scenic train journeys. Your guide will pick you up at the Hapuatle Station upon arrival at 3pm and you will go to your hotel. Location: - Haputale Hotel: Melheim Board: Breakfast &Dinner

Haputale: In the morning you will visit the Lipton Seat & Tea Estate Experience: Experience the process and lifestyle within a tea estate. Tea is known as Sri Lanka’s green gold and the tea estate provides insight into British colonial past and role of tea in Sri Lanka today. The scenic views from the tea estates are breathtaking, where Thomas Lipton used sit and watch his estate. Dambatenne is one of the only estates in the world that Sir Thomas Lipton planted himself. The term “Ceylon Tea” was coined here, and Lipton’s Tea was founded and sold its first pound of tea from the precincts of the factory which still stands today. Location: - Haputale; Hotel: Melheim; Board: Breakfast & Dinner

Udawalawe: After breakfast you will visit the Udawalawe National Park. Travel time 2 hours. You will enjoy lunch with a local family to taste the traditional house food by the lake. Afternoon safari in Udawalawe National Park known as the best national park to spot elephants. With an area of 31,800 hectares surrounded by mountain ranges, the terrain of the park is a mixture of grassland, shrub jungle, wild tea plantations and two important factors which make this park special - the large Udawalawe Reservoir and the Walewe River, which ensure a supply of water for the fauna within. Internationally renowned for its large herd of elephants, the park is also known for several species of Deer, Wild Boar, Wild Buffalo, Jackal and rare sightings of Leopard as well as many species of birds. Location: - Udawalawe; Hotel: Centuria Lake Resort; Board: Breakfast & Dinner

Mirissa. in the morning you will visit Elephant Transit Home (ETH), where the orphan wild elephants are treated, raised and released back to the wild, also is located at Udawalawe. Visitors to this place can observe how the elephants are taken care of, twice a day. Total number of orphaned elephants exceeds 40, of which most of them are calves and juveniles. The animals become matured enough to live on their own, are released back to the wild. Park authorities keep constant vigilance on the newly released animals, until they get used to the new life in the wild. Afterwards you will travel to Mirissa, travel time 2:30 hours. Location: - Mirissa Hotel: Garten Cape; Board: Breakfast & Dinner
Mirissa: Full day at leisure Location: - Mirissa Hotel: Garten Cape; Board: Breakfast & Dinner.

Galle: (Optional) Blue Whale watching tour. Afterwards you will travel to Galle Fort. In the afternoon you will discover the Dutch Fort. Galle is situated in the southern Sri Lanka. It is the best example of a fortified city built by Europeans in south and Southeast Asia, showing the interaction between European architectural styles and south Asian traditions. The Galle fort is a UNESCO world heritage site and the largest remaining fortress in Asia built by European occupiers. Galle offers a unique opportunity to create a visible demonstration of the conservation of its inheritance. Location: - Colombo Hotel: Garten Cape; Board: Bed & Breakfast
Colombo Airport - UK: Todays you will travel to Airport. Travel time approximately an hour.

tourName: Sri Lanka holiday, two weeks
generalInfo:
This tailor-made tour you will experience the wildlife, culture and beach. You will have your own personal chauffeur guide with car or van, so you can experience Sri Lanka at your own pace.

Tour Highlights
- Explore Dutch Galle Fort (UNESCO World Heritage Site)
- Ancient City of Anuradhapura (UNESCO World Heritage Site)
- Discover Wilpattu National park
- Blue whale Watching
- Panoramic train journey through tea hills and waterfalls above 1500 meters
- Watch the feedings of elephants in Elephant Transit Home
- Spotting leopards and elephants in Yala National park Safari
- Relax and unwind in Golden sandy beaches of East Coast
- Discover the legends in Trincomalee
- Ayurveda Traditional Massage
- Taste fresh sea food and Sri Lankan curry

dayInfo.description: Arrival - Balapitiya “Ayubowan” & ‘’Vanakkam’’ Welcome to tropical paradise. You will be welcomed & greeted by your guide or representative on arrival at the Waiting Area at the recently refurbished Modern BIA International Airport. You will travel to Balapitiya in the South West. Travel time approximately 2 hours depend on the road traffic. Location: - Balapitiya Hotel: Board: Breakfast & Dinner

Balapitiya: In the morning you will take Boat Tour on the Madu River. You will explore this remote area and Cinnamon Islands. Madu Ganga or (Madu River) wet land spreads across 915 hectares, out of which 770 hectares is covered with water. Sail downstream for about a kilometer, the river opens its doors to 36 spectacular islands covering the rest 145 hectares. The inhabitants of these islands are mostly traditional fishermen and to some extent they are engaged in some traditional cottage industries such as producing peeled cinnamon and cinnamon oil. Afterwards, Enjoy Sri Lankan traditional culinary experience for Lunch with a local family to learn about Sri Lankan food. You will visit a local family in Bentota and will be welcomed. Here you will learn how to prepare and cook certain Sri Lankan dishes with aromatic spices and organic herbs; Also discover how coconut milk is made, learn to crack open and scrape out your own coconut, and taste the samples of each dish as you go along. The end product is a feast of 7 unique dishes served in a lotus leaf which you can eat local-style with your fingers if you are up for a challenge. (If you like to spend the day buying ingredients with the host in local markets, you are welcome to join in the Morning). Location: - Balapitiya; Hotel: Board: Breakfast & Dinner

Sinharaja: Today you will travel to Sinharaja Rainforest. Travel time approximately 2 hours depend on the road condition. Rest of the day free or optional short walk near the park. Location: - Sinharaja; Board: Breakfast & Dinner.

Sinharaja - Galle - Ahangama: Early morning start let us take you on an inspirational experience to wilderness, where time stands still. This is a treasure trove of natural wonders encased by sheer wilderness waiting to be discovered. Here you will be welcomed by thick air of humidity, incessant noise of birds and insects, and endless canopy of tall trees. Sinharaja Rainforest National park is a (UNESCO World Heritage Site) primary tropical rainforest and biosphere and regarded as a biodiversity hotspot in Sri Lanka. More than 60% of the trees are endemic and many of them are considered rare. In Sinharaja you can spot endemic mammals, bird species, butterflies, insects, reptiles and rare amphibians. As well as an interesting spectacle known as ‘bird wave’ is that birds tend to move in mixed feeding flocks, invariably led by the fearless Greater Racket-tailed Drongo and the noisy Orange-billed Babbler of Sri Lanka's 26 endemic birds, the 20 rainforest species all occur here, including the elusive Red-faced Malkoha, Green-billed Coucal and Sri Lanka Blue Magpie. Watch the National Wild Geographic Video Here You will have opportunity swim under the waterfall or river along the walk. Along the way you will visit a remote community cut off from the rest of the world. There are more than 20 communities they live in Sinharaja Rainforest they livelihood is depends on this forest. You will be able to enjoy the Kitul ‘palm syrup’ made by these communities. After lunch you will travel to Ahangama via Galle. En – route, you will discover the Dutch Fort in Galle. It is situated in the southern Sri Lanka. The Galle fort is a UNESCO world heritage site and the largest remaining fortress in Asia built by European occupiers showing the interaction between European architectural styles and south Asian traditions. Other prominent landmarks in Galle include the natural harbour, the National Maritime Museum, St. Mary's Cathedral founded by Jesuit priests, one of the main Shiva temples on the island. Galle offers a unique opportunity to create a visible demonstration of the conservation of its inheritance. There are many boutique shops along the narrow streets of the fort as well as antiques, arts, and craft shops. Location: - Ahangama Hotel: Board: Breakfast

Ahangama - Ella: Today you’ll leave early in the morning around 06:00am from your hotel to Mirissa to watch the Blue Whales. Mirissa is the most reliable site in the world for seeing the difficult and desired Blue Whale. It may also be the best place for seeing Sperm Whales too. Blue whales are the largest animals ever lived on earth growing up to some 33 meters long, weighing up to some 150-180 metric tons. They live individually or in very small pods or groups and frequently swim in pairs. Large Baleen Whales and Toothed Whales also come within sight of the shore. The calm ocean is abundant with krill which Blue Whales feed. From December through to April; there is an outstanding wide opportunity for observing Blue Whales and Sperm Whales close to shore. Afterwards you will travel to Ella. Travel time’s approximately 3 hours. Location: - Ella; Board: Breakfast & Dinner

Ella Hike up to the Little Adam’s Peak; waking up early in the morning to astonish the breathtaking views of an endless valleys, lush tea plantations and flowing waterfalls as sunrises. Little Adam’s Peak resembles the main Adam’s Peak near Hatton. By foot it takes about 35-40 minutes. After breakfast you will visit Halpewatte Tea Factory. It is located in the beautiful town of Ella. It is one of the largest tea factories in the region of Uva. The factory was once a part of the British era which dates back to the 1940s. It provides a range of supreme quality tea using the latest manufacturing techniques and offers a guided tour for its’ visitors who wish to learn more about the authentic Sri Lankan tea. The tour usually lasts for 40 minutes to an hour. The tour commences from a short lecture on the different types of tea and the procedures which go into making the tea to the end of tasting session of the aromatic teas. Location: - Ella; Hotel: Board: Breakfast

Ella - Gal Oya: Today you will travel from Ella to Gal Oya. Travel time’s approximately 2 ½ hours. In the afternoon you will take a boat safari to watch the birds and wildlife of Gal Oya. This is only park in Sri Lanka where you can take a boat trip to watch the wildlife and swimming elephants. The lake is at its fullest with stunning early morning views of clouds engulfed mountains and wildlife. Gal Oya National Park lies south-east of the Kandy in the eastern district. The Park was closed during the war for three decades and was established to protect the catchments area of the Senanayake Samudraya (lake). The wildlife richness this wetland with natural habitat for a wide range of fauna and flora. About 45% of the vegetation is evergreen forest, 33% savanna, 9% grassland, 2% chena cultivations and the balance is water bodies dominated by Senanayake Samudraya. The Park is host of medicinal shrubs and trees, while a few locally known trees such as Vevarana, Halmilla, Veera, Palu, Ebony and Mahogany are found in great numbers. The Park with its thick green canopy is haven for species of birds including migratory birds such as Painted Storks, Pelicans, Cormorants and Teals. January to May is the green season, with chance of afternoon and night-time showers. June to December is the dry season, as the year goes on the lake subsides and exposes the lake floor where fresh grass grows and attracts large herds of elephant where the days are hot and nights are cooler. Location: - Gal Oya Hotel: Board: Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner.

Gal Oya - Pasikudha. Today you will travel to Pasikudha, travel time 2.5-3 hours. Pasikudha is situated in the east of Sri Lanka. It is one of the most beautiful beaches in the world and in Sri Lanka. It’s known for its long and wide pristine white powder sandy beaches in a quiet bay. You can wade into the clear turquoise water for hundreds of metres before needing to break into a backstroke. It is a perfect place for your ideal beach holiday. Location: - Pasikudha; Hotel: Board: Breakfast & Dinner.
Pasikudha Full day at leisure. Location: - Pasikudha; Hotel: Board: Breakfast & Dinner.

Pasikudha - Sigiriya: After breakfast you will travel to Sigiriya. Sigiriya is situated in the Cultural Triangle of Sri Lanka. One of the Asia’s major archaeological centres, home to 4 of the UNESCO World Heritage sites. The ruins and temple date back to 4th century B.C. The Cultural Triangle used to be the home of ancient Kingdoms. The area is full of culture, history and wildlife. Here the ancient Kings have developed one of the sophisticated and advanced civilisations of Sri Lanka. Afternoon enjoy a Jeep Safari at Minneriya National Park (Duration – hours). It’s on the banks of the Minneriya reservoir, which was built in the 4th century A.C. Minneriya is a hide-out for many elephants, where you could see herds of elephants approximately 50 to 60 elephants in a herd. Here in July to September one of the World top ten wild life spectacles takes place known as ‘The Gathering’, more 250 elephants gather around Minneriya water tank in search water and food. Apart from elephants, it is a habitant for migrant and resident bird species like Grey heron, Open built storks, Painted storks …etc. And also you could see 3 different species of monkeys like Silica makake, Pink faced leaf monkey and Grey langer. Location: - Sigiriya; Hotel: Board: Breakfast & Dinner.

Sigiriya - Negombo: In the morning enjoy Ayurveda massage to rejuvenate your bodies. Ayurveda is the ancient health care system in South Asia that has been passed down from father to son and based on herbs and diet. It is one of the world’s oldest forms of healing and treatment. You will find some of the best Ayurveda practitioners in Sri Lanka. Ayurveda is a well known treatment for stress, diabetes, migraine, asthma, arthritis, immune system and high blood pressure. Ayurveda is derived from Sanskrit for life (ayuh) and knowledge (veda), means ‘the science of life’. Therefore, Ayurveda is one of the oldest medical sciences of the world and its origins date back as far as 5,000 years South Asia. Optional you visit Sigiriya Rock or Dambulla Temple before go to Negombo. Afterwards you will to Negombo. Location: - Negombo; Hotel:; Board: Breakfast & Dinner.
Negombo - Airport: You will travel to the airport depend on your flight departure time.

tourName: Sri Lanka holiday, wild escapes
placesVisited: Colombo, Habarana, Sigiriya Rock Fortress, Minneriya National Park, Kandalama, Kandy, Nuwara Eliya, Sinharaja Rainforest, Ranweli Holiday Village
generalInfo:
This wonderful 8 day tour travels to lesser know locations and beautiful eco properties around the island, as well as visiting and viewing the elephants at Minneriya National Park.

Highlights include:
1. Jeep Safari – Minneriya National Park
2. Sigiriya Rock Fortress
3. Temple of the tooth
4. Tea Factory
5. Tea Plantation
6. Nature Trek - Sinharaja

Sinharaja Forest Reserve – one of the least disturbed and biologically unique primary lowland rain forests in Sri Lanka, covering an extent of over 11000 hectares. Of international significance and declared a Man and Biosphere Reserve (MAB) in 1978 when UNESCO included it in its international network of Biosphere reserves. Spend your day walking with expert guides through Sinharaja Rainforest - Sri Lanka’s last remaining rainforest and home to most of the island’s endemic bird life.

Nuwara Eliya is also the heart of Sri Lanka's tea country, producing some of the world’s best tea. The mountain slopes and valleys are a carpet of velvety green tea plantations.

The city of Kandy is famed for the Temple of the Tooth, commonly known as "Sri Dalada Maligawa". It is an important shrine for Buddhists as it holds the tooth relic of Lord Buddha and it is famous for its carvings and the beautiful art that is unique to Sri Lanka.

Ranweli is located in a coast wetland estuary and this contributes to a large diversity of over 130 species of birds. Activities include bird watching, nature walks, cycling tours, river cruise, craft demonstrations, butterfly tours, all of which can be arranged locally upon arrival at the hotel.

dayInfo.description: Depart London Heathrow on your overnight flight to Colombo, Sri Lanka.

On arrival at the Bandaranaike International Airport you will be met by Your Travel Representative and be transferred to Habarana. (Airport to Habarana: approx. 04 Hours / 160 Km). Upon arrival check in at hotel.

Today you will visit the Lion Rock, one of the seven World Heritage sites in the island. (Habarana to Sigiriya: approximately 45 Minutes / 25 Km). In the afternoon you have the option of enjoying a game drive at the Minneriya National Park.
This morning you will leave Kandalama and drive to Kandy. (Habarana to Kandy: approximately 03 Hours / 104 Km). Continue to Kandy and check in at your hotel.
Spend your day at leisure or you have the option of sightseeing in Kandy. The driver will be at your disposal to explore within the city limits of Kandy.
This morning you head to Nuwara Eliya. (Kandy to Nuwara Eliya: approx. 2.5 Hours / 82 Km) Upon arrival you will visit a Tea Plantation and Tea factory.

Today you will head to Sinharaja . (Nuwara Eliya to Sinharaja-approx. 05 Hours / 195 Km). Check in at hotel. Located on a division of the Enselwatte Tea Estate bordering the South-eastern side of the Sinharaja Rainforest

Wake up to the sounds of the rainforest this morning; a beautiful symphony of birds and frogs, and watch the mists rise over the luscious plantations. Spend your day walking with expert guides through Sinharaja Rainforest.
Enjoy a full day at the hotel on many of the activities on offer.
Today you will be transferred to the airport to board your departure flight back to London Heathrow.

tourName: Sri Lanka holiday with boutique hotels
generalInfo:
First stop is The Wallawwa, an ideal venue for post- and pre-flight pampering. Set in a former manor house surrounded by tropical gardens it offers elegant guestrooms, gourmet cuisine, discreet service and a decadent spa. Next you’ll travel up into the hills for a stay at Mountbatten Bungalow in Kandy. This is a is a tastefully renovated and refurbished century-old tea planter’s bungalow once the war office and sometimes private residence of Lord Mountbatten of Burma, hence its name. Experience a special moment in time, a bygone era of grace and elegance that is still tangible today.

A real gem at the southern end of the Hill Country, Living Heritage Koslanda is next on the agenda. Surrounded by 80 acres of deciduous woodland, known locally as ‘God’s Forest’, with a river running through it and a secluded waterfall, this off-the-beaten-track boutique hotel has nine stylish rooms and celebrates Sri Lanka’s traditional architectural design. From here you’ll leave the hills for the island’s low-lying southern plains, and then along the picturesque and cove-sprinkled southern coastline to Galle, famed for pretty beaches, a 17th century Dutch fort and a cosmopolitan vibe. Here you’ll stay at the Fort Bazaar right in the heart of Galle Fort, a UNESCO World Heritage site. This 18-room boutique hotel has a pool as well as fabulous eating and drinking venues.

You’ll end your trip at the oceanside on the island’s attractive west coast, staying at Kumu Beach, a contemporary beach hotel home to 10 generous bedrooms, chic living and dining areas basking in the open air, and a generous lawn with infinity swimming pool. Balapitiya's quiet and secluded powder-soft beach is footsteps away, and this exclusive boutique hotel is an enchanting place to relax, unwind, eat well and enjoy personalised service.

dayInfo.description: Arrive into Bandaranaike International Airport north of Colombo and head straight to Wallawwa, a 17-room boutique hotel, to recuperate amidst startlingly peaceful surroundings. Set in an expansive tropical garden, this former manor house indulges the senses with a chic collection of guestrooms, gourmet cuisine, discreet service and decadent spa – the venue for post- and pre-flight pampering. Night stay at Wallawwa.

At leisure. Be on the beach in 30 minutes, play a round of croquet in the garden or take a private guided tour by boat through the pretty bird-filled Muthurajawela Wetlands. Colombo’s restaurants, shops and sights are a little over 30 minutes’ drive away. Night stay at Wallawwa.

Wind your up through Sri Lankan ‘jungle’ and impressive mountain scenery into the northern Hill Country to Kandy, one of the principal points of the island’s Cultural Triangle. Night stay at Mountbatten Bungalow, which is a tastefully renovated and refurbished century-old tea planter’s bungalow once the war office and sometimes private residence of Lord Mountbatten of Burma, hence its name. Experience a special moment in time, a bygone era of grace and elegance that is still tangible today.

At leisure. May be experience the Buddhist puja (blessing ceremony) at the Temple of the Tooth, which houses Sri Lanka’s most revered religious relic. Kandy is the perfect size to be explored on foot, since the altitude (500 metres above sea level) makes the climate conducive to long and leisurely strolls. A guided walking tour of the city will take in the Hindu devales (temples), the lake and the municipal market. Visit the beautifully kept and well-presented Peradeniya Botanic Gardens on the outskirts of Kandy. Guided tour of Embekke, Lankathilake and Gadaladeniya temples close to Kandy, which display the late flowering of Kandyan artistic craftsmanship. Visit Udawattakele Sanctuary, once the royal hunting grounds of the erstwhile Kandyan kings and now a nature reserve in the heart of the city (beware leeches! Learn to prepare traditional ‘Rice and Curry’ and get hands-on experience of how the delicious food is eaten! Share in the adventure of the Ceylon Tea Museum, which tells the story of the tea industry in Sri Lanka – a monument to courage and a valuable part of the history of the island. Early evening performance of the famous Kandyan dancers and drummers, with a fire-walking finale! Trekking in the spectacular Knuckles Mountain Range or Hanthana Hills. Night stay at Mountbatten Bungalow.

Travel south from Kandy into Sri Lanka’s vertiginous Tea Country, so-named for the velveteen tea plantations that carpet the misty hills. Drive to the market town of Nuwara Eliya at 1900 metres before continuing into the southern Hill Country to Living Heritage Koslanda near Haputale. This secluded boutique hotel celebrates Sri Lanka’s traditional architectural motifs expressed in its hugely spacious suites with generous living areas, and a courtyard that includes an alfresco Jacuzzi and open-to-the-skies shower. Set in over 80 acres, the property borders a patch of forest known locally as ‘God’s Forest’, which contains a river and a secluded waterfall. Night stay at Living Heritage Koslanda.
At leisure. Local activities include trekking, tea factory visits, tree planting and cooking classes. Night stay at Living Heritage Koslanda.

From Koslanda, drop down from the southern Hill Country to the hot and dry southern plain before continuing south to the coast and heading west along the picturesque and cove-sprinkled southern coastline to Galle, famed for its Dutch colonial-era fort. Night stay at Fort Bazaar, which is a handsome 17th century Dutch merchant’s home redefined as a luxury town house hotel with 18 stylish guestrooms and fresh, contemporary interiors invoking a Middle Eastern vibe. This boutique spa hotel promises serenity, top-quality service and modern gourmet dining within the fort.

At leisure. What's on offer in the area? Well, a boat safari through the mangroves and lush vegetation along the Mahamodara River near Galle, which offers great opportunities for spotting birds, butterflies, monitor lizards, and much more! Guided cycling tours of the paddy fields and local villages around Galle. An early morning (06.30) boat safari off the south coast from Mirissa to spot Blue Whales, the largest animal on Earth! Sperm, Humpback and Orca Whales as well as large pods of dolphins are also regular sightings. Guided tour of the imposing rock temple of Mulkirigala Raja Maha Viharaya, which is situated about 15 km inland from Tangalle on an isolated rock 210 metres high rising almost vertically from the surrounding forest and believed to have been founded around 130 BC. Another boat safari, this time around Kalametiya Sanctuary near Tangalle, which is an extensive area of wetland with brackish lagoons, mangrove swamps, open grassy areas and pockets of scrub jungle. It is an important site for migrant waders and provides an important refuge (one of the few remaining on the southern coastal strip) for smaller mammals. Night stay at Fort Bazaar.

Head north up the island’s west coast to Balapitiya. Night stay at Kumu Beach, which is a contemporary beach hotel home to 10 generous bedrooms, chic living and dining areas basking in the open air, and a generous lawn with infinity swimming pool. Balapitiya's quiet and secluded powder-soft beach is footsteps away, and this exclusive boutique hotel is an enchanting place to relax, unwind, eat well and enjoy personalised service. The immaculately finished rooms and suites are spacious, light and airy, all with ocean views, and the attention to detail and design is impressive, from modern ribbed teak furniture to large luxury bathrooms.

At leisure. Enjoy an afternoon’s boat safari around the coastal lagoons and mangrove-clad waterways of the Madu Ganga near Balapitiya. Take a guided tour of the house and gardens of Lunuganga near Bentota, which were lovingly created over several decades by the legendary architect Geoffrey Bawa, as his vision of a tropical garden idyll. The Italian garden with spectacular views over lakes and tropical jungle together with a simply designed plantation house are one of the lasting legacies of Asia’s most famous architect. Visit the tropical garden paradise of Brief near Bentota, the life’s work of the late Bevis Bawa, renowned bon viveur and brother of Geoffrey. Night stay at Kumu Beach.
Transfer to the airport for your flight home.

tourName: Sri Lanka holidays, tailor made
placesVisited: Colombo, Sigiriya, Polonnaruwa, Minneriya National Park, Kandy, Temple of the Tooth, Peradeniya Botanic Gardens, Nuwara Eliya, Horton Plains National Park, Tissamaharama, Ella, Yala National Park, Tangalle, Galle
generalInfo:
Early Arab traders named Sri Lanka “Serendib” – which is where the word serendipity comes from, meaning discovery by happy accident. It’s a verdant, tropical island, that’s both rich in culture but also in natural beauty and wildlife. Our tailor made Sri Lanka holidays can pick and mix from the best of this diverse country, which boasts nine World Heritage Sites, 14 national parks, 86 species of mammals, including elephants and leopards, lush hill country where tea is grown and an Indian Ocean coastline with sandy beaches and swaying palms. No wonder Marco Polo described Sri Lanka as “undoubtedly the finest island of its size in the world”.

For our tailor made Sri Lanka holidays we have developed a unique online holiday planner to enable visitors to create their own itinerary. Sophisticated and user-friendly, the holiday planner offers an opportunity to create individual tailor made holidays to Sri Lanka at your leisure! You are able to explore and plan your own route, excursions and activities, as well as choose the type and style of accommodation that suits you best. A 15-day sample itinerary for one of our tailor made Sri Lanka holidays is given below, but the real choice is yours and an amazing variety of tailor made Sri Lanka holidays are available.

Temperatures remain pretty much the same throughout the year in Sri Lanka, because the island sits just north of the equator, but rainfall varies widely season to season. The best time to come is between the main rainy seasons, which affect different sides of the island at different times. In the south, southwest and hill country, November to April is the best time to come, when the southwest monsoon has finished. In the north and east, October to February is when the northeast monsoon occurs. In this part of the island, it’s better to come when it's dry but hot from April to September. Throughout the year, the hill country always feels much cooler, thanks to its higher elevation.

dayInfo.description: Arrive Colombo airport and drive into the island’s Cultural Triangle (ancient cities’ area). Night stay at Habarana.

Head to the medieval capital of Polonnaruwa for a guided tour of its historic temples and exquisitely carved statues, with visits to the Quadrangle, Northern Monuments, Royal Citadel Group and Southern Group – bicycles are available to hire for your own self-guided tour, if preferred. In the afternoon, drive back to Minneriya for a jeep safari in Minneriya National Park, which is part of an ‘elephant corridor’, along with Kaudulla National Park, for the vast herds roaming the eastern region of the country from Trincomalee through to Wasgamuwa, Maduru Oya and Gal Oya National Parks further south. The park is home to a variety of animals such as elephants, leopards, toque macaques, purple faced langurs, sloth bears, sambar and spotted deer, and about 160 bird species, including many endemics. IMPORTANT – Minneriya is home to the ‘gathering’ between August and October, when large herds of elephants congregate around Minneriya Lake to seek the last available water at the end of the dry season. Return to Sigiriya. Night stay at Habarana.

Early morning (07.00) ascent of 200-metre high ‘Lion Rock’ at Sigiriya to view the surrounding countryside at dawn – a very special experience indeed. The unique rock fortress of Sigiriya is a national icon, despite its origins as a usurper’s pleasure palace housing erotic frescoes! Guided tour of the rock palace and ornamental gardens before heading to Dambulla to climb gently up the granite massif to visit the most impressive cave temple complex in Sri Lanka, with five ornately and intricately decorated caverns under a vast overhanging rock. Continue south to Kandy, one of the principal points of the Cultural Triangle. The second city of Sri Lanka has a picturesque setting around its lake, a rich historical and cultural heritage, a comfortable Mediterranean-type climate, and UNESCO World Heritage Site status. Night stay at Kandy.

After an early breakfast, experience the Buddhist puja (blessing ceremony) at the Temple of the Tooth, which houses Sri Lanka’s most revered religious relic. Kandy is the perfect size to be explored on foot, since the altitude (500 metres above sea level) makes the climate conducive to long and leisurely strolls. A guided walking tour of the city will take in the Hindu devales (temples), the lake and the municipal market. After lunch, visit the beautifully kept and well presented Peradeniya Botanic Gardens on the outskirts of Kandy. In the early evening, enjoy a performance of the famous Kandyan Dancers and Drummers, with a fire-walking finale. Night stay at Kandy.

Leave Kandy and head into the upper Hill Country, following the winding, vertiginous roads through the velveteen slopes of verdant tea plantations and past spectacular waterfalls and impressive mountain scenery on your way to Nuwara Eliya, the British colonial capital of the Hill Country and the highest town in Sri Lanka at 1900 metres above sea level. On arrival, amble around the ‘City of Lights’ and enjoy a little piece of England in the tropics! Night stay at Nuwara Eliya.

Drive to Horton Plains for an early morning (07.00) trek through the heath and forest of Horton Plains National Park, via Baker’s Falls, in time to see the awe-inspiring views at World's End before the cloud sets in (circuit is approximately 9 km). Horton Plains is a particularly good area for spotting endemics, including: Sri Lankan Whistling Thrush (endangered), Sri Lankan Bush Warbler, Sri Lankan Blue Magpie, Black-throated Munia, Orange-billed Babbler and Dull-blue Flycatcher. Transfer to Nanuoya railway station for a scenic train journey – subject to availability – to Ella in the southern Hill Country. Night stay at Ella.

At leisure. There is plenty to do around the Ella area including an easy walk past tea pickers houses on your way to glorious views over the surrounding area from Little Adam's Peak; a moderate walk to the top of Ella Rock, which affords superb views from the southern Hill Country to the south coast (on a clear day!); a short drive and then walk up through the immaculately manicured Dambatenne tea estate to Lipton’s Seat, a viewpoint from where Sir Thomas Lipton, the tea magnate, often admired the 360-degree view, hence its name; visit Bambarakanda Falls, Sri Lanka’s highest waterfall at 263 metres; tour of a working tea factory to see how ‘two-leaves-and-a-bud’ turns into your daily cuppa; explore Ravana’s Cave, the mythical hideout of the Ramayana, where the demon king of Lanka imprisoned Rama's wife, Sita. Night stay at Ella.

Drop down to Wellawaya on the southern plain through Ella Gap before continuing south across the hot and dry southern plain to Yala for an afternoon (15.00) jeep safari in Yala National Park, which is one of the island's best-known reserves and one of its largest. This Dry Zone region has mostly dry thorn scrub, interspersed with small dusty glades – the ideal habitat to view elephants, Sri Lanka's largest mammal. The park does have a varied landscape, however, from parkland to dense jungle on the plains, scrubland with rocky outcrops and several streams, small lakes and lagoons. The picturesque ocean frontage to the east has wide beaches and high sand dunes. A former hunting reserve, which was transformed into a nature park in 1938, Yala National Park, also called “Ruhuna”, is currently home to over 390 elephants, several of which are tuskers, and about 120 leopards, reportedly the highest density of leopards in the wild anywhere in the world. Watching elephants go for their bath at sunset or seeing leopards laze about on the rocks at dusk are the most popular natural spectacles at Yala National Park. However, you may also see other species of mammals such as sambar and spotted deer, wild boar, buffalo, musk deer, black bear, the unique small Loris, toque macaque and langur monkeys, jackal, mongoose, porcupine, civet cat, anteater, and the enigmatic sloth bear. Over 150 species of birds have been recorded in Yala National Park, including the Sri Lankan Junglefowl, White-bellied Fish Eagle, Painted Stork, Black-necked Stork, Lesser Adjutant, Pompadour Green Pigeon, Orange-breasted Green Pigeon, Brown Fish Owl, Red-faced Malkoha, three species of bee-eaters, and large numbers of waders (including three species of pratincole and two thick-knees). IMPORTANT – Yala National Park is closed from 01 September for up to 2 months annually as a respite period for the animals and environment at the end of the dry season. Continue to Kataragama. Night stay at Kataragama.

Drive west to Bundala for an early morning (06.00) jeep safari in Bundala National Park, which is the first Ramsar site (wetlands of international importance) in Sri Lanka and it is the most significant wetland for birds on the island outside of Northern Province. The shallow, brackish lagoons and saltpans of the park are among the most important overwintering areas for migratory shore birds in the country. This bird sanctuary is home to every species of water bird resident in the country. The rare Black-necked Stork is said to be a breeding resident in Sri Lanka. Vagrants turn up occasionally including the Capion Plover, Ringer Plover, Common Redshank, Red Knot, Red-necked Phalarope, Common Avocet and various sandpipers. The forest still harbours elephants as well as toque macaque and common langur monkeys, jackal, leopard, fishing and spotted cats, mongoose, wild boar, mouse, barking and spotted deer, sambar, black-naped hare, Indian pangolin, porcupine, mugger and estuarine crocodiles, common monitors, star tortoise, and pythons. Leave the park and continue west along the picturesque and cove-sprinkled southern coastline to Talalla. Night stay at Talalla.

At leisure. Local sightseeing trips and activities include a guided tour of the imposing rock temple of Mulkirigala Raja Maha Viharaya, which is situated about 15 km inland from Tangalle on an isolated rock 210 metres high rising almost vertically from the surrounding forest and believed to have been founded around 130 BC; a boat safari in Kalametiya Sanctuary near Tangalle, which is an extensive area of wetland with brackish lagoons, mangrove swamps, open grassy areas and pockets of scrub jungle. It is an important site for migrant waders and provides an important refuge (one of the few remaining on the southern coastal strip) for smaller mammals; early morning (06.30) boat safari off the south coast from Mirissa to spot Blue Whales, the largest animal on Earth! Sperm, Humpback and Orca Whales as well as large pods of dolphins are also regular sightings. IMPORTANT – Season from November to April. Night stay at Talalla.

Continue along the southern coastline to Galle for a guided tour of the Dutch Fort, another of the island's World Heritage Sites. Amble around the ramparts and stroll through the Arab Quarter. Other activities around Galle include a boat safari through the mangroves and lush vegetation along the Mahamodara River, which offers great opportunities for spotting birds, butterflies, monitor lizards, and much more; guided cycling tours of the paddy fields and local villages. Night stay at Galle.

In the morning, you may like to enjoy a guided tour of the house and gardens of Lunuganga near Bentota, which were lovingly created over several decades by the world renowned architect, Geoffrey Bawa, as his vision of a tropical garden idyll. The Italian garden with spectacular views over lakes and tropical jungle together with a simply designed plantation house are one of the lasting legacies of Asia’s most famous architect. Or visit the tropical garden paradise of Brief near Bentota, the life’s work of Bevis Bawa, famed bon viveur and brother of Geoffrey. After lunch, head north to Negombo on the island's west coast close to the airport,. Night stay at Negombo.
Transfer to the airport for your flight home.

dayInfo.description: Arrive into Colombo International Airport and head straight to The Wallawwa to recuperate amidst startlingly peaceful surroundings. Set in expansive tropical grounds with a big kitchen garden, this former manor house offers family-orientated room options, varied cuisine, discreet service and a decadent spa. Be on Negombo Beach in 30 minutes, play croquet in the garden or take a private guided tour by boat or kayak through the bird-filled Muthurajawela Wetlands. Colombo is 30 minutes’ drive away. Travel time Colombo Airport to The Wallawwa: 20 minutes. Stay 2 nights at The Wallawwa.

TANGALLE: Travel straight down the expressway, and along the picturesque cove-sprinkled southern coastline to Mawella, seven kilometres west of Tangalle, a beautifully secluded two-kilometre curved beach. Here you’ll stay for four nights at The Last House, a Geoffrey Bawa-designed boutique hotel with just four individually designed guestrooms within earshot of the sea. The vibe here is relaxed and this destination is ideal for unwinding in private, tranquil surroundings. The staff will pamper you and the hotel cook is excellent. If you can draw yourself away from the near-deserted beach (which is great for strolls, jogs, swimming and body boarding), you’ll find Tangalle to be a great base for visiting national parks (Udawalawe is famed for elephants), wildlife reserves and ancient temples (Mulkirigala is a favourite). Travel time Negombo to Tangalle: 4.5 hours. Stay 4 nights at The Last House.

GALLE: Travel west along the picturesque cove-sprinkled southern coastline to Galle, famed for pretty beaches, a 17th century Dutch fort and a cosmopolitan vibe. Here you’ll stay at Why House, an idyllic country-style boutique hotel with big garden and expansive swimming pool. The hotel isn’t on the beach but is located just inland, a five-minute tuk tuk ride from Dalawella Beach, and many more. There’s an excellent restaurant too. Aside from beachcombing, activities in the local area include guided bicycle rides along scenic rural inland lanes, boat trips (on Koggala Lake), seasonal whale and dolphin watching (from nearby Mirissa), surfing (Kabalana and Weligama are two of the best), strolls around Galle Fort and shopping/eating out. Travel time Tangalle to Galle: 1.5 hours. Stay 4 nights at Why House.

BALAPITIYA: From Galle, it’s less than an hour’s drive to Balapitiya, a small coastal village on Sri Lanka’s sunset coast. Here you’ll stay at Kumu Beach, above a sandy beach edged by huge boulders set in its own private palm-shaded garden with a 25-metre swimming pool. The hotel was completed in 2017, and offers 10 bedrooms, four of which are very spacious Oceanview Suites with private lounges and superb sea views. This is a lovely place to relax and unwind; the hotel has a contemporary design style, and its kitchen produces fabulous local and fusion cuisine for enjoying on the long timber deck, beside the swimming pool or anywhere in the garden. The region is a centre for Sri Lankan folk culture with mask museums nearby at Ambalangoda and a number of attractions within reach including Lunuganga, the home and garden of the late Geoffrey Bawa, plus Bentota for water sports action. Travel time Galle to Balapitiya: 1 hour. Stay 3 nights at Kumu Beach.
DEPART SRI LANKA. Travel time Balapitya to Colombo Airport: 2 hours

tourName: Sri Lanka luxury camping & wildlife holiday
placesVisited: Camping experience, Wilpattu National Park, Udawalawe National Park, Yala National Park, Bundala National Park, Galle, Blue whales November to March
generalInfo:
Wildlife holidays in Sri Lanka will bring you into the heart of our great national parks, but few will immerse you in the habitats of our great creatures. However, by enjoying some luxury camping in Sri Lanka, you will have access to our natural heritage, morning, noon and night. Accompanied on all our safaris by expert local naturalist guides. Not only will you have opportunities to see Sri Lanka’s ‘Big 5’ - leopard, elephants, sloth bears, sperm and blue whales, but you will also be staying in quality camps, with fully serviced safari tents, eating superb food al fresco, on the borders of our national parks. However, with the environment in mind at all times, these campsites are also fully mobile.

We will sleep and safari in four of Sri Lanka’s national parks: Wilapttu NP, the largest park and famous for its sixty waterholes brimming with wildlife; Udawalawe NP, one of the country’s most prolific elephant habitats, but also finest birdwatching sites; Yala NP, beautifully biodiverse with just about every species thriving in mangroves, monsoon forests and marine wetlands, and famous for having the highest concentration of leopard in the world; and Bundala NP where myriad lagoons and dunes are home to migratory flamingos, storks and marine turtles.

This camping holiday is a first in Sri Lanka, and we are proud of its carbon neutral status, as well as the financial contribution we make to local conservation and community projects. And although our camps are fully mobile, we do not compromise on facilities and comfort, with real beds, quality bed linen and private bathroom facilities. As well as our much celebrated full time chefs, and plenty of cool wines and beers.

dayInfo.description: Upon your arrival in Colombo, rendezvous with your personal chauffeur/guide for a private transfer to the Wilpattu National Park to begin the first part of your adventure. Appropriate meals and refreshments will await you at the campsite depending on your time of arrival. You can meet with your designated naturalist to discuss a suitable plan for the rest of the day as well as the rest of your two-day stay at the park. You can even do a wilderness walk with your naturalist if time permits before an overnight stay at the Mahoora Tented Safari Camp.

Enjoy a full-day safari at the Wilpattu National Park, which is the oldest and largest national wildlife park in Sri Lanka and home to an array of unique species of flora and fauna including the famed Sri Lankan Leopard and Sloth Bears. We will serve a full serviced lunch within the park premises after which you can relax in the comfy hammocks that we have set up for you or have a detailed discussion with your naturalist to learn more about the wildlife that you encounter. In the evening, we will take you on another safari within the park before you head back to the comfort of the campsite.

You will start your adventure at the break of day with an early safari inclusive of a charming picnic breakfast. The Wilpattu National Park offers you the opportunity to film and photograph the Sri Lankan Leopard, the largest species of leopard living in Asia. These glorious beasts are often seen lying beside the Park’s many villus. You may even catch a glimpse of the endangered Sloth Bears, most commonly seen during the fruiting season of the Palu Tree between June and July. After that, you can enjoy another fully-serviced lunch at the park. We have also organised an optional night walk with the resident naturalist of the camp where we will attempt to seek out owls, Gray Slender Loris, Ring-Tailed Civet Cats, Rusty Spotted Cats, Golden Palm Civet Cats, chameleons and many other nocturnal species.

Following breakfast at the campsite, you will be transferred to Udawalawe. Upon your arrival, you will be greeted by the naturalist designated for the Udawalawe leg of your tour, who will then transfer you to the Udawalawe Mahoora Tented Safari Campsite. When you arrive in Udawalawe, your naturalist will take you on an evening walk in the neighboring village where you can learn about the way of life of the local farming communities and their encounters with the wildlife. We have organized your overnight stay at the luxurious Mahoora Tented Safari Campsite.

Enjoy a morning safari at the Udawalawe National Park which spans approximately 31,000 hectares and is located in the southern dry zone. It is the only place in the world where an elephant sighting is guaranteed on every single safari drive. After our morning safari we will take you to the Elephant Transit Home where abandoned, injured or orphaned elephants are taken in, treated and then released back into the wild. Here, you will be able to observe these magnificent creatures at a safe distance as human contact needs to be minimal. After a late lunch back at the camp an optional evening birding trail can be organized with the guidance of the resident naturalist.

After breakfast, you will be transferred to Yala. Here, you will spend your final three nights at the comfy tented camp we have set up bordering the Yala National Park, which is home to a range of ecosystems found nowhere else in Sri Lanka. Go on an evening safari at the park, which boasts the largest density of leopards in the world. With a density of one leopard per square mile, Yala is known as one of the best places on earth to film and photograph these regal beasts.

Another full day safari has been organized where you will be able to see the variety of habitats that this unique park has to offer with a host of endemic plant and animal species on display. The park boasts 44 species of recorded mammals, 215 species of birds, 46 species of reptiles and 21 species of amphibians. Lunch will be served in a suitable location within the park. After dinner, a walk with your resident naturalist along the park borders will open the doors for you to catch a glimpse of the park’s nightlife. Then return to the comfort and luxury of your camp to recharge your batteries.

We have two safaris lined up for you on this day and this time you have full control. You can either spend the whole day in Yala or spend half of the day at the Bundala National Park in the southern district of Hambantota. The Bundala National Park has been acknowledged as an Important Bird Area (IBA) for its 197 recorded bird species and is also the only national park where you can see both marsh and estuarine crocodiles on the same safari drive.

You will be transferred to Sri Lanka’s southern capital of Galle. This prominent port city is richly influenced by colonial architecture having been one of the most important strategic locations fortified by the colonists. Explore the multi-cultural and historic attractions of the city, including the Galle Fort, first built by the Portuguese and then extensively fortified in the 17th century by the Dutch. It is also the largest remaining fortress built by European occupiers in the Asian region. Then relax with an overnight stay at the tranquil and luxurious Fortress Resort and Spa.
An optional early morning whale watching tour is also available in the world’s best waters for Blue Whales (November to March).

After breakfast on the final day, you will be transferred to the Katunayake International Airport for your flight back to bring your lavish adventure to an end. You can also choose our suggested tour extensions or a custom extension to suit your needs.

dayInfo.description: NEGOMBO: Arrive into Colombo International Airport and head straight to The Wallawwa, an 18-room boutique hotel, to recuperate amidst peaceful surroundings. Set in a big tropical garden, this former manor house indulges couples with its chic collection of rooms, its gourmet cuisine, its discreet service and its decadent spa. Be on the beach in 30 minutes, play a round of croquet or take a private guided tour by boat through the bird-filled Muthurajawela Wetlands. Colombo’s restaurants, shops and sights are a mere 30-40 minutes’ drive away. Travel time Colombo Airport to The Wallawwa: 20 minutes. Stay 2 nights at The Wallawwa

SIGIRIYA: Continue up into Sri Lanka’s historic Cultural Triangle, so-called for the collection of World Heritage Sites and significant attractions located up here. You’ll stay at Water Garden – Sigiriya, one of the region’s newest boutique hotels, which is within eye-sight of one of the island’s most photographed attractions, Sigiriya. This former rock-top fortress dates back to the seventh century, and is home to superb examples of ancient hydro engineering as well as well-preserved frescoes. A hike up to the summit, where the views are incredible, will be a highlight of your holiday. The hotel’s rooms are all freestanding villas, and offer plenty of space – the most indulgent have private plunge pools – and there’s also a lovely spa. Other notable local sights include Dambulla’s Cave Temples while further afield you could try your luck seeking out elephants in Minneriya National Park, or visit Polonnaruwa or Anuradhapura, two former ancient capitals, and both World Heritage Sites. Travel time The Wallawwa to Water Garden: 4 hours. Stay 3 nights at Water Garden - Sigiriya.

KANDY: From Sigiriya, travel direct to Santani, which lies to the north east of Kandy. This superb wellness resort has won numerous accolades since its inception in 2016 and is an extremely tranquil base for exploring the surrounding area. The hotel has first class wellness facilities including an excellent spa, and is a rare destination for escaping the world. Despite the high quality spa and wellness facilities, you can just use the hotel as a base to do very little at all or for exploring some of Kandy’s lesser known sights. These includes wanders down to a river for wild swims, nature trails and day trips to The Knuckles Range, a biodiversity hotspot. The architecture is purposefully minimal and WiFi is only available in rooms on request. Yoga classes, wellness packages and spa treatments are all on available to you once you arrive. Kandy’s sights are around a 60- to 90-minute drive away. Other options in Kandy include The Kandy House, a gorgeous restored manor house home to nine rooms, and the more secluded family friendly Taylors Hill. Travel time Sigiriya to Kandy: 3 hours. Stay 3 nights at Santani, The Kandy House or Taylors Hill.

KANDAPOLA (NUWARA ELIYA): From Kandy, travel south to the highest region of the Hill Country, and to Kandapola, north east of Nuwara Eliya. This is one of Sri Lanka’s most spectacular regions, and the higher elevation means that the climate, especially at night, is a little cooler. Goatfell is a five-bedroom former estate manager’s bungalow located at an elevation of some 2000-metres. The bungalow has been charmingly restored and offers contemporary and luxurious comforts, great food, butler service and gardens with a swimming pool. Tea estates surround the bungalow and wanders to the local tea factory and strolls through the neighboring estates are some of the highlights of a stay here. Nuwara Eliya, a former British colonial hill station, is 30-minutes away. Travel time Santani to Kandapola (Nuwara Eliya): 3.5 hours. Stay 3 nights at Goatfell.

YALA NATIONAL PARK: Descend the hills to Noel Rodrigo’s Leopard Safaris and to the edge of Yala National Park, stopping off enroute at Buduruwagala – a series of seven well-preserved Buddhist figures carved into sheer rock. Yala National Park is the island’s premier game reserve, home to a dense population of leopards, as well as elephants and sloth bears. Camping at the edge of the park is a magical once-in-a-lifetime experience; Noel Rodrigo’s Leopard Safaris has comfortable family and double tents, and included in the rate are two game drives per day led by experienced local guides. Travel time Kandapola (Nuwara Eliya) to Yala National Park: 5 hours. Stay 3 nights at Noel Rodrigo’s Leopard Safaris.

GALLE: Make your way down to the southern coast and head west to Galle, famed for pretty beaches, a 17th century Dutch fort and a cosmopolitan vibe. One option (ideal for families) is to stay at the lovely Why House, a 10-bedroom boutique hotel in lush gardens a few minutes’ drive inland. Beaches are just a short drive away, and there are a host of activities to enjoy in the local area from inland bicycle rides through picture-postcard rice fields to diving, surfing and fishing. Another accommodation option in Galle is Fort Bazaar, a superbly renovated 18-bedroom boutique hotel in the heart of the historic Galle Fort. From here you can wander the fort’s famed cobbled streets at will, shopping and sightseeing, or discover hidden crevices with local guides Travel time Yala National Park to Galle: 3 hours. Stay 3 nights at Why House OR Fort Bazaar.

BALAPITIYA: From Galle, it’s just an hour’s drive to Balapitiya, a small coastal village on Sri Lanka’s sunset coast. Kumu Beach, located above a sandy stretch of beach edged by huge boulders, is set in its own private palm-shaded garden with a 23-metre swimming pool. The hotel was completed in 2017, and offers 10 bedrooms, four of which are very spacious Oceanview Suites with private lounges and superb sea views. This is a lovely place to relax and unwind; the hotel has a contemporary design style, and its kitchen produces fabulous local and fusion cuisine for enjoying on the long timber deck, beside the swimming pool or anywhere in the garden. The region is a centre for Sri Lankan folk culture with mask museums nearby at Ambalangoda and a number of attractions within reach including Lunuganga, the home and garden of the late Geoffrey Bawa, and Bentota for water sports action. Travel time Galle to Balapitiya: 1 hour. Stay 2 nights at Kumu Beach.

COLOMBO: Head to Sri Lanka’s up-and-coming capital for your last night, staying in a fabulous eight-bedroom heritage hotel. The city makes an exciting end to your Sri Lankan journey, and offers good souvenir shopping (Barefoot, Odel and Paradise Road are favourites), great restaurants (we love Monsoon), a few art galleries (the Saskia Fernando Gallery is nearby) and historical sites such as the National Museum and Number 11, Geoffrey Bawa’s fascinating former home. You can also enjoy hosted walks around Colombo. Maniumpathy dates back to 1906 and was commissioned by a doctor from Jaffna whose descendants lived in the house until recently. Sister hotel to The Kandy House and The Last House, this boutique hotel has been renovated for the modern age whilst preserving its sense of history. It is also incredibly peaceful, and makes a superb base for a last night in Sri Lanka. Travel time Galle to Colombo: 2 hours. Stay 1 night at Maniumpathy.
DEPART SRI LANKA: Travel time Colombo to Colombo Airport: 45-minutes

dayInfo.description: NEGOMBO: Arrive into Colombo International Airport and head straight to The Wallawwa, an 18-room boutique hotel, to recuperate amidst startlingly peaceful surroundings. Set in an expansive tropical garden, this former manor house indulges couples with its chic collection of rooms, its gourmet cuisine, its discreet service and its decadent spa, which is the venue for post- and pre-flight pampering. Be on the beach in 30 minutes, play a round of croquet in the garden or take a private guided tour by boat through the pretty bird-filled Muthurajawela Wetlands. Colombo’s restaurants, shops and sights are a mere 30 to 40-minutes’ drive away. Travel time Colombo Airport to The Wallawwa: 20 minutes. Stay 1 night at The Wallawwa.

CASTLEREAGH RESERVOIR. From The Wallawwa, head into the western hill country to Camellia Hills, above the Castlereagh Reservoir. This newly built five-bedroom boutique hotel by Teardrop Hotels is a contemporary interpretation of a tea planters home. Each of the five bedrooms are unique, with views of the lake and/or the tea fields and jungle that edge the garden. The feel is very much like a country home with butlers on hand to tend to guests and a superb chef to prepare meals. The climate in the hills is cooler, especially at night, and a roaring fire adds plenty of romantic atmosphere every evening. The hotel has a small swimming pool and activities include walks through the tea estates, scenic picnics, waterfall trails, lake boat tours and visits to a tea factory. Travel time Negombo to Castlereagh Reservoir: 4 hours. Stay 3 nights at Camellia Hills.

DEMODARA (ELLA): Travel to the western Hill Country, which is equally spectacular yet has a different feel. On your way, you could go via Nuwara Eliya to check out the colonial-era sights of this former British Hill Station and pause there for lunch. Around town are allotments bursting with leeks, potatoes, carrots and other vegetables and the region is also well known for growing strawberries. You could also take the train to Demodera from Hatton, which offers one of the most spectacular routes through the Hill Country. Demodera is close to better-known Ella (15-minutes away), yet is a secluded and much quieter place to stay. Nine Skies is located just above the railway line, and the station itself is famous for its 360-degree loop of track while nearby is the Nine Arch Bridge, after which the bungalow was named. The bungalow has been beautifully refurbished and offers plush contemporary comforts including butler service, excellent food and a garden with swimming pool. Attractions include tea factory visits, tea trails, waterfall swims and hill walks. Travel time Castlereagh Reservoir to Demodera: 4 hours. Stay 2 nights at Nine Skies.

KOGGALA LAKE: Travel south to reach the island’s picturesque southern coastline, and continue on towards Galle, famed for pretty beaches, a 17th century Dutch fort and a cosmopolitan vibe. Here you’ll stay inland from Galle, in the vicinity of Koggala Lake, Sri Lanka’s second largest inland waterway at Kahanda Kanda, set on its own 12-acre hilltop tea estate, a 30-minute drive inland from Galle. This is a blissful boutique hotels ideal for honeymooners. Nearly all of the ten exquisite suites at Kahanda Kanda are freestanding (immensely private Dubu, with its own pool, is fabulous, although there are three suites with pools) and from furnished terraces enjoy views over the tropical gardens, tea fields and distant Koggala Lake. Dine alfresco, relax poolside, enjoy a spa treatment, take a guided bicycle ride through picture-postcard rice fields, make for the beach or tour the hotel’s own tea estate. Travel time Demodera (Ella) to Koggala Lake: 5 hours. Stay 3 nights at Kahanda Kanda.

BALAPITIYA: From Koggala Lake, it’s just an hour and a bit’s drive to Kumu Beach in Balapitiya, a small coastal village on Sri Lanka’s sunset coast. The hotel is located above a sandy stretch of beach edged by huge boulders, in its own private palm-shaded garden with a 23-metre swimming pool. The hotel was completed in 2017, and offers 10 bedrooms, four of which are very spacious Oceanview Suites with private lounges and superb sea views. This is a lovely place to relax and unwind; the hotel has a contemporary design style, and its kitchen produces fabulous local and fusion cuisine for enjoying on the long timber deck, beside the swimming pool or anywhere in the garden. The region is a centre for Sri Lankan folk culture with mask museums nearby at Ambalangoda and a number of attractions within reach including Lunuganga, the home and garden of the late Geoffrey Bawa, plus Bentota for water sports action. Travel time Galle to Balapitiya: 1 hour 15 minutes. Stay 3 nights at Kumu Beach.

COLOMBO: Head to Sri Lanka’s up-and-coming capital for your last night, staying in Maniumpathy, a fabulous eight-bedroom heritage hotel. Maniumpathy dates back to 1906 and was commissioned by a doctor from Jaffna whose descendants lived in the house until recently. This peaceful boutique hotel has been renovated for the modern age whilst preserving its sense of history. The city offers good souvenir shopping (Barefoot, Odel and Paradise Road are favourites), great restaurants (we love Monsoon), art galleries (Saskia Fernando Gallery is nearby) and historical sites such as the National Museum and Number 11, Geoffrey Bawa’s fascinating former home. You can also enjoy hosted walks around Colombo with local expert Mark Forbes. Travel time Balapitiya to Colombo: 2 hours. Stay 1 night at Maniumpathy.
DEPART SRI LANKA: Travel time Colombo to Colombo Airport: 45-minutes

tourName: Sri Lanka off the beaten track holiday
generalInfo:
Welcome to our unique 14-day authentic off the beaten track holiday of Sri Lanka...

This holiday is tailor-made for you by your local guides Rajiv who has been working with tourists for the past 20 years and has an immense knowledge of his 'teardrop' island he calls home together with his wife Gillian. Rajiv has included both touristy activities and off the beaten track locations...

On your arrival in Sri Lanka, you will be met by your local team Gillian and Rajiv. We are both passionate about travel and local food and this makes us the best local team to travel with during your holiday.

We have designed this holiday for you from start to end with one key element in mind which is peace of mind.

Sri Lanka a paradise that we proudly call the Pearl of the Indian Ocean is surrounded by golden sandy beaches, majestic rainforest-covered mountains, cascading waterfalls, UNESCO heritage sites, sacred rock temples, tea plantations, and ancient royal cities.

During your holiday you will visit the must-see touristy sites of Sri Lanka and many off the beaten track locations including UNESCO world heritage sites and national parks.

One key element to consider when visiting Sri Lanka is the tropical weather. We as responsible and honest travel agents recommend this holiday between February and October to minimize the chance of rain especially when you are relaxing at the beach.

Our standard itinerary gives you the opportunity to encounter herds of wild elephants, the elusive leopards, and endangered sloth bears of Sri Lanka including hundreds of bird species in the company of a local guide or ranger. cultural, natural, and historic attractions are unsurpassed in this authentic off the beaten track holiday of Sri Lanka including amazing local food.

All hotels are locally owned and managed and you will be transported in the comfort of your own privet chauffeur-driven vehicle, where you sit back and enjoy a bespoke itinerary that is as unique and individual as you. All our vehicles are fully insured and driven by experienced chauffeurs.

Anyone can visit Sri Lanka, but not everyone gets the chance to chat over dinner or travel together with a local host, take a safari at dawn with a knowledgeable ranger, and get the best seats on one of the most scenic railway journeys in the world. You need a local specialist to provide you with insider information, make arrangements using local contacts, and advise on the best times of year to visit different areas.

Our family-operated company has been doing just that since 2004 and 50% of our business comes from personal referrals and repeat business. We strongly believe in responsible and sustainable tourism and are proud of the fact that 90% of your tour fee stays in Sri Lanka.

Sri Lanka is ready for you, so why not contact us today and allow us to design a unique, tailor-made Sri Lanka holiday to suit your specific interests and ideas.

We look forward to hearing from you today.

WELLCOME TO SRI LANKA MACHANG!

tourName: Sri Lanka off the beaten track tour
generalInfo:
A splendid tour for adventurous couples or friends, who would like to see the classics of Sri Lanka as well as its hidden treasures off the beaten track. Experience exclusive and remote resorts and activities, while in the midst of nature, enjoying hikes and plenty of wildlife. A highlight of this tour is the possibility to see the Asian elephant swimming in its natural habitat in Gal Oya, the only place where you can take a boat safari in Sri Lanka.

Includes:
- Accommodation on Bed & Breakfast basis at Jetwing Beach (1 Night | Deluxe Room), Aliya Resort & Spa (2 Nights | Deluxe Room), Clove Villa (2 Nights | Deluxe Room), 98 Acres Resort (2 nights | Superior Room), Buckingham Place (3 Nights | Balcony Room) and Fortaleza Church Cross Street (1 Night | Turquoise Room)
- Accommodation on Half Board basis at The Ibis (2 Nights | Standard A/C Room)
- Accommodation on Full Board basis at Gal Oya Lodge (2 Nights | Bungalow)
- Transport in an air conditioned car with the services of an English Speaking Guide.
- Guided Visits and Excursions:
Sigiriya
Polonnaruwa

Royal Botanical Gardens
Temple of the Tooth
Tea Factory visit
Little Adam’s Peak
Nine Arch Bridge

2 game drives at Wilpattu
Galle Fort walk with your guide
